description: The Amazon Web Services Certified SysOps Administrator (ACSA) certification is designed for professionals responsible for supporting deployments running in the AWS cloud. Topics covered include managing cloud based database instances, implementing security in the cloud and supporting virtual servers. The ACSA is an associate level certification intended as a starting point for technicians seeking AWS certification.

episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore security in Amazon Web Services, both what AWS implements to keep our environment secure as well as what the customer is responsible for. They begin with AWS security measures, specifically infrastructure security like, power redundancy, cooling, and proper data disposal. AWS also provides hardware redundancy, hypervisor isolation, and firewalling.

you want to double check your servers.

684
00:31:13.294 --> 00:31:16.497
You want to scan your servers and check
to make sure they are actually secure.

685
00:31:16.497 --> 00:31:18.611
Amazon is telling me
there's redundant routes.

686
00:31:18.611 --> 00:31:20.584
They're telling me there
is IP spoofing protection.

687
00:31:20.584 --> 00:31:22.348
But, do I really know that?

688
00:31:22.348 --> 00:31:23.440
Maybe I wanna test it.

689
00:31:23.440 --> 00:31:26.761
So the temptation may be there for
you to do pen testing on your server.

690
00:31:26.761 --> 00:31:28.154
Be very careful, all right?

691
00:31:28.154 --> 00:31:30.742
It's actually in the Amazon terms of
service that you're not allowed to pen

692
00:31:30.742 --> 00:31:31.520
test your own server.

693
00:31:31.520 --> 00:31:33.564
But that doesn't mean you can't do it.

694
00:31:33.564 --> 00:31:36.702
The reason they put that in there is
if you start pen testing your server,

695
00:31:36.702 --> 00:31:39.647
they're gonna view it as an attack and
they're gonna block it off.

696
00:31:39.647 --> 00:31:41.783
So your pen test isn't gonna work, right?

697
00:31:41.783 --> 00:31:43.872
Or I guess technically,
you could say that it did work, right?

698
00:31:43.872 --> 00:31:44.964
That it was protected.

699
00:31:44.964 --> 00:31:47.332
But if you actually
wanna scan your system.

700
00:31:47.332 --> 00:31:50.769
All that they ask is that you open
a support ticket with them first.

701
00:31:50.769 --> 00:31:55.499
Open a support ticket and say hey, I'd
like to run a security scan on my system.

702
00:31:55.499 --> 00:32:00.049
I'm gonna be coming from this IP, you need
to tell them the IP you're coming from,

703
00:32:00.049 --> 00:32:02.000
and I'm gonna scan it at this time.

704
00:32:02.000 --> 00:32:04.160
And then wait for their approval,
they'll give you approval.

705
00:32:04.160 --> 00:32:05.926
If you just submit the ticket and
then do the scan,

706
00:32:05.926 --> 00:32:07.620
then you might as well
not have done the ticket.

707
00:32:07.620 --> 00:32:11.077
But if you get their approval,
then they'll open up a window,

708
00:32:11.077 --> 00:32:13.239
a time where they allow your IP to scan.

709
00:32:13.239 --> 00:32:17.881
And it's actually pretty nice because
they'll disable some of the Amazon checks

710
00:32:17.881 --> 00:32:21.389
that happen on that IP to let you
get a true scan of that server.

711
00:32:21.389 --> 00:32:26.342
So, definitely be aware of that,
even if you're pen testing from another

712
00:32:26.342 --> 00:32:30.048
instance in the same VPC,
they're still scanning it.

713
00:32:30.048 --> 00:32:34.589
All traffic in a VPC, even traffic going
between two hosts in the same VPC,

714
00:32:34.589 --> 00:32:37.200
still pass through the firewall service.

715
00:32:37.200 --> 00:32:39.127
Amazon still sees it.

716
00:32:39.127 --> 00:32:42.042
So even though our hosts think they're on
the same network and talk to each other

717
00:32:42.042 --> 00:32:44.708
directly, they're actually going
through Amazon security filters.

718
00:32:44.708 --> 00:32:47.842
So you've always got to open a support
team with them first, really important.

719
00:32:47.842 --> 00:32:48.608
Awesome stuff.

720
00:32:48.608 --> 00:32:51.581
Thank you so much Don, for
explaining some of this AWS security.

721
00:32:51.581 --> 00:32:55.151
What they're responsible for, what we're
responsible for, how that mixes up,

722
00:32:55.151 --> 00:32:58.268
where it is and when it happens,
that's important stuff for us to know.

723
00:32:58.268 --> 00:33:00.613
Is there anything else we need to
cover before we close the show?

724
00:33:00.613 --> 00:33:01.263
I think that's it.

725
00:33:01.263 --> 00:33:04.025
I wanna move onto some other topics
where we'll take a look at some of

726
00:33:04.025 --> 00:33:07.239
the actual security features,
especially identity and access management.

727
00:33:07.239 --> 00:33:09.399
But that's for another show.

728
00:33:09.399 --> 00:33:11.488
Yeah, time is short and fleeting.

729
00:33:11.488 --> 00:33:13.207
So that being said, we'll go ahead and
close this show down.

730
00:33:13.207 --> 00:33:14.367
Thanks for watching.

731
00:33:14.367 --> 00:33:15.923
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

732
00:33:15.923 --> 00:33:16.759
And I'm Don Pezet.

733
00:33:16.759 --> 00:33:18.547
And we'll see you next time.

734
00:33:18.547 --> 00:33:24.300
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain what Identity and Access Management(IAM) is and the different components therein. They start by explaining the different types of credentials that can be used with IAM; things like passwords, access keys, key pairs, and x.509 certificates, then quickly touching on IAM users, groups, roles and policies. Then they discuss when you would use one form of access over the others and even when NOT to use an access type.
episodes.title: IAM Components
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.887 --> 00:00:13.247
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.247 --> 00:00:16.253
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.253 --> 00:00:17.810
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.810 --> 00:00:20.770
And in this episode we're
gonna talk about the IAM.

6
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:22.028
That's right.

7
00:00:22.028 --> 00:00:26.638
It is the Identity and
Access Management for Amazon Web Services,

8
00:00:26.638 --> 00:00:30.357
specifically looking at
the SysOps certification.

9
00:00:30.357 --> 00:00:34.811
And joining me in the studio today to help
us work through this little hairy bit of

10
00:00:34.811 --> 00:00:37.150
a topic is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:38.251
Welcome to the show, Don.

12
00:00:38.251 --> 00:00:40.662
>> All right, Daniel, thanks for
having me back on the show and

13
00:00:40.662 --> 00:00:43.407
I'm pretty excited to talk about
this cuz it's an important topic,

14
00:00:43.407 --> 00:00:45.134
and it's one that wasn't always around.

15
00:00:45.134 --> 00:00:49.350
If you guys started with AWS in
the early days, IAM didn't exist.

16
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:51.916
You signed in with a username and
password and that was the end of it.

17
00:00:51.916 --> 00:00:57.174
And it's really evolved over the years to
include a lot of additional functionality,

18
00:00:57.174 --> 00:00:59.775
and just a much stronger form of security.

19
00:00:59.775 --> 00:01:02.433
We get a lot of power with IAM, so
we definitely need to take a look at it.

20
00:01:02.433 --> 00:01:04.770
We need to understand each of
the individual components and

21
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:06.833
when they're appropriate for
the right solution.

22
00:01:06.833 --> 00:01:08.110
So that's what we're gonna tackle.

23
00:01:08.110 --> 00:01:09.329
>> Awesome, well,
it's gonna be a lot of fun.

24
00:01:09.329 --> 00:01:12.892
It's a very interesting topic as I
was looking this over for the show.

25
00:01:12.892 --> 00:01:16.001
Now, Don,
I've played around with AWS before and

26
00:01:16.001 --> 00:01:20.482
I've spun up a little microinstance,
a very easy, simple thing to do and

27
00:01:20.482 --> 00:01:24.409
all I used was a username and
password, so that was pretty easy.

28
00:01:24.409 --> 00:01:28.089
But what it looks like is, it gets
a little more complex than doing that.

29
00:01:28.089 --> 00:01:30.803
Help us out with this,
tell us some of the components,

30
00:01:30.803 --> 00:01:34.400
some of the ways that we can use
other than usernames and passwords.

31
00:01:34.400 --> 00:01:37.439
>> This is one of the areas where people
can sometimes have problems on the exam,

32
00:01:37.439 --> 00:01:39.352
because a lot of people do
set up a demo on a trial,

33
00:01:39.352 --> 00:01:42.674
or whatever, they're experimenting with
and you just log in with your username and

34
00:01:42.674 --> 00:01:43.743
password, works great.

35
00:01:43.743 --> 00:01:45.403
But think about a company.

36
00:01:45.403 --> 00:01:49.282
What if you're a company and
you have 20 system admins, right.

37
00:01:49.282 --> 00:01:50.048
Or 20 SysOps or

38
00:01:50.048 --> 00:01:53.681
whatever DEV, DEVOP, whatever crazy
terms they're calling us these days.

39
00:01:53.681 --> 00:01:58.114
So you have 20 staff and you want them
all to be able to get in there and

40
00:01:58.114 --> 00:02:03.310
work on your S3 buckets,
your RDS databases, your EC2 instances.

41
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:06.260
Well, you might have some employees you
want to have access to one resource and

42
00:02:06.260 --> 00:02:08.370
other employees access
to different resources.

43
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:11.010
You would have different levels
of access you wanna grant.

44
00:02:11.010 --> 00:02:15.097
Like your help desk, you might want them
to be able to login and see everything,

45
00:02:15.097 --> 00:02:16.442
but not change anything.

46
00:02:16.442 --> 00:02:21.949
But then your DBAs, you want them to have
full control over your RDS deployment.

47
00:02:21.949 --> 00:02:24.440
Well, with the username and
password like Daniel described,

48
00:02:24.440 --> 00:02:26.470
you don't really have that granularity,
right?

49
00:02:26.470 --> 00:02:30.029
I don't wanna just share this one username
and password with all of my staff,

50
00:02:30.029 --> 00:02:33.667
cuz then they all have full access and
in theory could really wreak some havoc.

51
00:02:33.667 --> 00:02:37.033
And if an employee leaves the company,
now I've gotta change the username and

52
00:02:37.033 --> 00:02:38.161
password for everybody.

53
00:02:38.161 --> 00:02:42.560
So, fortunately Amazon gives us a lot
of different ways to authenticate and

54
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:45.323
a lot of different ways
to dole out privileges.

55
00:02:45.323 --> 00:02:49.128
Instead of giving somebody the whole set,
which is really the easiest route,

56
00:02:49.128 --> 00:02:52.933
we can go a little bit tighter and we can
really be specific about this is the type

57
00:02:52.933 --> 00:02:56.567
of access that I want that user to have
and that's all I'm gonna give them,

58
00:02:56.567 --> 00:02:57.686
not anything beyond.

59
00:02:57.686 --> 00:02:58.882
That is a standard security practice.

60
00:02:58.882 --> 00:03:00.856
It's got a name in the security world,
what do they call it,

61
00:03:00.856 --> 00:03:02.040
the principal of least privilege?

62
00:03:02.040 --> 00:03:03.456
>> Yep, principal of least privilege,
that's it.

63
00:03:03.456 --> 00:03:05.081
>> There we go, I remember some
things from security training.

64
00:03:05.081 --> 00:03:05.743
>> Very nice.

65
00:03:05.743 --> 00:03:06.588
[LAUGH]
>> So

66
00:03:06.588 --> 00:03:10.036
principal of least privilege says you
shouldn't give somebody any more access

67
00:03:10.036 --> 00:03:13.278
than the bare minimum they need,
because even if they're not malicious,

68
00:03:13.278 --> 00:03:15.042
they could potentially make mistakes.

69
00:03:15.042 --> 00:03:17.979
And you don't want them making mistakes
outside of the area that they work in.

70
00:03:17.979 --> 00:03:20.033
It's okay if they mess their own stuff up.

71
00:03:20.033 --> 00:03:21.275
>> Yeah, well, good for them, right?

72
00:03:21.275 --> 00:03:23.341
>> [LAUGH]
>> Go ahead, enjoy that.

73
00:03:23.341 --> 00:03:28.252
So now we can separate out people, and
this is just common security practice.

74
00:03:28.252 --> 00:03:31.041
If you're running a Windows operating
system you're probably running

75
00:03:31.041 --> 00:03:31.736
multiple users.

76
00:03:31.736 --> 00:03:33.870
Same kind of idea applies right here.

77
00:03:33.870 --> 00:03:36.590
So that if Don does something,
it was Don that did it,

78
00:03:36.590 --> 00:03:39.805
we can see it was Don that did it,
and not Daniel, he can't fire me.

79
00:03:39.805 --> 00:03:40.400
[LAUGH]
>> All right, so

80
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:43.720
let's take a look at our AWS console, and
we'll get a chance to see how this works.

81
00:03:43.720 --> 00:03:46.392
And so
I'm logged in to my console here, and

82
00:03:46.392 --> 00:03:51.171
IAM actually has its own little area way
down here under Security & Identity.

83
00:03:51.171 --> 00:03:53.608
So that's what I'm looking for,
is Identity & Access Management.

84
00:03:53.608 --> 00:03:57.230
And you'll see the description,
Manage User Access and Encryption Keys.

85
00:03:57.230 --> 00:03:58.774
That's exactly what I want.

86
00:03:58.774 --> 00:04:02.105
There's other stuff, like
Directory Services, the Inspector, WAF,

87
00:04:02.105 --> 00:04:02.813
those things.

88
00:04:02.813 --> 00:04:06.506
But IAM is the one that's on the exam,
and it's a decent part on the exam.

89
00:04:06.506 --> 00:04:09.037
You're gonna have a couple of
questions on this at least, so

90
00:04:09.037 --> 00:04:10.487
you can pretty much count on that.

91
00:04:10.487 --> 00:04:12.903
They stress security a lot on the exam.

92
00:04:12.903 --> 00:04:17.163
So when you jump in the IAM,
first off, they welcome you to it.

93
00:04:17.163 --> 00:04:20.622
They really want you to use this, so
they try to make it as easy as possible.

94
00:04:20.622 --> 00:04:23.492
And so right here,
I'm basically seeing my sign-on link,

95
00:04:23.492 --> 00:04:26.207
if I wanna sign into my account,
this is where I can go to.

96
00:04:26.207 --> 00:04:28.910
Now I don't normally worry about that.

97
00:04:28.910 --> 00:04:34.542
When I go to log in, I just go to
console.aws.amazon.com and I log in as me.

98
00:04:34.542 --> 00:04:36.469
But that's because I own the account.

99
00:04:36.469 --> 00:04:40.430
If I'm a user on the account, though,
I have to go to this address.

100
00:04:40.430 --> 00:04:42.990
So you can customize that,
change it to a unique name.

101
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:46.230
You can do a CNAME in DNS to
make it easier for your users.

102
00:04:46.230 --> 00:04:49.330
But they need that so that Amazon will
know what account they're tied to and

103
00:04:49.330 --> 00:04:51.285
then you can start to
create user accounts.

104
00:04:51.285 --> 00:04:53.939
You'll see I already have one
user account on my system.

105
00:04:53.939 --> 00:04:56.553
But it's giving me some security
status messages down here and

106
00:04:56.553 --> 00:04:58.130
I'm even getting some warnings.

107
00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:01.390
And it's telling me I need to
delete my root access keys.

108
00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:04.672
Now I've got a green check mark, or
a green box with a white check mark,

109
00:05:04.672 --> 00:05:06.600
telling me that I've already done that.

110
00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:08.300
So some things I've kind
of already brought up.

111
00:05:08.300 --> 00:05:10.962
But I haven't activated MFA.

112
00:05:10.962 --> 00:05:14.121
I haven't, well I guess I have,
created individual IAM users.

113
00:05:14.121 --> 00:05:17.059
I haven't used groups
to assign permissions.

114
00:05:17.059 --> 00:05:19.079
These are things that
we need to implement.

115
00:05:19.079 --> 00:05:23.118
Amazon does not require them because
this has evolved over the years.

116
00:05:23.118 --> 00:05:26.485
So it was deployed originally
where you had root access keys,

117
00:05:26.485 --> 00:05:30.175
a single key that would give you
full access to the whole system, and

118
00:05:30.175 --> 00:05:33.240
you just shared that with
the employees that needed it.

119
00:05:33.240 --> 00:05:35.020
It was risky, right?

120
00:05:35.020 --> 00:05:37.980
And now we've moved beyond it so
you don't need those anymore.

121
00:05:37.980 --> 00:05:41.800
So if you still have them, it'll tell
you you should really delete them.

122
00:05:41.800 --> 00:05:43.042
Okay.

123
00:05:43.042 --> 00:05:45.591
If you don't know if you
still have those old keys,

124
00:05:45.591 --> 00:05:47.442
you can go up to your account up here.

125
00:05:47.442 --> 00:05:49.456
So I'm just gonna click
on my account name and

126
00:05:49.456 --> 00:05:51.634
under there you'll see
security credentials.

127
00:05:51.634 --> 00:05:55.058
And you can jump under security
credentials and it's gonna warn us.

128
00:05:55.058 --> 00:05:56.680
It's gonna say, wait a minute.

129
00:05:56.680 --> 00:06:00.620
Are you sure you wanna go to this screen,
because IAM has replaced this.

130
00:06:00.620 --> 00:06:01.886
So that's what it's telling me.

131
00:06:01.886 --> 00:06:06.081
And I can get started with IAM users if I
want, but I want to continue to security

132
00:06:06.081 --> 00:06:09.146
credentials cuz I want to see
the old way of doing things.

133
00:06:09.146 --> 00:06:12.838
And if I jump in here, I can start
to see my security credentials.

134
00:06:12.838 --> 00:06:14.444
Now, I know what you guys are thinking,

135
00:06:14.444 --> 00:06:17.100
is Don about to bring up his security
credentials up on the screen?

136
00:06:17.100 --> 00:06:17.842
Well, absolutely.

137
00:06:17.842 --> 00:06:20.792
>> [LAUGH]
>> So the neat part about a lot of these

138
00:06:20.792 --> 00:06:24.126
credentials is once you create them in
the system, it won't actually show you

139
00:06:24.126 --> 00:06:27.383
the passwords anymore and a lot of times,
Amazon doesn't even store them.

140
00:06:27.383 --> 00:06:30.519
If you don't store the copy,
then it's just gone forever.

141
00:06:30.519 --> 00:06:33.851
But if I had a password,
we would see that set right here and

142
00:06:33.851 --> 00:06:35.823
I can change my password if I want.

143
00:06:35.823 --> 00:06:40.863
If I've done multi-factor authentication,
MFA, I can see if it's turned on.

144
00:06:40.863 --> 00:06:41.896
I have not.

145
00:06:41.896 --> 00:06:44.215
That's why I was getting that warning
a moment ago so I could turn this on.

146
00:06:44.215 --> 00:06:49.504
The user account that owns this
deployment is called the root account and

147
00:06:49.504 --> 00:06:53.500
this is my root account and
I should activate MFA on it.

148
00:06:53.500 --> 00:06:56.333
We'll talk more about why and
what it does and why it's important.

149
00:06:56.333 --> 00:07:01.550
But you'll also see the access keys, and
these are the old style access keys.

150
00:07:01.550 --> 00:07:06.200
And basically the way it worked
is you had an access key ID, and

151
00:07:06.200 --> 00:07:08.352
you had a access secret key.

152
00:07:08.352 --> 00:07:11.109
And the secret key you saw
when you created it, and

153
00:07:11.109 --> 00:07:14.597
then Amazon throws it away and
won't show it to you ever again.

154
00:07:14.597 --> 00:07:17.806
So that's why I don't mind showing these
access keys on the screen because I know

155
00:07:17.806 --> 00:07:20.750
you need the secret, and I don't even
have the secret for these anymore.

156
00:07:20.750 --> 00:07:22.320
[LAUGH] I've lost them a long time ago.

157
00:07:22.320 --> 00:07:24.685
You'll see these were
created earlier this year.

158
00:07:24.685 --> 00:07:26.305
>> So these are basically useless now.

159
00:07:26.305 --> 00:07:27.785
>> Yeah, well, and
they're all deleted too.

160
00:07:27.785 --> 00:07:29.625
See how I've got this deleted column?

161
00:07:29.625 --> 00:07:33.293
So I've got a record of the fact that
they did exist, but they are deleted.

162
00:07:33.293 --> 00:07:37.150
If I create a new one, right, so if I
go in here and create a new access key,

163
00:07:37.150 --> 00:07:38.529
I can hit Show Access Key.

164
00:07:38.529 --> 00:07:43.134
Here's my access key ID and
here's my secret access key.

165
00:07:43.134 --> 00:07:46.435
In theory, if somebody's watching
the show live and they're fast enough,

166
00:07:46.435 --> 00:07:49.378
they can get this information,
load it in, connect to my account and

167
00:07:49.378 --> 00:07:51.134
start spinning up instances right now.

168
00:07:51.134 --> 00:07:52.492
Okay.
Almost there Don.

169
00:07:52.492 --> 00:07:54.512
>> I know [LAUGH]
>> So you've got to have that.

170
00:07:54.512 --> 00:07:58.333
Now once I close this if I don't download
the key final, basically you created that

171
00:07:58.333 --> 00:08:01.950
key, there it is, and then it will never

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don dive further into the Identity and Access Management groups and roles. They start by explaining how access is granted to user accounts through their group membership. Then they explain how Roles allow you to grant access to users outside of your AWS systems. Finally they cover the Security Token Service(STS) to integrate federation services using Security Assertion Markup Language compatible systems like Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services and Shibboleth.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain Identity and Access Management(IAM) security policies. They start by defining IAM security policies, both what they are and how they are implemented for granting access. 00:32:02.340 --> 00:32:04.410
So I need to pull him out of that.

678
00:32:04.410 --> 00:32:05.480
I gave you too much access.

679
00:32:05.480 --> 00:32:07.190
I gave you too much credit.

680
00:32:07.190 --> 00:32:12.180
And so now I've got a VM shutting
down that shouldn't be shutting down.

681
00:32:12.180 --> 00:32:15.078
So I'm going to start that
turkey back up again and

682
00:32:15.078 --> 00:32:18.260
we'll just get that one fired up,
go ahead and start.

683
00:32:18.260 --> 00:32:19.940
Okay, so that one is starting.

684
00:32:19.940 --> 00:32:21.150
And actually,
I've mixed them up haven't I.

685
00:32:21.150 --> 00:32:22.774
So I'll go ahead and
start the other one too.

686
00:32:22.774 --> 00:32:25.390
So, [LAUGH], that way I don't
have to remember which is which.

687
00:32:25.390 --> 00:32:26.730
So I'm gonna start them back up.

688
00:32:26.730 --> 00:32:30.497
So they're starting and now if Daniel were
to reach in there and try and stop them,

689
00:32:30.497 --> 00:32:32.750
we should see something
a little bit different.

690
00:32:32.750 --> 00:32:38.470
That if he tries to stop that instance,
we should get unauthorized operation.

691
00:32:38.470 --> 00:32:41.760
He wasn't allowed to do it, he tried to
call out a server and he couldn't do it.

692
00:32:41.760 --> 00:32:42.600
It wouldn't let him stop it.

693
00:32:42.600 --> 00:32:46.620
If we try the other one,
which was this one.

694
00:32:46.620 --> 00:32:48.180
It's stopping.

695
00:32:48.180 --> 00:32:50.440
Right so
now he has that fine grain privilege.

696
00:32:50.440 --> 00:32:51.970
These security policies
are really powerful.

697
00:32:51.970 --> 00:32:57.050
I definitely encourage you always
attach them to a group if you can.

698
00:32:57.050 --> 00:32:59.570
It's just gonna make life
a heck of a lot easier for you.

699
00:32:59.570 --> 00:33:00.510
>> Yeah.
Very, very cool.

700
00:33:00.510 --> 00:33:03.442
Now, I understand a lot of you are
probably looking at this and think, man,

701
00:33:03.442 --> 00:33:04.650
I'm drinking from a fire hose.

702
00:33:04.650 --> 00:33:05.640
This is a lot of information.

703
00:33:05.640 --> 00:33:08.940
But, if you really break it down,
you'll see that it's not that difficult.

704
00:33:08.940 --> 00:33:12.150
Even though the policies can get complex,
and making sure that they're

705
00:33:12.150 --> 00:33:16.170
attached correctly,
is something that we have to take care of.

706
00:33:16.170 --> 00:33:18.698
But, creating them?
I mean, they give you a lot of tools to

707
00:33:18.698 --> 00:33:22.687
enable you to create good policies
that work exactly how you need them.

708
00:33:22.687 --> 00:33:26.923
They even have policies available for
you that are prebuilt that you can use as

709
00:33:26.923 --> 00:33:31.890
templates, or just use them, exclusively,
to assign privileges and permissions too.

710
00:33:31.890 --> 00:33:34.909
Don is there anything else we need to
know when it comes to these policies?

711
00:33:34.909 --> 00:33:35.915
>> I think that's about it.

712
00:33:35.915 --> 00:33:36.970
Just remember the sky's the limit.

713
00:33:36.970 --> 00:33:37.860
They are hard to write.

714
00:33:37.860 --> 00:33:39.830
You do have the policy generator,
you can use that.

715
00:33:39.830 --> 00:33:40.910
You've got the built in
policies you can copy.

716
00:33:40.910 --> 00:33:43.230
And you can write your own from scratch.

717
00:33:43.230 --> 00:33:43.740
It does work.

718
00:33:43.740 --> 00:33:44.690
We saw it happen here.

719
00:33:44.690 --> 00:33:47.230
Just choose whichever one's best for you.

720
00:33:47.230 --> 00:33:50.010
On the exam they'll expect you
to be able to read a policy and

721
00:33:50.010 --> 00:33:51.310
understand what it does.

722
00:33:51.310 --> 00:33:55.080
So if they show you a policy and say this
user doesn't have the access they should,

723
00:33:55.080 --> 00:33:57.290
you need to be able to
identify why that isn't, or

724
00:33:57.290 --> 00:33:58.700
why they don't have that privilege.

725
00:33:58.700 --> 00:34:00.390
So make sure you're familiar
with that format and

726
00:34:00.390 --> 00:34:02.470
that you understand how they work.

727
00:34:02.470 --> 00:34:03.502
>> Awesome.
Well, Don, thank you so

728
00:34:03.502 --> 00:34:04.211
much for showing us that.

729
00:34:04.211 --> 00:34:05.973
And thank you for watching.

730
00:34:05.973 --> 00:34:08.950
We're going to go ahead and
sign off for IT Pro TV.

731
00:34:08.950 --> 00:34:12.660
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

732
00:34:12.660 --> 00:34:14.580
>> And I'm Don Pazet.

733
00:34:14.580 --> 00:34:15.700
>> And we'll see you next time.

734
00:34:15.700 --> 00:34:16.480
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore some of the additional security tools and practices available to you in Amazon Web Services. First they discuss the AWS Trusted Advisor tool which scans your system testing for best practices which helps you verify your IAM configuration and security. Then they go over the regulatory compliance (e.g. HIPPA/SOX) aspect of your AWS systems to help prepare you in the event your environment is subject to compliance auditing.
episodes.title: Additional Security Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.055 --> 00:00:10.055
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.197 --> 00:00:14.080
All right, greetings, everyone!

3
00:00:14.080 --> 00:00:17.320
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.320 --> 00:00:20.180
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in this episode,

5
00:00:20.180 --> 00:00:24.029
we're continuing on with more
AWS Certified SysOps Administrator.

6
00:00:24.029 --> 00:00:28.384
And joining me in the studio today to help
lend his expertise on this set exam is

7
00:00:28.384 --> 00:00:30.210
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.210 --> 00:00:31.500
How's it going today, Don?

9
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:34.641
It is going great, Daniel,
glad to be back on the show and

10
00:00:34.641 --> 00:00:39.210
ready to jump into what I'm going to call
our security, what is it on Jeopardy?

11
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:39.720
>> Bonus round?

12
00:00:39.720 --> 00:00:42.330
>> Potpourri, yeah,
just a collection of miscellaneous junk

13
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:44.710
that I didn't mentioned
in the other episodes.

14
00:00:44.710 --> 00:00:48.040
We've seen a lot on Identity and
Access Management, and

15
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:49.710
we've seen pretty much
what's gonna be on the exam.

16
00:00:49.710 --> 00:00:51.540
But there's a few other little
questions that could pop up so

17
00:00:51.540 --> 00:00:55.030
I want to talk about some other tools
that we can find inside of AWS,

18
00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:57.610
that are just important for
us to be aware of.

19
00:00:57.610 --> 00:01:00.958
>> Yeah, you make a really good point
there Don, cause we go through all this

20
00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:04.360
time and effort to set up these systems
and make sure they're as secure as we

21
00:01:04.360 --> 00:01:06.861
can make them, but
>> How do we know that we've actually

22
00:01:06.861 --> 00:01:07.814
succeeded on that?

23
00:01:07.814 --> 00:01:09.695
Other than I haven't gotten hacked yet.

24
00:01:09.695 --> 00:01:11.855
Somebody hasn't deleted something yet.

25
00:01:11.855 --> 00:01:13.782
That's basically our standard.

26
00:01:13.782 --> 00:01:15.547
But Amazon does help us out with that.

27
00:01:15.547 --> 00:01:18.843
They do give us some tools
to do a little verification.

28
00:01:18.843 --> 00:01:22.293
>> Yeah and if you sit down and
you read all of the Amazon white papers,

29
00:01:22.293 --> 00:01:26.065
which is fun, you'll learn exactly
how Amazon wants you to set this up.

30
00:01:26.065 --> 00:01:29.269
They're recommended, they're best
practices for getting it configured.

31
00:01:29.269 --> 00:01:31.790
But even if you've read them,
even if you have the best intentions,

32
00:01:31.790 --> 00:01:32.884
it's easy to make mistakes.

33
00:01:32.884 --> 00:01:34.295
Since we set all this stuff up,

34
00:01:34.295 --> 00:01:37.564
you guys have seen it's really spread
out in a lot of different places.

35
00:01:37.564 --> 00:01:41.397
It's centralized in IAM which is nice but
then you've got your users, your groups,

36
00:01:41.397 --> 00:01:42.152
your policies.

37
00:01:42.152 --> 00:01:44.690
And the policies can be applied
in more than one place and

38
00:01:44.690 --> 00:01:45.937
It's easy to mess that up.

39
00:01:45.937 --> 00:01:49.746
And so in AWS, we have what's
called the a Trusted Advisor.

40
00:01:49.746 --> 00:01:52.368
And it's a utility that will
scan your environment and

41
00:01:52.368 --> 00:01:54.990
give you recommendations
about your configuration.

42
00:01:54.990 --> 00:01:57.480
It's really just looking at IAM and
what it does.

43
00:01:57.480 --> 00:01:58.710
Alright, let's take a look at it.

44
00:01:58.710 --> 00:02:00.040
So here in my console,
if I look down here,

45
00:02:00.040 --> 00:02:04.860
it's actually under management
tools not under security.

46
00:02:04.860 --> 00:02:06.530
Which is kind of odd.

47
00:02:06.530 --> 00:02:09.880
But if you go under management tools,
you'll see Trusted Advisor right here and

48
00:02:09.880 --> 00:02:12.490
see how it says optimize performance and
security.

49
00:02:12.490 --> 00:02:16.366
It's not just security, which is
why it's not under security tools,

50
00:02:16.366 --> 00:02:17.799
it's performance also.

51
00:02:17.799 --> 00:02:20.555
It's looking at the way that we
we've got our system set up and

52
00:02:20.555 --> 00:02:23.258
evaluating whether we've done
it in the best way possible.

53
00:02:23.258 --> 00:02:26.480
It's looking at things like
your cost optimization.

54
00:02:26.480 --> 00:02:28.128
Are you doing things
the most effective way?

55
00:02:28.128 --> 00:02:31.725
Amazon doesn't want to bilk you for
every dime they can get out of you.

56
00:02:31.725 --> 00:02:35.055
They want you to use their system
wisely so that you see the benefits and

57
00:02:35.055 --> 00:02:36.359
you keep using it, right.

58
00:02:36.359 --> 00:02:38.396
If you look at an increasing
bill month after month,

59
00:02:38.396 --> 00:02:40.730
you're gonna say man how
can I get away from Amazon.

60
00:02:40.730 --> 00:02:44.589
They want you to stay so how can we
optimized our cost, our performance,

61
00:02:44.589 --> 00:02:47.387
our security, our fault tolerance,
each of them.

62
00:02:47.387 --> 00:02:48.600
And the Trust Advisor,

63
00:02:48.600 --> 00:02:51.699
the cool thing about it is I
don't have to schedule it to run.

64
00:02:51.699 --> 00:02:53.442
It's always running on its own.

65
00:02:53.442 --> 00:02:55.948
So you'll see here,
my checks have been refreshed.

66
00:02:55.948 --> 00:02:57.691
I didn't tell it to do that,
I just came to the page.

67
00:02:57.691 --> 00:02:58.712
It did it for me.

68
00:02:58.712 --> 00:03:01.222
And it's telling me,
welcome to the console apparently,

69
00:03:01.222 --> 00:03:04.600
this is my first time coming here so I
definitely didn't tell it to do anything.

70
00:03:04.600 --> 00:03:08.502
But now I can see what it's looking at.

71
00:03:08.502 --> 00:03:12.217
My Cost Optimization, see how they're all
gray, they're all zeros, well so far,

72
00:03:12.217 --> 00:03:15.070
everything I've done has been
within the free use, usage tier.

73
00:03:15.070 --> 00:03:17.010
I haven't done anything
to deviate from it.

74
00:03:17.010 --> 00:03:20.150
If you start watching in our DC2 episodes,
actually in the route 53 episodes

75
00:03:20.150 --> 00:03:23.210
when I do redundancy,
we'll start racking up some costs.

76
00:03:23.210 --> 00:03:27.120
And so you'll start to see messages here
that indicate areas you might be able to

77
00:03:27.120 --> 00:03:28.235
improve upon.

78
00:03:28.235 --> 00:03:32.307
You might have auto scaling turned on,
and you spawn up 50 VMs,

79
00:03:32.307 --> 00:03:35.950
and you never set a policy to
reduce them back off, right?

80
00:03:35.950 --> 00:03:38.783
And actually take systems out
of the auto scaling pool.

81
00:03:38.783 --> 00:03:42.103
And so, you might be wasting resources
there to help you identify that.

82
00:03:42.103 --> 00:03:45.152
Under performance, you can see that I've
got one green check right there, and

83
00:03:45.152 --> 00:03:46.572
things are looking pretty healthy.

84
00:03:46.572 --> 00:03:50.444
But under security, I've got one
green check and two orange triangles,

85
00:03:50.444 --> 00:03:53.270
which is letting me know
I've got two warnings.

86
00:03:53.270 --> 00:03:56.450
I don't have any errors, I don't have
any really big glaring problems but

87
00:03:56.450 --> 00:03:59.078
I do have some warnings something
I could be doing better.

88
00:03:59.078 --> 00:04:02.990
This is the Amazon looking at their best
practices, everything that's in their

89
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:06.700
white papers looking at what I'm doing and
showing me the difference.

90
00:04:06.700 --> 00:04:09.340
And so if I look down here,
I can see the recommended actions and

91
00:04:09.340 --> 00:04:10.350
here's the two warnings.

92
00:04:10.350 --> 00:04:13.047
I can also start to see those
green check marks and things.

93
00:04:13.047 --> 00:04:16.136
So like the green check mark
that I had here for performance,

94
00:04:16.136 --> 00:04:17.723
I can see my service limits.

95
00:04:17.723 --> 00:04:23.009
And it says here checks for usage that is
more than 80 percent of the service limit,

96
00:04:23.009 --> 00:04:26.297
0 of 31 items have usages
more than 80 percent.

97
00:04:26.297 --> 00:04:29.644
So if I have a server that's
running at 90 percent CPU,

98
00:04:29.644 --> 00:04:33.784
then Amazon recognizes that my
performance is not gonna be very good.

99
00:04:33.784 --> 00:04:37.208
And so they're gonna warn me and
say I should consider spinning

100
00:04:37.208 --> 00:04:41.618
out more instances, or well it's the old
argument do I scale up or do I scale out.

101
00:04:41.618 --> 00:04:44.136
My web server's at 90 percent CPU so
do I scale it up and

102
00:04:44.136 --> 00:04:47.150
add more CPU power to it or do I scale
it out and add more web servers.

103
00:04:47.150 --> 00:04:52.140
Decision's up to me but it lets me know
that it's time to make that decision.

104
00:04:52.140 --> 00:04:54.282
On the security side though,

105
00:04:54.282 --> 00:04:57.770
I've got security groups
specific ports unrestricted.

106
00:04:57.770 --> 00:04:59.940
What's it talking about there?

107
00:04:59.940 --> 00:05:02.980
Well, that means that I've got
some security groups, right.

108
00:05:02.980 --> 00:05:04.940
The software firewall in AWS.

109
00:05:04.940 --> 00:05:09.338
I've got the firewall configured and
there's access that's being

110
00:05:09.338 --> 00:05:13.521
granted to the entire network,
right, to the entire internet.

111
00:05:13.521 --> 00:05:14.682
What's that all about?

112
00:05:14.682 --> 00:05:19.016
Well, expect to see this one on your
account too, because the default security

113
00:05:19.016 --> 00:05:23.367
group has SSH enabled for the whole world,
and that's a management protocol.

114
00:05:23.367 --> 00:05:25.140
And so they're warning me about that.

115
00:05:25.140 --> 00:05:29.075
I should change that so that SSH is
only allowed for my office's IP or

116
00:05:29.075 --> 00:05:30.879
my home IP if I have a static IP.

117
00:05:30.879 --> 00:05:32.922
I should limit that as much as possible.

118
00:05:32.922 --> 00:05:36.380
Because otherwise, people could try to
brute force their way in via SSH and

119
00:05:36.380 --> 00:05:37.840
gain access to your server.

120
00:05:37.840 --> 00:05:41.420
You'll also see it's warning me
about MFA on my root account.

121
00:05:41.420 --> 00:05:43.410
I haven't turned on MFA yet.

122
00:05:43.410 --> 00:05:45.850
For the Root Account,
I should turn that on.

123
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:48.860
It's going to give me
a warning until I do that.

124
00:05:48.860 --> 00:05:52.050
And to take the action,
I can just click on this and

125
00:05:52.050 --> 00:05:54.880
it will take me straight there,
and I can go and set it up.

126
00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:57.880
In fact, here I just jumped to the IAM
screen, and you'll notice it was

127
00:05:57.880 --> 00:06:01.046
already warning me about that and
warning me about an IAM password policy.

128
00:06:01.046 --> 00:06:04.863
Well, the Trusted Advisor didn't
check that password policy did it?

129
00:06:04.863 --> 00:06:06.097
The Trusted Advisor is not magic.

130
00:06:06.097 --> 00:06:08.863
It's not this massive
all-encompassing thing.

131
00:06:08.863 --> 00:06:09.775
It has a few basic checks and

132
00:06:09.775 --> 00:06:11.810
it should make sure that we're
on the right course, right?

133
00:06:11.810 --> 00:06:13.180
But it's not hard to run.

134
00:06:13.180 --> 00:06:17.350
It's very easy to turn the Trusted Advisor
on, get it doing its stuff.

135
00:06:17.350 --> 00:06:22.700
In fact to turn it on,
all I did was clicked on Trusted Advisor.

136
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:25.170
That's it not a whole heck
of a lot to go there.

137
00:06:25.170 --> 00:06:29.940
But it's also telling me I have
a limited number of checks available

138
00:06:29.940 --> 00:06:32.830
because I'm in the free version.

139
00:06:32.830 --> 00:06:36.190
There is a paid version of the Trusted
Advisor that we can step up to and

140
00:06:36.190 --> 00:06:37.690
if we go to the the paid versions,

141
00:06:37.690 --> 00:06:40.410
you get a lot more in terms
of checks that are available.

142
00:06:40.410 --> 00:06:44.770
And you'll see, were we can monitor
things like recent changes, so

143
00:06:44.770 --> 00:06:48.560
you can match it up with change
tickets in your organization.

144
00:06:48.560 --> 00:06:51.800
You can create excluded items,
you can do five minute refreshes,

145
00:06:51.800 --> 00:06:55.080
versus the automatic refresh
it does in the background.

146
00:06:55.080 --> 00:07:00.270
So there's all sorts of different things
you can configure and setup for it.

147
00:07:00.270 --> 00:07:03.300
And it does cost a little bit of money
based on how many systems you're securing.

148
00:07:03.300 --> 00:07:04.024
So the free one is free.

149
00:07:04.024 --> 00:07:05.840
But then,
if you go to the developer level,

150
00:07:05.840 --> 00:07:07.519
it's $50 a month which is not so bad.

151
00:07:07.519 --> 00:07:10.066
And then it goes up based
on how many systems,

152
00:07:10.066 --> 00:07:12.711
you can get as much as $15,000 a month.

153
00:07:12.711 --> 00:07:18.180
It can actually be a lot, but that one
is doing a huge amount of checks for

154
00:07:18.180 --> 00:07:20.880
security and performance, all right.

155
00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:24.872
>> For $15,000, it should be basically
like you just hired a security expert.

156
00:07:24.872 --> 00:07:25.792
[LAUGH]
>> Well let's talk about how it isn't.

157
00:07:25.792 --> 00:07:27.830
[LAUGH]
>> So here's the problem,

158
00:07:27.830 --> 00:07:31.550
there's certain things the trusted
advisor just can't do.

159
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:33.960
For example,
if I I have a Linux AMI that I've spun up,

160
00:07:33.960 --> 00:07:36.190
which actually I think I have, right?

161
00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:37.800
Don't I have some instances?

162
00:07:37.800 --> 00:07:41.553
So I've spun up some instances, and
it's watching these instances and

163
00:07:41.553 --> 00:07:44.567
telling me, yeah,
they're not at over 80 percent,

164
00:07:44.567 --> 00:07:48.890
or their disk IO is within the tolerances,
you have enough IOPSs available for it.

165
00:07:48.890 --> 00:07:50.910
Well, it'll tell me that, but

166
00:07:50.910 --> 00:07:55.760
will it tell me that I have haven't
done my package updates inside of Linux.

167
00:07:55.760 --> 00:07:57.800
No.
It doesn't see inside of your

168
00:07:57.800 --> 00:07:58.520
operating system.

169
00:07:58.520 --> 00:08:01.280
So the Trust Advisor, even if you pay for
it even if you pay for the big giant full

170
00:08:01.280 --> 00:08:05.890
package, it's not a replacement for
standard security processes.

171
00:08:05.890 --> 00:08:09.310
You still need to be checking for
updates inside of your instances.

172
00:08:09.310 --> 00:08:10.480
It is a limit, right.

173
00:08:10.480 --> 00:08:14.190
There's only so much that the trust
advisor can actually monitor for.

174
00:08:14.190 --> 00:08:16.070
So be you aware that
it's not a magic wand.

175
00:08:16.070 --> 00:08:18.940
It doesn't just solve all your security
problems with a click of a button.

176
00:08:18.940 --> 00:08:22.610
You know, this is when you
still need a security admin.

177
00:08:22.610 --> 00:08:23.920
>> But it's still pretty cool though.

178
00:08:23.920 --> 00:08:26.800
It gives you a nice overview of
what your systems are doing.

179
00:08:26.800 --> 00:08:27.870
Checks for that optimization.

180
00:08:27.870 --> 00:08:29.190
Checks for that best practices.

181
00:08:29.190 --> 00:08:30.338
That's always a good thing.

182
00:08:30.338 --> 00:08:32.322
Now when it comes to practices,

183
00:08:32.322 --> 00:08:36.223
obviously a lot of times there
are compliance issues, right?

184
00:08:36.223 --> 00:08:38.058
You have to be compliant.

185
00:08:38.058 --> 00:08:40.278
Maybe you work in
the health care industry,

186
00:08:40.278 --> 00:08:44.358
maybe you work in the banking industry,
those have a lot of standardizations and

187
00:08:44.358 --> 00:08:48.498
compliances that they have to make sure
that they are following under now Amazon,

188
00:08:48.498 --> 00:08:51.200
they have helped us out with this as well,
right Don?

189
00:08:51.200 --> 00:08:51.967
>> To an extent, yeah.

190
00:08:51.967 --> 00:08:54.526
I like to think that most companies want
there systems to be secure because they

191
00:08:54.526 --> 00:08:55.630
know it's the right thing to do.

192
00:08:55.630 --> 00:08:57.050
But a lot of companies don't.

193
00:08:57.050 --> 00:08:59.610
A lot of companies don't care about it,
right?

194
00:08:59.610 --> 00:09:02.980
They worry about features first and
security second.

195
00:09:02.980 --> 00:09:06.199
And so, in those scenarios oftentimes,
the government will step in and

196
00:09:06.199 --> 00:09:07.640
they'll create a regulation.

197
00:09:07.640 --> 00:09:12.890
They'll create something like HIPAA,
I don't know.

198
00:09:12.890 --> 00:09:13.746
There's some of the ISO
standards that are out there.

199
00:09:13.746 --> 00:09:15.315
They'll create these things and

200
00:09:15.315 --> 00:09:18.520
they'll basically force your
organization to obey them, right?

201
00:09:18.520 --> 00:09:19.370
Hippa compliance.

202
00:09:19.370 --> 00:09:22.730
If you carry medical records, you have
to encrypt them to a certain standards,

203
00:09:22.730 --> 00:09:25.820
all defined as part of HIPAA compliance.

204
00:09:25.820 --> 00:09:30.890
Well, Amazon knows that and Amazon knows
that if you're using their servers,

205
00:09:30.890 --> 00:09:33.564
that they need to be HIPAA compliant,
or or

206
00:09:33.564 --> 00:09:35.947
whatever it is,
they need to follow those same practices.

207
00:09:35.947 --> 00:09:41.070
So they've actually done that for a lot
of it and Amazon has a great web page.

208
00:09:41.070 --> 00:09:46.180
Let me just pull this up here which
is the AWS cloud compliance page.

209
00:09:46.180 --> 00:09:49.720
Now this page shows some of
the different standards that

210
00:09:49.720 --> 00:09:51.490
Amazon already lives up to, PCI.

211
00:09:51.490 --> 00:09:53.500
PCI compliance is the payment
card industry, and

212
00:09:53.500 --> 00:09:56.160
that's a real important one If you
accept credit cards on your website,

213
00:09:56.160 --> 00:10:00.310
you have to be PCI-compliant or
your credit card processors will drop you.

214
00:10:00.310 --> 00:10:01.260
Right?

215
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:05.610
So Amazon's data centers
are PCI-compliant.

216
00:10:05.610 --> 00:10:08.630
Well, you'll notice that they're
SOC-compliant, they're ISO 9001,

217
00:10:08.630 --> 00:10:09.140
MTCS Tier 3.

218
00:10:09.140 --> 00:10:11.470
You'll see a bunch of other ones.

219
00:10:11.470 --> 00:10:14.810
HPAA, FERPA, ITAR, all these great ones,
already done, right?

220
00:10:14.810 --> 00:10:17.250
If I take a look at HIPAA.

221
00:10:17.250 --> 00:10:23.628
They break it down here for me and let me
know that we are HIPAA compliant on AWS.

222
00:10:23.628 --> 00:10:25.630
Sort of, right?

223
00:10:25.630 --> 00:10:27.380
Now, what's the sort of?

224
00:10:27.380 --> 00:10:31.760
Notice this link right here, architecting
for HIPAA security and compliance on AWS.

225
00:10:31.760 --> 00:10:35.955
If Amazon is already HIPAA compliant,
why do I have to architect for it?

226
00:10:35.955 --> 00:10:37.585
Haven't they done it?

227
00:10:37.585 --> 00:10:40.655
Well they have for their stuff,
remember that Amazon for

228
00:10:40.655 --> 00:10:44.565
some services like EC2,
they are infrastructures of service.

229
00:10:44.565 --> 00:10:47.840
They're taking care of the hardware and
on the hardware side.

230
00:10:47.840 --> 00:10:48.860
Yeah they're HIPAA compliant.

231
00:10:48.860 --> 00:10:50.030
They've taken care of it.

232
00:10:50.030 --> 00:10:51.410
Data is being destroyed properly.

233
00:10:51.410 --> 00:10:53.150
Systems are being backed up properly.

234
00:10:53.150 --> 00:10:55.530
They're taking care of that.

235
00:10:55.530 --> 00:10:58.910
But when you create an instance,
you're in charge of the instance.

236
00:10:58.910 --> 00:11:02.360
And you may not be treating it
in a HIPAA compliant manner.

237
00:11:02.360 --> 00:11:03.700
And so now you're not compliant.

238
00:11:03.700 --> 00:11:07.820
And nowhere is that more true than with
PCI, right with the payment card industry.

239
00:11:07.820 --> 00:11:09.910
So if you're accepting credit
cards on your website,

240
00:11:09.910 --> 00:11:14.220
yeah Amazon's got you taken care
on the infrastructure side.

241
00:11:14.220 --> 00:11:18.530
But if you're website is not using SSL,
then you're not PCI compliant and

242
00:11:18.530 --> 00:11:20.440
Amazon's not gonna stop you
because it's your website.

243
00:11:20.440 --> 00:11:22.300
You control it.
You can take credit cards without

244
00:11:22.300 --> 00:11:23.220
SSL if you want.

245
00:11:23.220 --> 00:11:25.280
But you're not PCI compliant anymore.

246
00:11:25.280 --> 00:11:25.820
Right?

247
00:11:25.820 --> 00:11:31.530
So it's not that we can just show
this webpage to our auditor and be

248
00:11:31.530 --> 00:11:35.840
like " this is right here, we're covered,
don't bother me, we're done." But no, and

249
00:11:35.840 --> 00:11:39.200
if you've ever seen a PCI compliance,
audit form, it's 50, 60 pages long.

250
00:11:39.200 --> 00:11:41.680
It takes forever to fill out
even if you know the answers,

251
00:11:41.680 --> 00:11:42.610
it takes forever to fill out.

252
00:11:42.610 --> 00:11:44.730
If you don't know
the answers it takes months,

253
00:11:44.730 --> 00:11:46.820
it's crazy, you don't want to do it.

254
00:11:46.820 --> 00:11:49.670
Well if you're looking at Amazon
to be your crutch for this,

255
00:11:49.670 --> 00:11:50.320
it's not gonna happen.

256
00:11:50.320 --> 00:11:53.150
They are taken care of on their end.

257
00:11:53.150 --> 00:11:54.680
It's up to you to do the rest.

258
00:11:54.680 --> 00:11:55.800
Right?
Your servers, and so on.

259
00:11:55.800 --> 00:11:58.990
So, things like the trust advisor
that I showed you a little earlier?

260
00:11:58.990 --> 00:12:00.960
It doesn't even bother with compliance.

261
00:12:00.960 --> 00:12:03.940
Because Amazon already knows
they're compliant, and

262
00:12:03.940 --> 00:12:05.820
they can't check your systems to do it.

263
00:12:05.820 --> 00:12:08.930
They don't have that visibility inside of
your systems, and so it's left to you.

264
00:12:08.930 --> 00:12:12.470
So be careful, this page is really
tempting to look at and say, I'm covered,

265
00:12:12.470 --> 00:12:15.670
problem solved,
I'll just show that to the auditors,

266
00:12:15.670 --> 00:12:16.950
because they'll just eat you alive.

267
00:12:16.950 --> 00:12:19.970
Your systems may very well
not be in compliance.

268
00:12:19.970 --> 00:12:24.160
But, the nice thing here is that Amazon
does publish some articles on these.

269
00:12:24.160 --> 00:12:27.060
So if I want to become,
let's go with HIPAA,

270
00:12:27.060 --> 00:12:30.630
I can go to this Architecting for
HIPAA Security and Compliance on AWS, and

271
00:12:30.630 --> 00:12:34.950
they've got a whole white paper here that
lists, here's the things that you need

272
00:12:34.950 --> 00:12:37.930
to do for each of these different
services, EC2, Redshift, S3.

273
00:12:37.930 --> 00:12:40.560
How do I encrypt and
protect my data, right?

274
00:12:40.560 --> 00:12:43.090
And then, oops,
clicked on the dad-gum thing.

275
00:12:43.090 --> 00:12:46.840
And then it breaks down other areas that
we can go to improve those systems and

276
00:12:46.840 --> 00:12:49.685
make sure that we are HIPAA
compliant with our own data.

277
00:12:49.685 --> 00:12:51.830
But it is up to us.

278
00:12:51.830 --> 00:12:53.030
How do we do auditing?

279
00:12:53.030 --> 00:12:53.720
How do we do backups?

280
00:12:53.720 --> 00:12:56.320
How do we do disaster recovery,
all laid out, right here.

281
00:12:56.320 --> 00:12:59.410
But you've gotta do it, all right.

282
00:12:59.410 --> 00:13:01.220
Don't discount the Amazon white papers.

283
00:13:01.220 --> 00:13:03.330
I know a lot of companies,
you buy a product,

284
00:13:03.330 --> 00:13:07.580
like here read the white paper,
and you just throw it away.

285
00:13:07.580 --> 00:13:08.440
That's what I do.

286
00:13:08.440 --> 00:13:10.400
But with Amazon, they actually have value.

287
00:13:10.400 --> 00:13:12.320
They're actually bringing this to you and
saying,

288
00:13:12.320 --> 00:13:13.420
here's the steps you need to follow.

289
00:13:13.420 --> 00:13:14.740
It's a really wonderful thing.

290
00:13:14.740 --> 00:13:17.120
>> Yeah, it's never fun to get a white
paper and it's basically saying,

291
00:13:17.120 --> 00:13:19.694
you need to secure your stuff and
good luck with that.

292
00:13:19.694 --> 00:13:20.704
[LAUGH] You throw those away.

293
00:13:20.704 --> 00:13:24.450
Amazon on there actually trying to help
you out, make sure that you are compliant.

294
00:13:24.450 --> 00:13:25.030
Very cool.
And

295
00:13:25.030 --> 00:13:28.810
it is still a good thing that when
you purchase services from Amazon,

296
00:13:28.810 --> 00:13:32.860
you know that whatever you're
purchasing from them, like Don said,

297
00:13:32.860 --> 00:13:35.280
the hardware is under HIPAA compliance.

298
00:13:35.280 --> 00:13:37.400
It's under all those
different compliances.

299
00:13:37.400 --> 00:13:40.660
That you at least have that
portion of compliance under wraps.

300
00:13:40.660 --> 00:13:41.940
You don't have to worry about it.

301
00:13:41.940 --> 00:13:43.310
They have taken a lot off your plate.

302
00:13:43.310 --> 00:13:46.690
Now you just have to deal with
whatever it is your environment is

303
00:13:46.690 --> 00:13:48.390
that you're responsible for.

304
00:13:48.390 --> 00:13:51.260
All right, Don, is there anything
else we need to cover when

305
00:13:51.260 --> 00:13:52.610
it comes to your extra security tools?

306
00:13:52.610 --> 00:13:53.470
>> That's basically it.

307
00:13:53.470 --> 00:13:56.300
I mean, there are a few other ones but
these are the only ones that really show

308
00:13:56.300 --> 00:13:58.100
up on the exam,
the ones that you need to know.

309
00:13:58.100 --> 00:14:00.690
In real life, take advantage of every
tool that's available to you but

310
00:14:00.690 --> 00:14:02.410
I think we've covered.

311
00:14:02.410 --> 00:14:04.040
For what we need to be exam ready.

312
00:14:04.040 --> 00:14:04.600
>> Well, awesome.

313
00:14:04.600 --> 00:14:08.370
Thanks so much for those demonstrations
and explaining how we can use them.

314
00:14:08.370 --> 00:14:09.610
And thank you for watching.

315
00:14:09.610 --> 00:14:11.530
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

316
00:14:11.530 --> 00:14:13.870
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

317
00:14:13.870 --> 00:14:17.240
And I'm Don Pezet.

318
00:14:17.240 --> 00:14:19.222
>> We'll see you next time.

319

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel get into cloud networking with AWS Virtual Private Cloud(VPC). They begin by explaining what VPC is and how it works and then they jump right into creating and configuring a VPC. Once they get the VPC created they then show you how to get it connected to the internet.
episodes.title: Virtual Private Cloud
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.538 --> 00:00:10.538
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.409 --> 00:00:16.549
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.549 --> 00:00:18.433
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:18.433 --> 00:00:22.970
today's episode we're continuing on
the trail of the Amazon Certified, or

5
00:00:22.970 --> 00:00:26.686
the AWS, I'll shorten it down,
AWS Certified SysOps Admin.

6
00:00:26.686 --> 00:00:29.785
And joining us on the studio today well,
it's none other than Don Pezet.

7
00:00:29.785 --> 00:00:32.040
Don, welcome to the show,
how you doing today, sir?

8
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:32.760
>> Doing great, Daniel.

9
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:34.155
Thanks for having me back.

10
00:00:34.155 --> 00:00:39.136
And in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at VPCs, or virtual private clouds,

11
00:00:39.136 --> 00:00:41.570
which are a pretty important part of AWS.

12
00:00:41.570 --> 00:00:43.920
It's one of those things that you
can actually choose to ignore.

13
00:00:43.920 --> 00:00:46.290
There's a default configuration
that does work for some people.

14
00:00:46.290 --> 00:00:48.690
But most of us are gonna find
that we need to get in there and

15
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:50.440
tweak the way that the VPCs work.

16
00:00:50.440 --> 00:00:54.140
And so it's a good idea to understand what
the heck they are in case you don't know.

17
00:00:54.140 --> 00:00:56.910
And then how we can use
them to provide networking

18
00:00:56.910 --> 00:00:59.130
in various scenarios
inside of Amazon Cloud.

19
00:00:59.130 --> 00:01:00.860
So that's what we've got lined up for
today.

20
00:01:00.860 --> 00:01:04.680
>> Now Don, this is obviously, you hit
the big buzz word there, networking.

21
00:01:04.680 --> 00:01:08.770
This is something to do with connecting
different things together over some sort

22
00:01:08.770 --> 00:01:10.970
of network connection.

23
00:01:10.970 --> 00:01:13.409
VPCs obviously does that.

24
00:01:13.409 --> 00:01:15.540
How is it any different than
traditional networking?

25
00:01:15.540 --> 00:01:17.740
It is really where the brass
tacks hits the floor.

26
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:20.138
So, help us out with that.

27
00:01:20.138 --> 00:01:20.821
>> Sure.

28
00:01:20.821 --> 00:01:23.360
So, when you setup an on premises
solution, you have to buy switches.

29
00:01:23.360 --> 00:01:25.540
You have to buy routers,
you have to buy firewalls.

30
00:01:25.540 --> 00:01:30.447
And you get all that setup and
configured and it's all physical hardware.

31
00:01:30.447 --> 00:01:31.318
Right?

32
00:01:31.318 --> 00:01:34.469
With AWS, Amazon has that stuff,
they have firewalls, they have routers,

33
00:01:34.469 --> 00:01:35.840
they have switches.

34
00:01:35.840 --> 00:01:37.910
But you can't see them,
you don't have access to them,

35
00:01:37.910 --> 00:01:39.550
you don't have that kind of control.

36
00:01:39.550 --> 00:01:44.544
So what VPCs are, are basically like
a logical representation of all those

37
00:01:44.544 --> 00:01:46.210
other components.

38
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:50.160
And so when we go to set these things up,
what you're doing when you create a VPC

39
00:01:50.160 --> 00:01:53.170
is, ultimately, if you're a network
engineer, you know about this.

40
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:56.326
You're creating what are called VLANs,
or virtual local area networks.

41
00:01:56.326 --> 00:02:01.230
You're dividing up pieces of
Amazon's network to be private and

42
00:02:01.230 --> 00:02:03.710
isolated just to contain your systems.

43
00:02:03.710 --> 00:02:06.668
So, for example, I might not need that.

44
00:02:06.668 --> 00:02:08.810
I might wanna have five web
servers stored up in AWS, and

45
00:02:08.810 --> 00:02:11.420
I want them all to be publicly
accessible and that's it.

46
00:02:11.420 --> 00:02:15.140
So I just have one network, I put all
those servers in the same network,

47
00:02:15.140 --> 00:02:17.190
I expose them to the internet and
that's it.

48
00:02:17.190 --> 00:02:19.458
But I might wanna have separate networks.

49
00:02:19.458 --> 00:02:23.650
I might wanna have web servers that
are public and exposed to the internet.

50
00:02:23.650 --> 00:02:26.040
And I might wanna have database
servers that are private,

51
00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:28.860
on the back-end that the internet's
not allowed to access.

52
00:02:28.860 --> 00:02:30.362
Right?
Maybe for security reasons,

53
00:02:30.362 --> 00:02:34.046
you don't want people on the outside
having direct access to your database

54
00:02:34.046 --> 00:02:34.581
servers.

55
00:02:34.581 --> 00:02:38.370
So, on a physical network, I would use
separate switches, use separate routers.

56
00:02:38.370 --> 00:02:41.290
You'll put them on a separate network and
that would take care of it.

57
00:02:41.290 --> 00:02:45.460
In Amazon Cloud we can use VPCs, we can
create a virtual private cloud just for

58
00:02:45.460 --> 00:02:49.700
our database servers, and a virtual
private cloud just for our web servers.

59
00:02:49.700 --> 00:02:54.740
Or, you can create one virtual
private cloud and divide it up.

60
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:57.220
So I might have a virtual private
cloud that lines up with my web app.

61
00:02:57.220 --> 00:03:00.230
I have a web application and
this is its cloud.

62
00:03:00.230 --> 00:03:04.670
And then inside of that cloud,
I create separate subnets, one for

63
00:03:04.670 --> 00:03:07.930
each of the different service levels or
service types that I have.

64
00:03:07.930 --> 00:03:10.780
So I might have database servers,
web servers, app servers, whatever, and

65
00:03:10.780 --> 00:03:12.570
they're all kind of divided
up on their subnets.

66
00:03:12.570 --> 00:03:14.670
You get a lot of control,
a lot of flexibility.

67
00:03:14.670 --> 00:03:17.900
Now there's different times where you
use different parts of the solution, so

68
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:20.100
I'll point that out as the show goes on.

69
00:03:20.100 --> 00:03:24.660
But, one key thing we need to remember
is that when you create a VPC,

70
00:03:24.660 --> 00:03:26.470
a VPC is tied to a region.

71
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:30.530
So if I create a virtual private
cloud in the US East region,

72
00:03:30.530 --> 00:03:33.240
in Virginia, that's where it resides.

73
00:03:33.240 --> 00:03:36.980
It doesn't reside in US West,
or in Europe West, or wherever.

74
00:03:36.980 --> 00:03:40.570
If the US East data center goes down,
my VPC goes down.

75
00:03:40.570 --> 00:03:43.360
So the odds are you're going to
need more than one VPC to be

76
00:03:43.360 --> 00:03:45.960
able to cover the different
regions that are out there.

77
00:03:45.960 --> 00:03:49.336
And then within a region,
you have availability zones.

78
00:03:49.336 --> 00:03:51.645
Right?
