00:25:31.480 --> 00:25:33.760
And so that means they're
not taking advantage of it.

534
00:25:33.760 --> 00:25:38.830
So as that stands right now, each of
these subnets are actually isolated.

535
00:25:38.830 --> 00:25:42.500
They could try and communicate but their
not properly attached, so there's a little

536
00:25:42.500 --> 00:25:45.130
bit more leg work we have to do to
get this kind of straightened out.

537
00:25:45.130 --> 00:25:50.420
And so one of the next things that I would
do is go in and attach these subnets

538
00:25:50.420 --> 00:25:53.160
to this routing table unless I wanted
them all to have separate routing tables.

539
00:25:53.160 --> 00:25:56.580
There are times where you might want to
have one subnet that gets a specifically

540
00:25:56.580 --> 00:25:59.860
different set of routes than the others
and so you could go through and do that.

541
00:25:59.860 --> 00:26:07.420
But I'm just going to associate all of
my subnets with this one routing table.

542
00:26:07.420 --> 00:26:10.280
Now once that's done,
I can start to determine

543
00:26:10.280 --> 00:26:13.040
things like whether I want them to
have internet access or not, and

544
00:26:13.040 --> 00:26:15.470
in fact, I might have different
behaviors that I want.

545
00:26:15.470 --> 00:26:20.380
So for example,
I had this one routing table but honestly,

546
00:26:20.380 --> 00:26:24.060
I might not want my database servers to
be able to get out to the internet and

547
00:26:24.060 --> 00:26:26.220
I might want my web servers to
be able to get to the internet.

548
00:26:26.220 --> 00:26:30.020
So that would be a scenario where I
need different route associations and so

549
00:26:30.020 --> 00:26:31.600
let me take the database servers back out.

550
00:26:31.600 --> 00:26:32.589
And it's easy enough, right?

551
00:26:32.589 --> 00:26:36.100
You just go in and
uncheck them, save that.

552
00:26:36.100 --> 00:26:37.200
It's now it's gonna take it back out,

553
00:26:37.200 --> 00:26:38.910
I might want that to have
it's own routing table and

554
00:26:38.910 --> 00:26:40.480
we'll see as we start to
create some gateways.

555
00:26:41.720 --> 00:26:45.050
So basically at this point,
I've created them.

556
00:26:45.050 --> 00:26:46.660
They're up and they're going.

557
00:26:46.660 --> 00:26:48.910
I stuck my web apps here
into the routing table.

558
00:26:48.910 --> 00:26:52.210
They're able to see each other now,
but that's about it.

559
00:26:52.210 --> 00:26:53.270
There's not much else.

560
00:26:53.270 --> 00:26:54.940
See, we know that one network is local,

561
00:26:54.940 --> 00:26:58.180
but we don't necessarily know
about how to get to the Internet.

562
00:26:58.180 --> 00:27:03.100
So if I want Internet connectivity,
the last piece that I need is a gateway.

563
00:27:03.100 --> 00:27:05.570
I've gotta give it a gateway so
it knows how to get out to the internet.

564
00:27:05.570 --> 00:27:08.754
So if I go over here to my internet
gateways, I've got the default one for

565
00:27:08.754 --> 00:27:09.380
my default VPC.

566
00:27:09.380 --> 00:27:10.590
But this is an all new VPC.

567
00:27:10.590 --> 00:27:13.900
So I'm gonna create a new gateway and
I'll give it a name.

568
00:27:13.900 --> 00:27:17.851
And I'll just call this
like webapp1-web-gw.

569
00:27:17.851 --> 00:27:18.889
So this is gonna be my gateway.

570
00:27:19.980 --> 00:27:23.660
And when I create it, what it's
basically doing is making a router.

571
00:27:23.660 --> 00:27:26.719
So this is a router that is spinning up,

572
00:27:26.719 --> 00:27:30.816
that's going to allow
traffic on my 172.16.

573
00:27:30.816 --> 00:27:33.356
I think it was .0 is the network
I used for the web servers.

574
00:27:33.356 --> 00:27:36.170
It's going to allow them
to get out to the internet.

575
00:27:36.170 --> 00:27:37.860
Right.
And if they get assigned to public IP,

576
00:27:37.860 --> 00:27:39.330
then they're gonna go out with that.

577
00:27:39.330 --> 00:27:43.260
So, [COUGH] basically I just need
to take this one and attach it.

578
00:27:43.260 --> 00:27:46.550
Now see when I added it,
it came up as detached, right.

579
00:27:46.550 --> 00:27:48.320
I'm not quite sure why Amazon doesn't ask

580
00:27:48.320 --> 00:27:49.920
you to attach it during the wizard,
but they don't.

581
00:27:49.920 --> 00:27:52.913
So they create it and
then you've got to attach it to a VPC.

582
00:27:52.913 --> 00:27:56.460
So I'm gonna go ahead and
do that and I'll pick my web app.

583
00:27:56.460 --> 00:27:58.510
And see how I can't pick the default one?

584
00:27:58.510 --> 00:28:01.490
You can only have one gateway per VPC.

585
00:28:01.490 --> 00:28:05.460
My default VPC already has a gateway so
it's not on the list.

586
00:28:05.460 --> 00:28:06.380
Webapp1 is the only one.

587
00:28:06.380 --> 00:28:07.090
Right.

588
00:28:07.090 --> 00:28:08.170
I'm gonna go ahead and

589
00:28:08.170 --> 00:28:13.500
attach that and now, I've got
a router attached to that network.

590
00:28:13.500 --> 00:28:16.740
And if I adjust this a little bit,
there it is, so

591
00:28:16.740 --> 00:28:22.311
here's this webapp1 web gateway and it's
attached to the 172.16.0.0/16 network.

592
00:28:23.570 --> 00:28:25.790
And now if I want people
to have internet access,

593
00:28:25.790 --> 00:28:29.760
all I've got to do is set up a default
route, for them to go through this

594
00:28:29.760 --> 00:28:32.390
router on the way out to the internet,
and that's gonna give them that access.

595
00:28:32.390 --> 00:28:37.440
So I'm gonna go back to my routing table,
and in the routing table I'm gonna take

596
00:28:37.440 --> 00:28:42.750
that routing table for our web app VPC,
and I'm gonna go down here to Routes and

597
00:28:42.750 --> 00:28:45.980
I'm gonna edit it, and I need to put
in what's called the default route.

598
00:28:45.980 --> 00:28:49.060
And what a default route is is it says
if you want to get to a network that's

599
00:28:49.060 --> 00:28:52.090
not in this list, who do you go to?

600
00:28:52.090 --> 00:28:55.630
There are tens of thousands of
networks out there on the internet.

601
00:28:55.630 --> 00:28:58.310
I'm not gonna enter everyone of them
in here and tell it how to get there.

602
00:28:58.310 --> 00:29:02.221
So I need a catch all route that says
anything that's not in this list,

603
00:29:02.221 --> 00:29:03.970
send to that router.

604
00:29:03.970 --> 00:29:08.975
So when I choose to add another route,
the catch-all network, is all zeros.

605
00:29:08.975 --> 00:29:12.555
0.0.0.0/0, all right.

606
00:29:12.555 --> 00:29:15.580
It's kinda weird to write that but
that's a catch-all.

607
00:29:15.580 --> 00:29:20.370
That means every other network
that's not in this list.

608
00:29:20.370 --> 00:29:23.600
And then where I wanna send it,
notice the moment I click on it,

609
00:29:23.600 --> 00:29:25.510
it starts listing my gateways.

610
00:29:25.510 --> 00:29:27.270
And you're only gonna
have one gateway here, so

611
00:29:27.270 --> 00:29:30.610
you'll just choose that one,
that's the gateway that we just created.

612
00:29:30.610 --> 00:29:36.180
And I can save that, and now the VPCs
will be able to see each other,

613
00:29:36.180 --> 00:29:38.870
well, the VPCs that I attached
to this routing table.

614
00:29:38.870 --> 00:29:42.778
So my two web subnets that I made.

615
00:29:42.778 --> 00:29:45.420
Those subnets will be able
to see each other, and,

616
00:29:45.420 --> 00:29:49.420
they'll be able to hit this gateway and
get out to the internet.

617
00:29:49.420 --> 00:29:53.300
And as long as they have a public IP
attached to them, they're gonna be able to

618
00:29:53.300 --> 00:29:56.260
get out to the internet and people in
the internet will be able to get to them,

619
00:29:56.260 --> 00:29:58.820
assuming they haven't blocked it
with security groups and so on.

620
00:29:58.820 --> 00:30:02.350
But they're now internet enabled and
ready to rock.

621
00:30:02.350 --> 00:30:02.900
>> Awesome Don.

622
00:30:02.900 --> 00:30:05.090
Obviously the stars have
all aligned finally,

623
00:30:05.090 --> 00:30:07.830
we're able to get to the internet,
something that most people.

624
00:30:07.830 --> 00:30:10.170
That's exactly what they're looking for
but

625
00:30:10.170 --> 00:30:12.910
I got a feeling there's
a whole lot more to this.

626
00:30:12.910 --> 00:30:16.880
We have just scratched the surface on
the networking inside these VPCs, but

627
00:30:16.880 --> 00:30:21.850
looking at our clock, we are well out of
time and I know you got plenty more to

628
00:30:21.850 --> 00:30:25.500
talk about so,
looks like a part two is in store for us.

629
00:30:25.500 --> 00:30:27.800
>> I think so, you know,
we've given these people internet access.

630
00:30:27.800 --> 00:30:30.350
But there's other types of internet
access we might want to do,

631
00:30:30.350 --> 00:30:31.120
we need to see that and

632
00:30:31.120 --> 00:30:33.710
there's a few other things that show up on
the exam that I definitely want to cover.

633
00:30:33.710 --> 00:30:35.290
So let's break that up
into another episode.

634
00:30:35.290 --> 00:30:37.190
>> Yes definitely, so
I look forward to part two.

635
00:30:37.190 --> 00:30:38.500
Hopefully you do as well.

636
00:30:38.500 --> 00:30:40.960
As for this episode,
signing off for ITProTv.

637
00:30:40.960 --> 00:30:42.760
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

638
00:30:42.760 --> 00:30:43.390
>> And I'm Don Pizette.

639
00:30:43.390 --> 00:30:45.014
>> And we'll see you next time

640
00:30:45.014 --> 00:30:51.680
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel pick right back up with Virtual Private Clouds; specifically getting them internet connectivity. Then they explain how employ NAT to allow internet access while blocking outside exposure. They also show you other security measures like using network ACLs. Finally they touch upon AWS Direct Connect which allows you to connect on-premises networks to a VPC.
episodes.title: Virtual Private Cloud Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.945 --> 00:00:10.945
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.170 --> 00:00:17.350
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.350 --> 00:00:18.620
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.620 --> 00:00:23.310
And in today's episode we're continuing
on at AWS Certified SysOps Admin.

5
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:23.980
And joining me yet

6
00:00:23.980 --> 00:00:27.790
again one more time today is none other
than my good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:27.790 --> 00:00:28.700
Don, welcome to the show.

8
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:29.580
Or welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:29.580 --> 00:00:31.620
>> Welcome back, thanks for
having me, Daniel.

10
00:00:31.620 --> 00:00:35.030
You know, we're gonna pick back up
with virtual private clouds and

11
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:36.210
working with them, getting them created.

12
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:39.060
We kinda left off hopefully,
you watched the first part or

13
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:41.350
otherwise you will be confused while
we're starting up in the middle.

14
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:45.350
But we had created some subnets
that were tied to some AZ's.

15
00:00:45.350 --> 00:00:49.620
They were inside one VPC, I'm gonna
use as many acronyms as I can here.

16
00:00:49.620 --> 00:00:51.550
And so, we had that VPC set up.

17
00:00:51.550 --> 00:00:52.830
We created some web server.

18
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:55.810
We created some database server subnets.

19
00:00:55.810 --> 00:00:57.370
And kind of got those put into place.

20
00:00:57.370 --> 00:01:01.894
And the last thing that we did is
we took an internet gateway and

21
00:01:01.894 --> 00:01:06.337
attached it to the subnets that
were part of our web servers.

22
00:01:06.337 --> 00:01:09.920
Now once we did that, technically
those subnets have internet access.

23
00:01:09.920 --> 00:01:13.230
But I actually left out one step
that was kind of important.

24
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:15.380
I didn't notice it until during the break.

25
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:17.960
In between the show I went ahead and
spun up a few instances,

26
00:01:17.960 --> 00:01:19.950
just a few servers to chuck them in there.

27
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:21.780
And I noticed what I forgot real quick.

28
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:22.940
So let me show you.

29
00:01:22.940 --> 00:01:27.058
So here on my console,
if I go down to VPCs.

30
00:01:27.058 --> 00:01:30.743
What we did is we went into
our internet gateways and

31
00:01:30.743 --> 00:01:36.069
I added this internet gateway right here,
webapp1-web-gw, right.

32
00:01:36.069 --> 00:01:37.636
That was the gateway.

33
00:01:37.636 --> 00:01:41.670
And I attached it to my subnets
that actually had that.

34
00:01:41.670 --> 00:01:43.009
So if I go to my routing tables.

35
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:46.445
And I look, I've got a routing table here.

36
00:01:46.445 --> 00:01:51.540
It's tied at the webapp1-vpc and
in that routing table,

37
00:01:51.540 --> 00:01:55.010
if I go down to my routes, there's
the route that includes that gateway.

38
00:01:55.010 --> 00:01:57.310
So I've got this local
network of 172.16.0.0/16 and

39
00:01:57.310 --> 00:02:01.620
now I've got the default route for
the gateway.

40
00:02:01.620 --> 00:02:04.010
That was how we ended
the episode right there.

41
00:02:04.010 --> 00:02:06.520
Well, during the break I jumped up here.

42
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:08.990
And I went to my instances.

43
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:11.520
And I started firing up
some virtual machines.

44
00:02:11.520 --> 00:02:15.640
I fired up one web server in each
of the two web server subnets.

45
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:18.670
And I fired up one database server and
stuck it back in the database one.

46
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:22.407
So notice how I've got a database and
a web server in us-east-1a.

47
00:02:22.407 --> 00:02:23.499
And I've got one in us-east-1d, right?

48
00:02:23.499 --> 00:02:27.590
Those are the three subnets that we made,
the three availability zones we covered.

49
00:02:27.590 --> 00:02:32.999
Now, if I scroll over,
I can see that they're healthy and

50
00:02:32.999 --> 00:02:35.140
if I just kinda look at all their data,

51
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:40.770
you'll notice this nice big gap right
here under public DNS and public IP.

52
00:02:40.770 --> 00:02:41.880
Right.

53
00:02:41.880 --> 00:02:47.320
When you create a VPC,
the default is that it is private.

54
00:02:47.320 --> 00:02:52.080
It's a virtual private cloud,
it's local addresses only and that's it.

55
00:02:52.080 --> 00:02:55.368
And what that means is that it's not gonna
be able to talk to the internet because

56
00:02:55.368 --> 00:02:56.596
it's got fake IP addresses,

57
00:02:56.596 --> 00:02:59.317
it's got internal IP addresses
that are not internet routable.

58
00:02:59.317 --> 00:03:03.413
So when I added that gateway, that
connected my machines to the internet but

59
00:03:03.413 --> 00:03:07.509
they're not gonna be able to get out
to the internet because they don't have

60
00:03:07.509 --> 00:03:08.099
a real IP.

61
00:03:08.099 --> 00:03:12.090
They've got a 172.16 address, and any
internet routers instructed to drop those.

62
00:03:12.090 --> 00:03:15.760
Those are private IPs, you have to
translate over to a public one.

63
00:03:15.760 --> 00:03:18.030
There's two ways I can get around this.

64
00:03:18.030 --> 00:03:21.009
If I want these VPCs
to be internet facing.

65
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:25.460
Then I just need to assign public IPs to
match up with those internal systems.

66
00:03:25.460 --> 00:03:27.690
If they're web servers,
you want them to have public IPs and

67
00:03:27.690 --> 00:03:29.240
I need to do that, right?

68
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:34.170
Now what I should have done was
back when I set up those subnets,

69
00:03:34.170 --> 00:03:36.920
I should have told it to assign
public IPs and I didn't.

70
00:03:36.920 --> 00:03:38.480
If I go back here to my VPCs.

71
00:03:40.920 --> 00:03:42.320
When we jump into the VPC and

72
00:03:42.320 --> 00:03:46.830
we take a look at like the webapp1-vpc,
this guy right here, and

73
00:03:46.830 --> 00:03:50.870
you look at its various options,
all it asked me for was a CIDR block.

74
00:03:50.870 --> 00:03:52.730
And that was it,
I assigned it a CIDR block.

75
00:03:52.730 --> 00:03:55.660
It never mentioned
anything about public IPs.

76
00:03:55.660 --> 00:04:01.200
And that's because we can then go subnet
by subnet and customize the public IPs.

77
00:04:01.200 --> 00:04:06.230
And so if I jump over to my subnets,
and I take web1d, for example,

78
00:04:06.230 --> 00:04:11.860
notice in web1d, there's this option right
down here, Auto-assign Public IP, no.

79
00:04:11.860 --> 00:04:14.150
So they're not gonna get public IPs,
and for

80
00:04:14.150 --> 00:04:16.030
my database servers, that's what I want.

81
00:04:16.030 --> 00:04:18.810
I don't want them to have
public IPS because then

82
00:04:18.810 --> 00:04:21.620
somebody on the internet could try and
access the database server directly.

83
00:04:21.620 --> 00:04:23.390
I have to make sure I
put security groups in.

84
00:04:23.390 --> 00:04:26.650
But if I just have internal IPs,
nobody on the internet can access it,

85
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:29.670
cuz it's not a routable IP, right?

86
00:04:29.670 --> 00:04:31.770
Or not an internet routable IP.

87
00:04:31.770 --> 00:04:35.940
So, I need to change my subnets for
my web servers to auto-assign public IPs.

88
00:04:35.940 --> 00:04:38.890
So, I'm just gonna take these guys.

89
00:04:38.890 --> 00:04:43.127
And if we dig into their settings,
you'll see where you can modify

90
00:04:43.127 --> 00:04:47.531
the auto-assign public IP option
right here under subnet actions.

91
00:04:47.531 --> 00:04:51.700
I'm just gonna turn that on, and
I'll do that for both them, right?

92
00:04:51.700 --> 00:04:57.395
So I just did it for web1d, now I'll
do it for web1a, and I'll turn that on.

93
00:04:57.395 --> 00:04:59.120
Now, usually I'm much better
about remembering this.

94
00:04:59.120 --> 00:05:02.330
So, I actually don't know if that's gonna
apply to my existing instances or not.

95
00:05:02.330 --> 00:05:03.630
So, I'll have to double check, but

96
00:05:03.630 --> 00:05:07.110
I can see right down here that auto
assign public IP is now set to yes.

97
00:05:07.110 --> 00:05:09.870
And if I jump over to my instances.

98
00:05:09.870 --> 00:05:11.080
Let's see if it did it for me.

99
00:05:12.150 --> 00:05:15.160
We'll find out real quick and I didn't.

100
00:05:15.160 --> 00:05:15.830
Shoot.

101
00:05:15.830 --> 00:05:19.850
All right, so as I started spinning up
new ones they'll get those public IPs but

102
00:05:19.850 --> 00:05:22.110
since these guys were already here,
they don't have it so

103
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:25.110
I'm gonna have to edit those and
kinda reassign it.

104
00:05:25.110 --> 00:05:28.900
So when you go into like your instance
settings, you'll see we got all sorts of

105
00:05:28.900 --> 00:05:31.770
different stuff that you can mess with
under networking, here's where you can

106
00:05:31.770 --> 00:05:35.520
manage your private IP address and you
can attach network interfaces and so on.

107
00:05:36.570 --> 00:05:39.060
But, they don't actually have a public IP.

108
00:05:39.060 --> 00:05:40.660
So there is a few ways I can resolve this,

109
00:05:40.660 --> 00:05:45.080
I could spit up new instances, or
I could just do some elastic IPs and

110
00:05:45.080 --> 00:05:48.590
attach them, which works also, and
then they would have those public IPs.

111
00:05:48.590 --> 00:05:50.770
But that's one step that
I kind of left out,

You don't have to bill to to all of them,

552
00:28:31.750 --> 00:28:35.140
you can pick particular VPCs to connect
and now you'll be able to communicate.

553
00:28:35.140 --> 00:28:37.790
And those network ACLs become
kind of important there too.

554
00:28:37.790 --> 00:28:40.720
If you wanna set that up
here in your VPC dashboard.

555
00:28:40.720 --> 00:28:44.290
If you just scroll down you'll see
VPN connections, right down here, and

556
00:28:44.290 --> 00:28:48.180
what you have to do is, first you
have to set up a customer gateway.

557
00:28:48.180 --> 00:28:50.630
And a customer gateway
is usually a firewall or

558
00:28:50.630 --> 00:28:52.270
a router that's at your location.

559
00:28:52.270 --> 00:28:54.900
And so you define it right here,
what is your router and

560
00:28:54.900 --> 00:28:57.850
firewall in its basically
it's configuration.

561
00:28:57.850 --> 00:28:58.960
Okay?

562
00:28:58.960 --> 00:29:02.230
To get this all to work you have to
have border gateway protocol, or BGP.

563
00:29:02.230 --> 00:29:04.960
And BGP uses these autonomous
system numbers, or ASN's.

564
00:29:04.960 --> 00:29:08.090
And so you have to define what autonomous
system number you're going to use at your

565
00:29:08.090 --> 00:29:10.320
office versus up here in the Cloud.

566
00:29:10.320 --> 00:29:12.870
And so
once you define that router as connected.

567
00:29:12.870 --> 00:29:15.700
And then you tell it the networks
that you want to be a part of that.

568
00:29:15.700 --> 00:29:18.100
And so you go down here to
virtual Private Gateways,

569
00:29:18.100 --> 00:29:21.150
then you actually start to define the VPCs

570
00:29:21.150 --> 00:29:24.520
that are gonna be tied to this to
allow the communications between it.

571
00:29:24.520 --> 00:29:27.940
And so those are kind of the VPN
connections that we can build.

572
00:29:27.940 --> 00:29:30.510
And once the VPN is up,

573
00:29:30.510 --> 00:29:35.680
now you're able to flow traffic between
your on-premises side and Amazon, right.

574
00:29:35.680 --> 00:29:39.750
There is one other service that's
very very similar to this.

575
00:29:39.750 --> 00:29:41.630
So these were VPN's.

576
00:29:41.630 --> 00:29:45.730
The problem with VPN's is that they're not
really efficient as far as moving a lot

577
00:29:45.730 --> 00:29:46.540
of traffic.

578
00:29:46.540 --> 00:29:50.870
Bandwidth wise, you're having to encrypt
and decrypt and you're subject to Amazon's

579
00:29:50.870 --> 00:29:55.740
incoming bandwidth rules, which Incoming
bandwidth is free, but that means

580
00:29:55.740 --> 00:29:59.240
it's slower, and so you don't necessarily
get the greatest bandwidth out of it.

581
00:29:59.240 --> 00:30:01.610
And VPN tunnels usually
rebuild every 24 hours.

582
00:30:01.610 --> 00:30:04.510
There's these little micro outages
that happen with VPN tunnels that

583
00:30:04.510 --> 00:30:05.570
are kind of annoying.

584
00:30:05.570 --> 00:30:07.190
It's just how the protocols work.

585
00:30:08.280 --> 00:30:12.140
If you wanna get away from that, if you
want a super stable connection that's

586
00:30:12.140 --> 00:30:14.660
always up that has very high bandwidth,

587
00:30:14.660 --> 00:30:18.840
there's another service that may show up
on this service called direct connect.

588
00:30:18.840 --> 00:30:20.920
If I go back to my AWS dashboard,

589
00:30:20.920 --> 00:30:24.010
here's my VPCs and
right beneath it I've got direct connect.

590
00:30:24.010 --> 00:30:27.930
And inside direct connect you
can create a connection and

591
00:30:27.930 --> 00:30:30.060
to reconnect is very similar.

592
00:30:30.060 --> 00:30:32.860
You have a private connection that runs
between your own premises equipment

593
00:30:32.860 --> 00:30:34.090
and Amazon.

594
00:30:34.090 --> 00:30:35.450
And you can float traffic over it.

595
00:30:35.450 --> 00:30:37.710
Sounds just like the VPNs, right?

596
00:30:37.710 --> 00:30:40.740
The difference here,
it's actually a physical connection.

597
00:30:40.740 --> 00:30:44.790
You can get an MPLS line or
a point-to-point T1 or

598
00:30:44.790 --> 00:30:48.240
some kind of actual physical line,
a Metro Ethernet line.

599
00:30:48.240 --> 00:30:51.910
That's a point to point line
between you and Amazon.

600
00:30:51.910 --> 00:30:55.020
And so that means you gotta pay for
the line on both ends.

601
00:30:55.020 --> 00:30:56.180
You've gotta get this physically set up.

602
00:30:56.180 --> 00:30:58.620
This isn't something in software where I
can click some check boxes and turn on.

603
00:30:58.620 --> 00:31:02.020
I've actually got a order service and
pay a monthly bill and all that.

604
00:31:02.020 --> 00:31:04.380
But at the end of the day its a permanent,

605
00:31:04.380 --> 00:31:07.100
always on connection
with dedicated bandwidth.

606
00:31:07.100 --> 00:31:09.964
And so if I go here and
create a new connection,

607
00:31:09.964 --> 00:31:12.251
I can tell it who I'm connecting to.

608
00:31:12.251 --> 00:31:16.233
And you'll see Equinix, that's the company
that kinda manages for Amazon.

609
00:31:16.233 --> 00:31:19.423
And they've got connections in Ashburn,
Virginia,

610
00:31:19.423 --> 00:31:23.320
for US East and Dallas, Texas, for
one of the other data centers.

611
00:31:23.320 --> 00:31:24.720
I can't remember what they call that one.

612
00:31:24.720 --> 00:31:26.660
And then you've got this
one over here in New York.

613
00:31:26.660 --> 00:31:29.730
Notice they don't have connections
in US West or Europe or whatever.

614
00:31:29.730 --> 00:31:32.670
Well, that's partly influenced because
I've got north Virginia chosen up here

615
00:31:32.670 --> 00:31:35.900
as my Out of my region,
if I flip that all start to change.

616
00:31:35.900 --> 00:31:40.250
But you have to basically buy a physical
connection that runs from your office to

617
00:31:40.250 --> 00:31:41.840
one of these locations.

618
00:31:41.840 --> 00:31:44.648
And then you specify the Port Speed,
and they offered gigabyte or

619
00:31:44.648 --> 00:31:45.884
ten gigabyte connections.

620
00:31:45.884 --> 00:31:49.421
And you, if you buy the gigabyte
connection you know how to dedicated link

621
00:31:49.421 --> 00:31:51.317
to Amazon that bypasses the internet.

622
00:31:51.317 --> 00:31:55.160
That's the point to point link that you
don't pay bandwidth on because you're

623
00:31:55.160 --> 00:31:56.200
paying for the line.

624
00:31:56.200 --> 00:31:58.470
And you get dedicated
access right up there.

625
00:31:58.470 --> 00:32:02.391
So if you need a permanent connection for
your on premises equipment to AWS,

626
00:32:02.391 --> 00:32:03.810
this is a great way to do it.

627
00:32:03.810 --> 00:32:05.260
But there's a lot more work.

628
00:32:05.260 --> 00:32:07.750
I mean you can click Create.

629
00:32:07.750 --> 00:32:11.350
If I hit that button what it actually does
is it creates a support ticket to Amazon.

630
00:32:11.350 --> 00:32:14.120
And then they say hey,
we think you might have chosen this by

631
00:32:14.120 --> 00:32:16.930
accident because 99% of the people
don't actually understand what it is.

632
00:32:16.930 --> 00:32:19.450
And then they say, if you really
wanna do this let us know and

633
00:32:19.450 --> 00:32:23.070
let's start a service order and you
actually go through and do that process.

634
00:32:23.070 --> 00:32:26.170
But once you've got it then
you'll have a connection,

635
00:32:26.170 --> 00:32:28.990
like I have one here that's
just kinda pending right now.

636
00:32:28.990 --> 00:32:31.480
You'll have this connection
that runs up and

637
00:32:31.480 --> 00:32:33.930
you gotta go and
order a physical line and attach it.

638
00:32:33.930 --> 00:32:37.020
And once it's there you'll
have virtual interfaces.

639
00:32:37.020 --> 00:32:40.310
And you can take those virtual interfaces
and attach them to each of your subnets.

640
00:32:40.310 --> 00:32:44.590
Now, these virtual interfaces
are 802.1Q VLAN tagged instances, and

641
00:32:44.590 --> 00:32:49.240
that means you could have more than
one VLAN on your local network

642
00:32:49.240 --> 00:32:52.490
tied to different subnets
up in your VPCs in Amazon.

643
00:32:52.490 --> 00:32:55.610
So, you can have several
different segregated networks all

644
00:32:55.610 --> 00:32:56.430
crossing this one line.

645
00:32:56.430 --> 00:32:59.440
It's really neat stuff but
it's really involved.

646
00:32:59.440 --> 00:33:03.700
For the exam, you just need to know
that if bandwidth is a concern,

647
00:33:03.700 --> 00:33:07.510
if you need a permanent high bandwidth
reliable connection to Amazon,

648
00:33:07.510 --> 00:33:09.040
DirectConnect's the way to go.

649
00:33:09.040 --> 00:33:11.750
But if you just need a straight up
connection for management purposes or

650
00:33:11.750 --> 00:33:13.040
transferring little bits of data,

651
00:33:13.040 --> 00:33:17.300
something that's not 100% reliable, the
VPN technology is far easier to implement,

652
00:33:17.300 --> 00:33:19.830
far less expensive, and
easy to get deployed and in place.

653
00:33:19.830 --> 00:33:24.060
So those are the two ways that we
can connect on premises into a VPC.

654
00:33:24.060 --> 00:33:25.740
>> Very impressive Don.

655
00:33:25.740 --> 00:33:27.550
I was unaware completely that,

656
00:33:27.550 --> 00:33:30.080
that's basically a traditional leased
line that connects to the cloud right?

657
00:33:30.080 --> 00:33:30.800
>> That's exactly it, yeah.

658
00:33:30.800 --> 00:33:32.500
>> Awesome, that's awesome stuff.

659
00:33:32.500 --> 00:33:36.390
So now if you are one of those people
that, I'm used to using these type of WAN

660
00:33:36.390 --> 00:33:40.760
technologies, well, you can continue
doing that and use the cloud as well.

661
00:33:40.760 --> 00:33:41.820
That's very awesome.

662
00:33:41.820 --> 00:33:45.000
Don, any parting words of wisdom
that you have for our viewers?

663
00:33:45.000 --> 00:33:46.190
>> I think that's about it.

664
00:33:46.190 --> 00:33:47.460
Run through the process.

665
00:33:47.460 --> 00:33:50.430
In the show note I'll put a link to
a Amazon article where they do the step

666
00:33:50.430 --> 00:33:54.050
by step exactly how to set up those
NAT instances, it's kinda daunting.

667
00:33:54.050 --> 00:33:56.640
For the exam, they're not gonna ask
you to set up an add instance, but

668
00:33:56.640 --> 00:33:59.680
what they are gonna do is ask you some
basic troubleshooting questions, and

669
00:33:59.680 --> 00:34:01.810
it always boils down to skipping a step.

670
00:34:01.810 --> 00:34:04.470
So you wanna run through that
process a few times, get used to it,

671
00:34:04.470 --> 00:34:07.610
get comfortable with it so you can
recognize when a step has been missed.

672
00:34:07.610 --> 00:34:09.540
It happens.
I missed a step when I was setting it up.

673
00:34:09.540 --> 00:34:12.310
I didn't have public IPs on my web
servers, so they couldn't get out.

674
00:34:12.310 --> 00:34:13.716
Well, I guess that wasn't NAT, that was-
>> Still.

675
00:34:13.716 --> 00:34:14.970
[LAUGH]
>> Well, whatever, whatever.

676
00:34:14.970 --> 00:34:16.610
So it's easy to forget things, right.

677
00:34:16.610 --> 00:34:19.250
So we wanna make sure that we have that,
that we're comfortable with it, and

678
00:34:19.250 --> 00:34:19.880
just run through it.

679
00:34:19.880 --> 00:34:24.020
But at the end of the day, VPCs are very
powerful, they're not that hard to get set

680
00:34:24.020 --> 00:34:29.000
up, and thanks to the new NAT gateway that
Amazon rolled out literally yesterday,

681
00:34:29.000 --> 00:34:32.780
the net stuff is just two clicks away,
but for the exam, know the full process.

682
00:34:32.780 --> 00:34:35.830
>> All right, Don, well thanks for
joining us today, and those explanations.

683
00:34:35.830 --> 00:34:37.200
Thank you guys for watching.

684
00:34:37.200 --> 00:34:38.242
We're going to go ahead and sign off.

685
00:34:38.242 --> 00:34:40.900
For ITProTV I've been your Daniel Lowery.

686
00:34:40.900 --> 00:34:41.590
>> And I'm Donald Pizette.

687
00:34:41.590 --> 00:34:42.780
>> And we'll see you next time.

688
00:34:42.780 --> 00:34:49.380
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at disk storage in EC2. They start off by describing Volume types, those being the Root volume and then any additional volumes. Then they look at Storage types in AWS; these being Instance Store, also known as Ephemeral storage, and Elastic Block Storage(EBS). They then move on to EC2 Storage Media which can be standard magnetic storage, General Purpose SSD, or Provisioned IOPS SSD and their attributes.
episodes.title: EC2 Disk Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.747 --> 00:00:16.413
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTv.

3
00:00:16.413 --> 00:00:18.070
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.070 --> 00:00:22.210
in today's episode we're taking a look at
the AWS certified sys ops administrator.

5
00:00:22.210 --> 00:00:25.260
Joining me in the studio today is none
other than my good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:25.260 --> 00:00:26.200
Don, welcome to the show.

7
00:00:26.200 --> 00:00:27.080
How you doing today, sir?

8
00:00:27.080 --> 00:00:27.857
>> I am doing great Daniel.

9
00:00:27.857 --> 00:00:30.758
Thanks for having me here, and
excited to jump back into the world

10
00:00:30.758 --> 00:00:34.280
of Amazon Web Services and
the sys ops administrator certification.

11
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:35.692
We got a cool show lined up for you today.

12
00:00:35.692 --> 00:00:39.750
We're gonna be tackling EC2
disk storage and I know it

13
00:00:39.750 --> 00:00:43.310
seems kinda weird because the whole point
is that Amazon manages this stuff for

14
00:00:43.310 --> 00:00:47.030
us, but we do need to be aware of some
of the little ins and outs of storage.

15
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:50.352
And you guys have learned previously
about Amazon instances and

16
00:00:50.352 --> 00:00:53.243
spinning up VMs and
getting them running up in EC2, but

17
00:00:53.243 --> 00:00:57.137
there's a lot of decisions that we
make about storage that are important.

18
00:00:57.137 --> 00:00:59.730
And so I wanna make sure that we cover
each of the little ins and outs.

19
00:00:59.730 --> 00:01:02.058
And make sure we're choosing
the right storage for the right job.

20
00:01:02.058 --> 00:01:02.920
And it is important.

21
00:01:02.920 --> 00:01:06.799
>> Yeah Don, I was kinda hoping it was
just gonna be, here's some storage,

22
00:01:06.799 --> 00:01:08.050
make it this size.

23
00:01:08.050 --> 00:01:08.700
And you're done.

24
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:10.621
But obviously I'm looking
over your notes here.

25
00:01:10.621 --> 00:01:13.049
It seems to be a little
more complex than that.

26
00:01:13.049 --> 00:01:14.147
So where do we begin?

27
00:01:14.147 --> 00:01:15.208
>> All right, well, you know,

28
00:01:15.208 --> 00:01:17.718
honestly Daniel, you certainly could
treat it the way that you said.

29
00:01:17.718 --> 00:01:22.370
Which is, if you go to spin up a new EC2
instance, you can just click next a bunch

30
00:01:22.370 --> 00:01:26.765
of times and finish the wizard and
not even blink an eye at storage, right.

31
00:01:26.765 --> 00:01:30.846
But there's actually several decisions
that we make throughout the process, and

32
00:01:30.846 --> 00:01:34.530
let me just kind of show you how we
don't necessarily see what's going on.

33
00:01:34.530 --> 00:01:38.050
So, I've got my EC2 council
pulled up right here.

34
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:43.260
And if I go into EC2 and
I'll spin up a new instance, right?

35
00:01:43.260 --> 00:01:48.500
So I'll go here under Instances and
I'll just launch a new instance, and

36
00:01:48.500 --> 00:01:51.590
when I go through, I'm going to pick
my AMI that I want to go with and

37
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:54.360
I'll pick like,
an Amazon Linux AMI, all right?

38
00:01:54.360 --> 00:01:59.080
Well, when I do that, it's actually
already making one decision for me.

39
00:01:59.080 --> 00:02:03.470
Notice right here how it
says root device type EBS.

40
00:02:03.470 --> 00:02:05.540
Okay, that means that the root drive for

41
00:02:05.540 --> 00:02:09.100
this system is going to
be elastic block storage.

42
00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:11.990
When you spin up a VM there's actually
two different types of storage.

43
00:02:11.990 --> 00:02:15.280
We don't see this a lot, cuz it's
all kind of behind the scenes, but

44
00:02:15.280 --> 00:02:19.210
there's elastic block storage and
there's instance store storage.

45
00:02:19.210 --> 00:02:22.610
That's kind of redundant, but that's what
it's called, instance store storage.

46
00:02:22.610 --> 00:02:25.688
And when you spin up a VM, its important
that we understand what those are.

47
00:02:25.688 --> 00:02:29.825
All right, well where it starts to get
a little complex is that you're VM isn't

48
00:02:29.825 --> 00:02:32.913
necessarily going to be just EBS or
just instance store, or

49
00:02:32.913 --> 00:02:35.490
it could actually be a mixture of the two.

50
00:02:35.490 --> 00:02:38.980
You could have some drives on your
system that are instance stored and

51
00:02:38.980 --> 00:02:40.930
others that are EBS.

52
00:02:40.930 --> 00:02:41.680
It is very possible.

53
00:02:41.680 --> 00:02:45.370
It's not necessarily a great idea,
but you certainly can do it.

54
00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:48.860
So we need to understand that, and
before we can understand that,

55
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:50.640
we need to understand
when each is appropriate,

56
00:02:50.640 --> 00:02:53.410
so let's start out talking
about the other part here.

57
00:02:53.410 --> 00:02:57.330
It's telling me the root device is EBS,
all right?

58
00:02:57.330 --> 00:02:58.750
So what does it mean by that?

59
00:02:58.750 --> 00:03:02.490
Well, in Amazon land,
when you spin up a new instance,

60
00:03:02.490 --> 00:03:05.410
at a minimum you're gonna
have one storage drive.

61
00:03:05.410 --> 00:03:07.549
Because you gotta put the operating
system somewhere, right?

62
00:03:07.549 --> 00:03:09.310
You're gonna boot up a virtual machine.

63
00:03:09.310 --> 00:03:13.080
It's got an operating system, it's gonna
be Linux, or Windows, or whatever.

64
00:03:13.080 --> 00:03:15.140
It's gotta store that OS somewhere,
and for

65
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:17.780
that it's gonna do it on the root device.

66
00:03:17.780 --> 00:03:22.210
And then you may choose to have
other drives, or you may not.

67
00:03:22.210 --> 00:03:25.820
And if you do choose to have other drives,
that's where your data is going to go.

68
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:28.490
And Amazon just calls those
additional disks, right?

69
00:03:28.490 --> 00:03:30.860
So you've got a root device, and
then you've got additional disks.

70
00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:32.590
So those are the official terms.

71
00:03:32.590 --> 00:03:36.830
And the root device, the type is
gonna be determined right away.

72
00:03:36.830 --> 00:03:39.960
When you spin up that instance,
it's gonna be determined.

73
00:03:39.960 --> 00:03:42.740
And there is not a good way to
change from one to the other.

74
00:03:42.740 --> 00:03:44.690
Like when you spin up one, it's that one.

75
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:47.680
And I'll talk a little bit later
about how you kind of convert it for

76
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:48.670
additional disks.

77
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:51.840
But for root devices it's very,
very difficult to change that over.

78
00:03:51.840 --> 00:03:53.400
So we need to be aware of that.

79
00:03:53.400 --> 00:03:54.310
We need to understand it.

80
00:03:54.310 --> 00:03:56.440
Now why is this all important?

81
00:03:56.440 --> 00:04:00.320
Well, the root device is probably the most
important, cuz it's where our operating

82
00:04:00.320 --> 00:04:04.240
system is, and depending on the storage
type that we choose, it's gonna impact

83
00:04:04.240 --> 00:04:08.640
whether or not this data is what's
called persistent, or ephemeral, right?

84
00:04:08.640 --> 00:04:11.980
Persistent data is data that's
always gonna be there for me.

85
00:04:11.980 --> 00:04:15.990
If I shut those instance down and I bring

00:25:06.420 --> 00:25:08.250
And so you know they're fast.

541
00:25:08.250 --> 00:25:10.960
And they're guaranteeing you
a certain level of IOPS.

542
00:25:10.960 --> 00:25:12.677
Now why does it say 24 / 3000?

543
00:25:12.677 --> 00:25:19.550
Well, 3000 is considered my baseline,
but 24 is what I'm being guaranteed.

544
00:25:19.550 --> 00:25:22.170
I'm being guaranteed only 24.

545
00:25:22.170 --> 00:25:23.880
Where did that number come from?

546
00:25:23.880 --> 00:25:27.410
Well it's three times
whatever size you put.

547
00:25:27.410 --> 00:25:32.330
So if I were to bump this up to a ten
gig drive, see how it went to 30?

548
00:25:32.330 --> 00:25:34.850
Well if I do a 100 gig drive,
it went to 300, right.

549
00:25:35.880 --> 00:25:39.620
So this was how we increased
the performance of a drive in the past.

550
00:25:39.620 --> 00:25:42.490
If you had a database on a drive and
disc IO was starting to

551
00:25:42.490 --> 00:25:45.680
bottle neck a little bit, we'll see in the
monitoring episodes how we can monitor and

552
00:25:45.680 --> 00:25:49.230
see when that bottle necking is happening,
that we could take a look at it.

553
00:25:49.230 --> 00:25:54.110
See where that was kind of choking and
say all right, I need more IOs per second.

554
00:25:54.110 --> 00:25:57.280
And the solution, well,
in a real data center,

555
00:25:57.280 --> 00:26:00.390
like Daniel, do you know, if you had
a drive that was running too slow,

556
00:26:00.390 --> 00:26:02.400
what are our solutions
in a real data center?

557
00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:03.600
>> We'd buy a better drive.

558
00:26:03.600 --> 00:26:04.910
>> You can buy a better drive, right?

559
00:26:04.910 --> 00:26:09.310
Maybe you had 5,400 RPM magnetic drives,
you go to 7,200 RPMs.

560
00:26:09.310 --> 00:26:12.770
But if you've got SSD's in
there your only solution is to

561
00:26:12.770 --> 00:26:13.840
break out in a raid array right.

562
00:26:13.840 --> 00:26:15.180
Scale out, add more drives and

563
00:26:15.180 --> 00:26:17.870
spread your data across them
to improve your disk access.

564
00:26:17.870 --> 00:26:20.560
Well that's effectively what Amazon
does except I can't come in here and

565
00:26:20.560 --> 00:26:22.000
say increase my drives.

566
00:26:22.000 --> 00:26:25.280
The way you do it is by
increasing the size of the drive.

567
00:26:25.280 --> 00:26:28.194
So if I want to truly get those 3,000 IOs,

568
00:26:28.194 --> 00:26:31.820
I actually have to create
a one terabyte drive.

569
00:26:31.820 --> 00:26:35.402
And see how when I go to a 1
terabyte drive I get the 3,000 IOs?

570
00:26:35.402 --> 00:26:38.370
Now, watch what happens
if I start going higher.

571
00:26:38.370 --> 00:26:39.720
Well, it keeps going up.

572
00:26:39.720 --> 00:26:42.370
It keeps going up for a while, right?

573
00:26:42.370 --> 00:26:44.699
Let's see if I can spot
where that limit is.

574
00:26:46.150 --> 00:26:50.090
All right, so here I just went to 3,300 or
3.3 terabytes and

575
00:26:50.090 --> 00:26:54.520
it went up to 9,900, so
I'm getting close to the limit.

576
00:26:54.520 --> 00:26:56.806
There's a limit, it's 10,000, I know what
the limit is I'm just trying to hit it.

577
00:26:56.806 --> 00:26:57.596
There we go.

578
00:26:57.596 --> 00:27:02.388
So when I get to 3,400 I got 10,000 IOs,
and if I go to 3,500,

579
00:27:02.388 --> 00:27:04.410
it's still 10,000 IOs.

580
00:27:04.410 --> 00:27:07.840
In fact, if I start bumping this up and
I do like a 4TB drive,

581
00:27:07.840 --> 00:27:10.700
it's still 10,000 IOs.

582
00:27:10.700 --> 00:27:16.085
So General Purpose SSD will
give you 3,000 IOs baseline,

583
00:27:16.085 --> 00:27:21.786
and then you get 3 IOs for
every gig in size up to 10,000 IOs.

584
00:27:22.910 --> 00:27:25.540
What if I need more than 10,000 IOs?

585
00:27:25.540 --> 00:27:28.885
Well that's when Amazon says,
you're a special case, you're not normal.

586
00:27:28.885 --> 00:27:32.400
[LAUGH] You're that strange kid
in the back of the class, and

587
00:27:32.400 --> 00:27:35.830
so what they do is they say,
you just have to pay more, right?

588
00:27:35.830 --> 00:27:38.403
Sometimes the solution is to
throw money at a problem.

589
00:27:38.403 --> 00:27:39.020
[LAUGH]
>> It's so

590
00:27:39.020 --> 00:27:40.620
easy how that works out, isn't it?

591
00:27:40.620 --> 00:27:42.300
[LAUGH]
>> That's exactly how this one is.

592
00:27:42.300 --> 00:27:45.320
So if you need more IOs at that point,
don't use General Purpose.

593
00:27:45.320 --> 00:27:47.250
Switch to Provisioned IOPS.

594
00:27:47.250 --> 00:27:51.550
With Provisioned IOPS, you pay for
how many IOPS you want.

595
00:27:51.550 --> 00:27:56.930
So I might have a 200 gig drive, but
I can reserve 20,000 IOPS for it, right?

596
00:27:56.930 --> 00:27:59.900
And I'm pretty sure 20,000's the max,
so let's make sure.

597
00:27:59.900 --> 00:28:04.800
If I go too high, oops,
if I go too high, let me do it.

598
00:28:04.800 --> 00:28:05.950
I don't think that will save.

599
00:28:05.950 --> 00:28:08.290
I'm pretty sure the match
is 20,000 on this one.

600
00:28:08.290 --> 00:28:11.330
But I can have a 200 gig drive and
I don't have to go to a two or four or

601
00:28:11.330 --> 00:28:12.670
eight terabyte system.

602
00:28:12.670 --> 00:28:15.900
Now that's important because notice what
happened, you guys probably saw this,

603
00:28:15.900 --> 00:28:18.820
I didn't point it out, but
when I took that root volume and

604
00:28:18.820 --> 00:28:22.560
I started bumping it up to a terabyte,
well we didn't get any complaints, right?

605
00:28:22.560 --> 00:28:25.500
And then when I bumped it up to two
terabytes, still no complaints.

606
00:28:25.500 --> 00:28:30.070
But when I got to like three or four
terabytes, there it is, specifying this

607
00:28:30.070 --> 00:28:33.770
size of a root volume may result in
the instance not booting successfully.

608
00:28:33.770 --> 00:28:36.740
Remember what I said earlier
about that root volume.

609
00:28:36.740 --> 00:28:40.730
And I said when you have an EBS root
volume in the documentation they tell you

610
00:28:40.730 --> 00:28:44.610
the maximum size is one terabyte, but
you can actually set it to two terabytes.

611
00:28:44.610 --> 00:28:48.480
Well when I did that, when I was at two
terabytes, I didn't get any complaints.

612
00:28:48.480 --> 00:28:52.030
But as soon as I start getting over that,
like here just 2.1 terabytes,

613
00:28:52.030 --> 00:28:53.350
I started getting that warning.

614
00:28:53.350 --> 00:28:55.640
I've exceeded that limit and
that's what we need to know.

615
00:28:55.640 --> 00:28:58.400
And so on the exam they may
still say one terabyte,

616
00:28:58.400 --> 00:28:59.720
in real life it is two terabytes.

617
00:28:59.720 --> 00:29:00.950
We see that right here.

618
00:29:00.950 --> 00:29:04.966
But if I need two terabytes what I
need to really do is stop messing with

619
00:29:04.966 --> 00:29:05.942
my boot volume.

620
00:29:05.942 --> 00:29:06.590
Right?

621
00:29:06.590 --> 00:29:09.670
This boot volume was only eight
gigs in size in the beginning and

622
00:29:09.670 --> 00:29:13.360
so if I really need that much storage
I need to add an additional disc.

623
00:29:13.360 --> 00:29:15.770
And when I add an additional EBS disk,
I can come in and

624
00:29:15.770 --> 00:29:19.440
I can make this one three terabytes and
see no warning.

625
00:29:19.440 --> 00:29:21.660
It's your boot volume
that can't be that big.

626
00:29:21.660 --> 00:29:24.090
An EBS volume can be very, very large.

627
00:29:24.090 --> 00:29:25.750
Your operating system
will choke after a while.

628
00:29:25.750 --> 00:29:28.840
A lot of OSes have problems with
drives over four terabytes.

629
00:29:28.840 --> 00:29:31.340
So you'll consider that
when you add more drives.

630
00:29:31.340 --> 00:29:36.180
But so I can add this three, or
even bump it up to a four terabyte drive.

631
00:29:36.180 --> 00:29:41.020
And as an EBS disk, I can come in and
start to reserve IOs.

632
00:29:41.020 --> 00:29:42.940
Now, notice what happened here.

633
00:29:42.940 --> 00:29:47.890
I created a four terabyte EBS drive,
and how many IOs do I have?

634
00:29:47.890 --> 00:29:49.965
Zero.

635
00:29:49.965 --> 00:29:54.110
Well, what happened to that whole
three times whatever stuff?

636
00:29:54.110 --> 00:29:55.650
Well, the three times whatever stuff?

637
00:29:55.650 --> 00:29:58.480
It's probably a technical term for
that, I mean I'll just call it that.

638
00:29:58.480 --> 00:30:00.713
That applies to the root volume, right?

639
00:30:00.713 --> 00:30:05.040
With additional disks you
don't get reserved IOs.

640
00:30:05.040 --> 00:30:08.760
What you have is baselined IOPS and
burst IOPS.

641
00:30:08.760 --> 00:30:11.630
And there's this crazy thing
that goes on in the background

642
00:30:11.630 --> 00:30:13.490
that's called an IOPS credit.

643
00:30:13.490 --> 00:30:17.450
And so when you spin up that extra
instance, so this extra volume that I'm

644
00:30:17.450 --> 00:30:22.250
adding right here,
I get some IOPS credits.

645
00:30:22.250 --> 00:30:26.427
For the record, I doubt this will be on
the exam, but I get 5.4 million credits.

646
00:30:26.427 --> 00:30:29.240
Now, that means nothing to us, right?

647
00:30:29.240 --> 00:30:31.759
It's like
>> 5.4 million rupees or something.

648
00:30:31.759 --> 00:30:33.550
[LAUGH]
>> It's like learning a foreign currency.

649
00:30:33.550 --> 00:30:34.280
>> Yeah.
>> Really is.

650
00:30:34.280 --> 00:30:37.500
If I tell you it cost 5.4 million rupees,

651
00:30:37.500 --> 00:30:39.230
I don't know what
the conversion rate is and

652
00:30:39.230 --> 00:30:44.700
so when I look here at that number I get
5.4 million credits what does that mean?

653
00:30:44.700 --> 00:30:51.090
Well, that means that this disk could
run at 3,000 IOPS for 30 minutes, right?

654
00:30:51.090 --> 00:30:54.830
They give me 30 minutes worth
of credits to run at 3,000 IOPS.

655
00:30:54.830 --> 00:31:01.240
Okay, and so if I run at 3,000 IOPS for
30 minutes, I've burned up all my credits,

656
00:31:01.240 --> 00:31:05.270
and when those credits are out,
it kind of becomes like magnetic media.

657
00:31:05.270 --> 00:31:09.350
It's still SSD so it's still fast but
other people might get prioritized over

658
00:31:09.350 --> 00:31:13.230
me so the disk might be slower or
faster depending on when I use it.

659
00:31:13.230 --> 00:31:17.267
And then anytime I'm
running below 3,000 IOPS,

660
00:31:17.267 --> 00:31:21.340
I start accruing credits, so
you kinda build your credits.

661
00:31:21.340 --> 00:31:23.300
So Amazon rewards you for

662
00:31:23.300 --> 00:31:27.740
not being at peak performance all the time
and basically their stance is this,

663
00:31:27.740 --> 00:31:32.360
if you went 3,000 IOPS all the time,
you've got to use Provision IOPS.

664
00:31:32.360 --> 00:31:34.247
Switch to Provision IOps then
you'll always have 3000,

665
00:31:34.247 --> 00:31:35.491
you don't have to worry about credits.

666
00:31:35.491 --> 00:31:36.560
Right?

667
00:31:36.560 --> 00:31:41.160
But if you have bursty traffic, I know
every now and then this database gets busy

668
00:31:41.160 --> 00:31:45.900
or it only gets busy when I do backups,
or it only gets busy when I compile code.

669
00:31:45.900 --> 00:31:48.120
In that case,
just go with the General Purpose.

670
00:31:48.120 --> 00:31:50.830
You'll build up tons of credits in
the background and never even notice and

671
00:31:50.830 --> 00:31:53.960
anytime you have to hit 3000
IOPS you'll be able to do it.

672
00:31:53.960 --> 00:31:55.940
But if you're consistently
running that high,

673
00:31:55.940 --> 00:31:57.860
then you'll need to bump
over to provision storage.

674
00:31:57.860 --> 00:32:02.470
Now, I'll show you,
definitely don't have time to,

675
00:32:02.470 --> 00:32:04.960
I'll show you how to convert from
General Purpose to Provision.

676
00:32:04.960 --> 00:32:07.380
It's not easy, it's not something you
should do, so, you want to plan for

677
00:32:07.380 --> 00:32:08.480
this ahead of time.

678
00:32:08.480 --> 00:32:11.720
It's not like a check mark you check, so
this decision is pretty important when I

679
00:32:11.720 --> 00:32:15.980
spin up these disks, but
understand your data.

680
00:32:15.980 --> 00:32:17.510
Amazon does know what you're
doing with your data.

681
00:32:17.510 --> 00:32:19.120
So, you've got to understand your data.

682
00:32:19.120 --> 00:32:23.750
Is this bursty type or is this something
where I absolutely need those iOS?

683
00:32:23.750 --> 00:32:25.440
Let's get them reserve and
get them put in place.

684
00:32:25.440 --> 00:32:27.170
So, that's the decision I make here.

685
00:32:27.170 --> 00:32:29.590
And it's a decision I can't easily change.

686
00:32:29.590 --> 00:32:30.840
Same thing with magnetic.

687
00:32:30.840 --> 00:32:33.580
If I choose magnetic,
I can't easily change that.

688
00:32:33.580 --> 00:32:35.180
You really end up having to redeploy.

689
00:32:35.180 --> 00:32:37.600
And just, in case you don't see
the episode where I show this.

690
00:32:37.600 --> 00:32:40.329
The process is basically,
you take a snapshot of the disk,

691
00:32:40.329 --> 00:32:43.604
you blow the disk away, you provision
a new disk from the snapshot, and

692
00:32:43.604 --> 00:32:46.388
when you're provisioning that
new disk from the snapshot,

693
00:32:46.388 --> 00:32:49.780
you can choose the other media type and
then you can reattach the VM.

694
00:32:49.780 --> 00:32:51.860
That means you've got downtime and
it's kind of a hassle.

695
00:32:51.860 --> 00:32:53.360
You go through all those steps to do it.

696
00:32:53.360 --> 00:32:54.580
So it kind of stinks.

697
00:32:54.580 --> 00:32:58.260
So, that's the way it's done and
I'll show how to do it in another episode.

698
00:32:58.260 --> 00:33:01.410
>> Awesome, well Don, let's just say
we have definitely run out of time for

699
00:33:01.410 --> 00:33:04.940
this episode, really looking forward to
seeing that part two though, thank you for

700
00:33:04.940 --> 00:33:07.730
joining us, and
thank you guys out there for watching.

701
00:33:07.730 --> 00:33:10.650
Signing off for ITproTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

702
00:33:10.650 --> 00:33:11.260
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

703
00:33:11.260 --> 00:33:13.895
>> And we'll see you next time.

704
00:33:13.895 --> 00:33:18.470
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue to take a look at disk storage in EC2. They pick up where they left off; looking at EC2 Storage Media attributes. They they show you how to allocate EC2 storage, walking you through each step and describing the options as they are encountered.
episodes.title: EC2 Disk Storage Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.100 --> 00:00:10.100
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.941 --> 00:00:16.341
Alright, greetings everyone and
welcome to another episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.341 --> 00:00:19.289
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.289 --> 00:00:23.820
we're actually continuing looking at
AWS Certified SysOps Administrator.

5
00:00:23.820 --> 00:00:25.441
And that EC2 storage types and

6
00:00:25.441 --> 00:00:29.550
joining me again today here in the studio
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:31.220
Don, welcome back to the show,
how's it going?

8
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:31.930
>> It is going great,

9
00:00:31.930 --> 00:00:36.030
Daniel, and ready to jump right
back into that EC2 disk storage.

10
00:00:36.030 --> 00:00:38.575
We had a few things, things that I wanted
to get to that we just couldn't get

11
00:00:38.575 --> 00:00:40.015
in that last episode.

12
00:00:40.015 --> 00:00:42.905
And I'm kind of glad it worked out,
cuz as I skimmed over my notes,

13
00:00:42.905 --> 00:00:45.185
I noticed a few things that I left out.

14
00:00:45.185 --> 00:00:47.095
So, let's pick back up
with where we left off,

15
00:00:47.095 --> 00:00:51.817
which was talking about the differences
between going with magnetic storage,

16
00:00:51.817 --> 00:00:57.947
the general purpose SSD, and
the provisioned IOPS SSD, right?

17
00:00:57.947 --> 00:01:00.937
So, it's kind of giving you the rundown on
those and just as a real quick summary.

18
00:01:00.937 --> 00:01:04.267
Magnetic, that's the old
type of storage where amazon

19
00:01:04.267 --> 00:01:07.147
doesn't guarantee you a service level,
right?

20
00:01:07.147 --> 00:01:09.777
You just get what you get with it,
there's no guaranteed level of IOPS.

21
00:01:09.777 --> 00:01:10.280
Now.

22
00:01:10.280 --> 00:01:13.390
One of the things I forgot to mention was
that there is a baseline IOPS for it,

23
00:01:13.390 --> 00:01:14.000
it's a 100 IOPS.

24
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:18.960
No matter what the size of your magnetic
storage is, your baseline is 100, and

25
00:01:18.960 --> 00:01:22.055
that means that Amazon expects you
to stay right around 100 IOPS or

26
00:01:22.055 --> 00:01:24.480
input/output operations per second.

27
00:01:24.480 --> 00:01:26.610
And, maybe you do, maybe you don't.

28
00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:31.190
If it's a low yield server, if it's an OS
drive that's maybe not getting hit a lot,

29
00:01:31.190 --> 00:01:32.300
that might work out.

30
00:01:32.300 --> 00:01:34.260
Most of the time we're going to exceed it,
right.

31
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:36.900
And that's where we get
into our other disks.

32
00:01:36.900 --> 00:01:41.590
So, you talk about the general
purpose where we saw that it had that

33
00:01:41.590 --> 00:01:46.250
kinda base line of 3,000 IOPS, but it was
really three time the amount of gigs that

34
00:01:46.250 --> 00:01:49.770
we had up to a certain level and
10,000 aps was the max.

35
00:01:49.770 --> 00:01:54.213
And then, once we went to that
provisioned IOPS that's where we could

36
00:01:54.213 --> 00:01:59.500
specifically reserve an amount of
I/O operations up to 20,000 IOPS.

37
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:01.060
So, it'd actually go really high, and

38
00:02:01.060 --> 00:02:02.990
it wasn't based on the size
of the disk anymore.

39
00:02:02.990 --> 00:02:05.940
So, I didn't have to create a giant disk
when in reality all I needed were some

40
00:02:05.940 --> 00:02:06.650
extra IOPS.

41
00:02:07.750 --> 00:02:12.570
Another thing I kinda just didn't mention,
was that when you create magnetic storage,

42
00:02:12.570 --> 00:02:14.900
the magnetic storage can be
up to 1 terabyte in size.

43
00:02:14.900 --> 00:02:17.390
But that's it.
That's the max is 1 terabyte.

44
00:02:17.390 --> 00:02:19.640
But when you go general-purpose SSD or

45
00:02:19.640 --> 00:02:24.300
if you go provisioned IOPS, you can
actually do up to 16 terabytes in size.

46
00:02:24.300 --> 00:02:27.640
And I showed larger drives
on the show in part one, but

47
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:29.000
I didn't actually mention
that upper limit.

48
00:02:29.000 --> 00:02:30.770
And on the exam,
they can ask you that upper limit.

49
00:02:30.770 --> 00:02:33.310
So magnetic, it's 1 terabyte for the max.

50
00:02:33.310 --> 00:02:38.250
For provision to IOPS and for general
purpose SSD, both of those 16 terabytes.

51
00:02:38.250 --> 00:02:39.300
You can go pretty large on them.

52
00:02:40.455 --> 00:02:44.940
Alright, now let's say that performance
is your big concern, right?

53

We haven't even broken the tip of
the iceberg for things like backup and

506
00:23:38.788 --> 00:23:39.377
restore.

507
00:23:39.377 --> 00:23:40.711
So we'll get to see those later too.

508
00:23:40.711 --> 00:23:44.366
But these decisions are important to
what we covered in the last two episodes

509
00:23:44.366 --> 00:23:48.380
because the decisions you make when you
deploy the instance in the very beginning.

510
00:23:48.380 --> 00:23:50.970
So, you can make mistakes early on and
they kind of become.

511
00:23:50.970 --> 00:23:54.550
somewhat permanent, just difficult to fix,
not necessarily permanent.

512
00:23:54.550 --> 00:23:57.450
>> Awesome, well thank you for that,
and thank you, everyone, for watching.

513
00:23:57.450 --> 00:23:58.660
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

514
00:23:58.660 --> 00:24:01.045
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

515
00:24:01.045 --> 00:24:03.587
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel show you how to monitor your EC2 Instance performance. Watch here as they utilize CloudWatch to enable monitoring and explain how to interpret the data being displayed in CloudWatch. They also show you how to configure both system and instance status checks. Next they look at metrics available for Instances and EBS Volumes as well as Roles, which are used to assign access to CloudWatch. Also covered is setting up Alarms and the triggers that define them.
episodes.title: Monitoring EC2 Performance

00:00:53.296 --> 00:00:54.810
So kind of important stuff.

00:00:54.810 --> 00:00:55.730
>> Yeah it was a nice thing.

23
00:00:55.730 --> 00:00:58.320
Now this is where we're talking
about things like solar winds right,

24
00:00:58.320 --> 00:00:59.620
that's what we're going to use.

25
00:00:59.620 --> 00:01:01.270
>> Well you certainly can.

26
00:01:01.270 --> 00:01:03.991
At the end of the day when you deploy
your instances you can monitor them

00:01:03.991 --> 00:01:05.296
with whatever the heck you want.

28

But there's a lot of stuff built

>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

33
00:01:14.520 --> 00:01:16.730

us.

34

Now, Amazon's monitoring
has a really cool name.

35
00:01:18.630 --> 00:01:19.454
It's called Cloud Watch.

36
00:01:19.454 --> 00:01:22.570
And so you want to use it anyways,
it's just got a cool name.

37
00:01:22.570 --> 00:01:25.150
But the best part about it
is it's built into AWS.

38
00:01:25.150 --> 00:01:28.990
Basically what Amazon did is they
said look, we need to bill you.

39
00:01:28.990 --> 00:01:30.380
You've got to pay us money.

40

The disk IO that you use.

42

The amount of disk storage that you use.

43

So, they have to collect that

44
00:01:41.380 --> 00:01:45.260
So, they said hey why not make this

45
00:01:45.260 --> 00:01:46.990
We have to collect it anyway for

46
00:01:46.990 --> 00:01:48.720
So, let's just share it with you guys too.

47
00:01:48.720 --> 00:01:51.370
And now you can use it for
monitoring part of that health.

48
00:01:51.370 --> 00:01:54.480
They also needed to monitor your
instances to make sure they were healthy.

49
00:01:54.480 --> 00:01:55.880
Because if there was a failure.

50
00:01:55.880 --> 00:01:58.470
They needed to know to move you
over to new racks, and so on.

51
00:01:58.470 --> 00:02:00.920
And so again,
they had to monitor it themselves.

52
00:02:00.920 --> 00:02:02.620
Why not share it with you?

53
00:02:02.620 --> 00:02:05.450
And so CloudWatch is built into AWS.

54
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:07.570
It's actually turned on by default.

55
00:02:07.570 --> 00:02:09.750
It's running, monitoring your systems.

56
00:02:09.750 --> 00:02:12.900
And it does a lot of really good stuff,
just right out of the box.

57
00:02:12.900 --> 00:02:14.240
But you can make it better.

58
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:17.090
There's extra things you could do
it to improve it, to change it,

59
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:19.890
to make it work meeting your needs.

60
00:02:19.890 --> 00:02:22.430
And basically avoid using
an external system and

61
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:23.790
monitor like Daniel was mentioning.

62
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:26.120
And so
that's where it really gets kind of cool.

63
00:02:26.120 --> 00:02:30.790
Now CloudWatch is enable by default but
there's actually two levels of CloudWatch.

64
00:02:30.790 --> 00:02:33.910
If you ever look at the Amazon pricing
page you'll see that there's one level of

65
00:02:33.910 --> 00:02:36.490
CloudWatch that falls
under the free usage tier.

66
00:02:36.490 --> 00:02:38.120
And then there's one level that doesn't.

67
00:02:38.120 --> 00:02:39.940
The free usage tier CloudWatch,

68
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:42.050
it's collecting your
metrics every five minutes.

69
00:02:42.050 --> 00:02:44.650
That's all Amazon needs for their billing,
and so that's what they give you,

70
00:02:44.650 --> 00:02:45.570
and it's free.

71
00:02:45.570 --> 00:02:48.830
So it's monitoring things like your
CPU and network and platform and

72
00:02:48.830 --> 00:02:50.950
all that good stuff every five minutes.

73
00:02:50.950 --> 00:02:53.930
And if that's all you need, you can get
some great information out of there,

74
00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:55.320
doesn't cost you a dime.

75
00:02:56.350 --> 00:03:00.530
But you can turn on what's called
Cloudwatch Detailed Monitoring.

76
00:03:00.530 --> 00:03:03.520
Detailed Monitoring moves
it up to every one minute.

77
00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:05.740
So you get much more relevant
data much more quickly.

78
00:03:05.740 --> 00:03:07.360
You can dial it down to a smaller time.

79
00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:09.180
It's more granular, right?

80
00:03:09.180 --> 00:03:11.900
And you get some enhanced
monitoring functionality like

81
00:03:11.900 --> 00:03:14.230
custom metrics that we'll
see in another episode.

82
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:17.160
That are pretty neat and
really open up some power.

83
00:03:17.160 --> 00:03:19.970
And when you have that,
the sky's the limit.

84
00:03:19.970 --> 00:03:21.790
You can really monitor a lot of stuff.

85
00:03:21.790 --> 00:03:24.500
Now, when you wanna switch
to detailed monitoring.

86
00:03:24.500 --> 00:03:26.300
You guys have probably noticed it before,
right?

87
00:03:26.300 --> 00:03:28.920
Let me show you here in my console.

88
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:32.530
If I go into my EC2 console,
and I spin up an instance.

89
00:03:32.530 --> 00:03:35.870
When you spin up a new instance it
actually asks you in the wizard.

90
00:03:35.870 --> 00:03:37.740
As you move through the wizard and

91
00:03:37.740 --> 00:03:40.750
you'll see all the different
options that we get and so on.

92
00:03:40.750 --> 00:03:44.350
And then right here at the bottom
of this page I've got Monitoring,

93
00:03:44.350 --> 00:03:46.650
Enable CloudWatch detailed monitoring.

94
00:03:46.650 --> 00:03:47.990
Additional charges apply.

95
00:03:47.990 --> 00:03:52.150
If I leave that turned off, that doesn't
mean that I don't have CloudWatch.

96
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:56.360
I do, it is gonna monitor
the server every five minutes.

97
00:03:56.360 --> 00:03:59.390
But if I check that,
it's gonna monitor it every one minute.

98
00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:00.003
And that's kind of nice.

99
00:04:00.003 --> 00:04:01.350
So you get it much more relevant.

100
00:04:01.350 --> 00:04:04.380
But you also get some more
detailed metrics out of it.

101
00:04:04.380 --> 00:04:07.170
Now, if you do that,
if you turn it on, that's great.

102
00:04:07.170 --> 00:04:08.860
If you didn't do it.

103
00:04:08.860 --> 00:04:11.420
Maybe somebody else spun up
the instance and has not enabled,

104
00:04:11.420 --> 00:04:13.430
you can enable it after the fact.

105
00:04:13.430 --> 00:04:17.680
All you do is take an instance and
when you go into the action menu up top,

106
00:04:17.680 --> 00:04:19.390
it's right down here.

107
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:23.420
We can go to the action menu,
go to CloudWatch monitoring.

108
00:04:23.420 --> 00:04:27.629
And you can enable, or disable that
detailed monitoring whenever you choose.

109
00:04:27.629 --> 00:04:30.821
Okay, be careful with that because
what CloudWatch does on the back

110
00:04:30.821 --> 00:04:32.837
end when you turn it on detail monitoring.

111
00:04:32.837 --> 00:04:36.629
It's gonna store your information for
two weeks.

112
00:04:36.629 --> 00:04:38.707
Okay, and
then after two weeks it ages that out and

113
00:04:38.707 --> 00:04:40.254
replaces it with the new data right?

114
00:04:40.254 --> 00:04:45.270
So data today is replacing your
data from 14 days ago, right?

115
00:04:45.270 --> 00:04:47.910
Well if I turn on detail
monitoring right now.

116
00:04:47.910 --> 00:04:50.520
I don't just magically have
14 days worth of data there.

117
00:04:50.520 --> 00:04:52.140
It starts today.

118
00:04:52.140 --> 00:04:55.280
So if I'm having a performance
issue on my server and I go and

119
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:57.350
turn on detail monitoring right now.

120
00:04:57.350 --> 00:04:58.440
It doesn't really help.

121
00:04:58.440 --> 00:05:00.890
I mean unless I want to sit around for
a few days and collect some new data and

122
00:05:00.890 --> 00:05:02.060
have bad performance that whole time.

123
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:04.880
So we want to make sure that
we turn on detailed monitoring

124
00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:06.490
before we have an issue.

125
00:05:06.490 --> 00:05:08.610
And that way when the issue starts
we can go in and we can look,

126
00:05:08.610 --> 00:05:10.940
and we have relevant
data already there right?

127
00:05:10.940 --> 00:05:15.090
So better to have it and not need it,
then to need it and not have it.

128
00:05:15.090 --> 00:05:17.720
It's one of those kinda things,
and it's not that expensive.

129
00:05:17.720 --> 00:05:21.070
They charge you based on how
many polls you do on the data.

130
00:05:21.070 --> 00:05:24.587
So if you have enough instances that

131
00:05:24.587 --> 00:05:26.211
It can start to add up a little bit.

132
00:05:26.211 --> 00:05:29.830
But it's worth it in the end, cuz you get
some really good monitoring in the system.

133
00:05:29.830 --> 00:05:31.697
So we can turn that on and
off just whenever it's needed.

134
00:05:31.697 --> 00:05:34.962
>> Now Don, it's excellent that they
already have this on by default.

135
00:05:34.962 --> 00:05:38.630
Something I can use and that makes me,
I've got a server, right?

136
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:41.130
Say I've whipped up a server and
I say you know what?

137
00:05:41.130 --> 00:05:44.070
I want a monitor.
What is the best way to actually see

138
00:05:44.070 --> 00:05:45.570
some of the health of that server.

139
00:05:45.570 --> 00:05:48.227
>> Well you actually get the really high
level checks right here on the console

140
00:05:48.227 --> 00:05:49.337
that I'm already at, right.

141
00:05:49.337 --> 00:05:53.080
So when you're in the EC2 dashboard and
you go under instances.

142
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:56.292
You've got your instance panel here,
and as you look at it you'll see

143
00:05:56.292 --> 00:05:59.680
you've got an instance state that
says whether it's up or down.

144
00:05:59.680 --> 00:06:01.570
And then you got status checks.

145
00:06:01.570 --> 00:06:03.960
See I've got a terminated
instance here with no checks.

146
00:06:03.960 --> 00:06:08.310
But I've got a running instance, and it's
saying that i'm passing two of two checks.

147
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:12.110
Those two checks,
those are actually a part of CloudWatch.

148
00:06:12.110 --> 00:06:15.810
Those are the basic CloudWatch services
that Amazon is using themselves

149
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:18.870
to determine whether or not they need
to move your instance somewhere else.

150
00:06:18.870 --> 00:06:22.000
If the physical server you're on or
the rack that you're in.

151
00:06:22.000 --> 00:06:23.670
If it has some kind of failure.

152
00:06:23.670 --> 00:06:25.560
They'll move their
instance to another rack.

153
00:06:25.560 --> 00:06:29.910
They'll move your instance to another zone
within the same region if they need to.

154
00:06:29.910 --> 00:06:31.550
But they need to know when to do that.

155
00:06:31.550 --> 00:06:33.150
And that's what these
checks are all about.

156
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:34.110
It's a really high level.

157
00:06:34.110 --> 00:06:34.850
You can just look at that.

158
00:06:34.850 --> 00:06:36.900
And if you see a green
checkmark there you're okay.

159
00:06:36.900 --> 00:06:38.100
All right.

160
00:06:38.100 --> 00:06:40.210
But you even get some other
detailed information.

161
00:06:40.210 --> 00:06:42.020
Like down here on the bottom.

162
00:06:42.020 --> 00:06:43.330
If you choose an instance,

163
00:06:43.330 --> 00:06:46.280
you'll see the little tab at
the bottom that says status checks.

164
00:06:46.280 --> 00:06:49.350
And it's telling me here there's
two of two status checks.

165
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:51.540
Right here I can see what
those two checks are.

166
00:06:51.540 --> 00:06:55.620
I've got a systems status check,
and an instance status check.

167
00:06:55.620 --> 00:06:59.220
And those are giving me basically
details about this instance and

168
00:06:59.220 --> 00:07:00.280
kind of what they got.

169
00:07:00.280 --> 00:07:02.700
And I expect to see
certain colors in there.

170
00:07:02.700 --> 00:07:04.940
Like green means it's good.

171
00:07:04.940 --> 00:07:09.110
Amber or red means it's got a problem,
and I need to do something about it.

172
00:07:09.110 --> 00:07:10.950
So I can see right now
both of mine are healthy.

173
00:07:10.950 --> 00:07:14.230
And that's what you're gonna see most
of the time because Amazon's working

174
00:07:14.230 --> 00:07:15.840
to resolve these issues, too.

175
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:19.450
So if there was an actual system status
check, Amazon's normally on top of it and

176
00:07:19.450 --> 00:07:20.670
working to resolve it.

177
00:07:20.670 --> 00:07:24.590
If not, then you may actually see
that amber or red warning here.

178
00:07:25.920 --> 00:07:29.020
Now, these are a couple of
the status checks that we've got.

179
00:07:29.020 --> 00:07:31.550
The way these work, let me tell
you about each one a little bit.

180
00:07:32.590 --> 00:07:34.670
The system status check for example.

181
00:07:34.670 --> 00:07:38.940
This one is reporting really on
the managed services that Amazon provides.

182
00:07:38.940 --> 00:07:41.010
So we're talking about hardware, right?

183
00:07:41.010 --> 00:07:44.870
Is the physical server your
instance is on, is it healthy?

184
00:07:44.870 --> 00:07:45.900
Does it have power?

185
00:07:45.900 --> 00:07:47.360
Does it have network?

186
00:07:47.360 --> 00:07:49.070
Is it, you know, up and running?

187
00:07:49.070 --> 00:07:50.571
Is the operating system working properly?

188
00:07:50.571 --> 00:07:54.735
Because under the hood, Amazon is
running the Zen Virtualization platform,

189
00:07:54.735 --> 00:07:56.194
which runs on top of Linux.

190
00:07:56.194 --> 00:08:00.124
And so, is the underlying Linux
operating system okay and healthy?

191
00:08:00.124 --> 00:08:02.953
If they are, great,
you get a green check mark or

192
00:08:02.953 --> 00:08:05.380
a green system reach ability check pass.

193
00:08:05.380 --> 00:08:07.900
But if they aren't,
then you'll get an amber or

194
00:08:07.900 --> 00:08:09.590
a red letting you know
that there's a problem.

195
00:08:09.590 --> 00:08:11.830
So that's what that one is monitoring.

196
00:08:11.830 --> 00:08:13.520
And then under Instance Checks,

197
00:08:13.520 --> 00:08:17.270
this is where it's monitoring
your instance itself, right?

198
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:19.690
Is your virtual machine doing okay?

199
00:08:19.690 --> 00:08:20.880
Is it out of RAM?

200
00:08:20.880 --> 00:08:22.030
Has it locked up?

201
00:08:22.030 --> 00:08:23.350
Right?
What kinda problem's there?

202
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:26.000
And if it's got a problem,
you'll get amber or

203
00:08:26.000 --> 00:08:28.920
red on that one, but otherwise it'll
stay green just like we're seeing.

204
00:08:28.920 --> 00:08:31.220
So that's kinda what these two checks are.

205
00:08:31.220 --> 00:08:34.595
Remember that system status checks, that's
the physical platform that Amazon deals

206
00:08:34.595 --> 00:08:38.605
with, and in Instance Status Checks that's
your virtual machine that it's monitoring.

207
00:08:38.605 --> 00:08:41.175
>> So Don, what do I do,
say I'm monitoring my servers,

208
00:08:41.175 --> 00:08:45.165
I come into work one day, I sit down,
I come in here and I take a look and I see

209
00:08:45.165 --> 00:08:49.875
some of those horrible red little status
checks or maybe an amber or something.

210
00:08:49.875 --> 00:08:52.385
So let's say I'm doing
a System Status Check.

211
00:08:52.385 --> 00:08:54.870
What do I do at that point?

212
00:08:54.870 --> 00:08:56.360
Most of the time you're
not gonna see this,

213
00:08:56.360 --> 00:08:57.730
cuz Amazon's gonna resolve them for you.

214
00:08:57.730 --> 00:09:01.310
But if you do see one, you can open
up a ticket with Amazon, right,

215
00:09:01.310 --> 00:09:02.920
that's probably the best thing.

216
00:09:02.920 --> 00:09:04.580
They probably are already
aware of it though, so

217
00:09:04.580 --> 00:09:05.650
you probably don't even have to do that.

218
00:09:05.650 --> 00:09:09.370
But if you're in a super hurry when
you have a system status check

219
00:09:09.370 --> 00:09:11.400
that means the underlying

>> Awesome, well Don, this actually

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe how to perform advanced monitoring with custom metrics in AWS CloudWatch. First they define what a custom metric is and then walk you through creating custom metrics that will be viewable in CloudWatch. In that endeavor, you will also see how to create an Identity and Access Management(IAM) role.
episodes.title: Monitoring Custom Metrics

1

This is basically normally what we would

25

>> Yeah, I mean, if you think about it,
what's in CloudWatch already

00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:22.710
are the things that Amazon needs
to know to bill you, right.

31

not the detailed monitoring, right.

32

If you do detailed monitoring,

33

34

IOPS drive, or even if you're just doing

00:02:22.785 --> 00:02:26.422

51
00:02:26.422 --> 00:02:29.257
earn for IOPS, if you,
if you're doing general purpose SSD or

52
00:02:29.257 --> 00:02:32.110

00:02:32.110 --> 00:02:34.080
All that stuff has to be tracked.

00:02:34.080 --> 00:02:36.590

55

62
00:02:56.940 --> 00:02:59.310
I just need to know to do that, right?

provision that drive, you provision

65
00:03:06.400 --> 00:03:10.090

66
00:03:10.090 --> 00:03:11.790
You're paying for what you use.

67
00:03:11.790 --> 00:03:15.770
They don't care if you, inside of that,

68
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:20.130
1 gig, they're not concerned,

69
00:03:20.130 --> 00:03:23.870
And so Amazon's suggestion

70
00:03:23.870 --> 00:03:25.370
They're not monitoring it by default.

71
00:03:25.370 --> 00:03:28.880
And so it's not baked into CloudWatch,
it's not a part of that regular system.

72
00:03:28.880 --> 00:03:32.540
It's not there, but
you can do one of two things.

73
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:35.290
You can, one, you can do what most

So there's products out there like

76
00:03:41.190 --> 00:03:48.420
Zenoss, Zabixx, MRTG, what are some

00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:52.370
there's a ton of them that are out there

00:03:52.370 --> 00:03:56.460

00:03:56.460 --> 00:04:00.280

I I love Solar Wind's

00:04:41.390 --> 00:04:44.560
I think it's great software,

00:04:44.560 --> 00:04:45.310
So if you're a small or

I'm gonna jump into Roles, and

In fact, you'll see I've got

These are ones that I've made for

let's create one from scratch.

00:08:19.708 --> 00:08:24.364
So I'm gonna create a new role,
and I'll call this my
