00:08:24.364 --> 00:08:30.381
itprotv-demo-cw-writer so
this would be my CloudWatch writer.

169
00:08:31.780 --> 00:08:34.430
And anybody who has this role

170
00:08:34.430 --> 00:08:37.940
will be allowed to write
metric data into CloudWatch.

171
00:08:37.940 --> 00:08:40.280
So that's important for an instance.

172
00:08:40.280 --> 00:08:43.370
Then, I need to give it what
type of role it's going to be.

00:08:43.370 --> 00:08:45.940
And you'll see there's all sorts of
different role in here, but right at

174
00:08:45.940 --> 00:08:49.810

that's exactly what I wanted.

175
00:08:49.810 --> 00:08:52.000
So I'm gonna select that EC2 side.

176
00:08:53.590 --> 00:08:55.864
And then I can pick
a policy to attach to it.

00:08:55.864 --> 00:08:59.250
Now here's where things get a little
bit tricky, because the policies,

178
00:08:59.250 --> 00:09:02.260
there's some pre-built ones,
if I do a search for Cloudwatch.

179
00:09:02.260 --> 00:09:06.763
But when you look at the Cloudwatch
permissions, the things like read only,

180
00:09:06.763 --> 00:09:11.610
full access, and so on, these are talking
about access to the Cloudwatch portal,

181
00:09:11.610 --> 00:09:14.150
access to the Cloudwatch logs.

182
00:09:14.150 --> 00:09:16.020
I need the ability to write
in to CloudWatch, and

183
00:09:16.020 --> 00:09:17.478
none of these actually give that access.

184
00:09:17.478 --> 00:09:19.650
I'm gonna have to create a custom policy,
and

185
00:09:19.650 --> 00:09:21.580
unfortunately they won't let
me do that from right here.

186
00:09:21.580 --> 00:09:25.660
So what I'm gonna do is, let's see, I'm
pretty sure they won't let me do it, yeah,

187
00:09:25.660 --> 00:09:26.460
they won't let me do it from here.

188
00:09:26.460 --> 00:09:29.300
So I'm just gonna skip this and
not assign any policy whatsoever,

189
00:09:29.300 --> 00:09:30.860
I'll attach one in a second.

190
00:09:30.860 --> 00:09:33.190
And I'll just hit Next Step,
and I'll create that role.

191
00:09:33.190 --> 00:09:34.870
Now, when I create the role,

192
00:09:34.870 --> 00:09:39.210
it's kinda pointless cuz the roll
has no real permissions right?

193
00:09:39.210 --> 00:09:43.290
So I'm gonna go over here to Policies and
whip up a policy that will grant those

194
00:09:43.290 --> 00:09:46.150
permissions, so
inside of my policies here.

195
00:09:46.150 --> 00:09:50.730
I'm just gonna create a new policy and
I'm gonna use the policy generator for

196
00:09:50.730 --> 00:09:52.000
this one, that's the easiest,

197
00:09:52.000 --> 00:09:54.180
you could actually just create
your own and type it out.

198
00:09:54.180 --> 00:09:58.600
I've actually got, let me show you guys a
policy that I wrote before the show here,

199
00:09:58.600 --> 00:10:00.772
that would grant the permissions
that I'm talking about.

200
00:10:00.772 --> 00:10:02.800
There's four permissions that we need for

201
00:10:02.800 --> 00:10:06.180
a machine to be able to
write to CloudWatch.

202
00:10:06.180 --> 00:10:08.880
The first three are pretty understandable,
right?

203
00:10:08.880 --> 00:10:11.620
So, cloudwatch:GetMetricsStatistics.

204

00:31:52.920 --> 00:31:54.550

00:31:54.550 --> 00:31:55.120

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel take a look at leveraging AWS services to provide an environment with high availability. They begin by defining the term "high availability" and concepts for safeguarding against outages, specifically backup/redundancy, elasticity, and scalability. Then they show you how to orchestrate services like Elastic Load Balancers and Auto-Scaling to ensure a highly available system or service at all times.
episodes.title: High Availability
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:02.825
[SOUND]

2
00:00:02.825 --> 00:00:11.554
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.554 --> 00:00:13.597
All right, greetings, everyone, and

4
00:00:13.597 --> 00:00:16.700
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.700 --> 00:00:18.025
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:18.025 --> 00:00:20.670
In today's episode we're
continuing on our series with

7
00:00:20.670 --> 00:00:23.260
the AWS Certified SysOps Admin, and

8
00:00:23.260 --> 00:00:25.860
joining me again in the studio
today is none other than Don Pezet.

9
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:28.270
Don, welcome to the show,
how you doing today sir?

10
00:00:28.270 --> 00:00:29.190
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

11
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:32.900
Excited to talk about high
availability which is one

12
00:00:32.900 --> 00:00:38.260
of the really shining points of AWS is
that it gives us so many different ways.

13
00:00:38.260 --> 00:00:41.650
To make sure that our services
are always available and

14
00:00:41.650 --> 00:00:43.080
people are able to access them.

15
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:46.531
We're done and see that we couldnt even,
we usually couldn't even afford,

16
00:00:46.531 --> 00:00:48.919
in our own data centers it's
easy to deploy up an AWS,

17
00:00:48.919 --> 00:00:51.278
you really get to take
advantage of some neat stuff.

18
00:00:51.278 --> 00:00:53.180
You need to know it's there,
you need to understand how it works.

19
00:00:53.180 --> 00:00:56.640
And more importantly for the exam, we need
to know how Amazon intends us to use it.

20
00:00:56.640 --> 00:00:59.700
So that's what we're gonna take a look at
in this episode as we move through some of

21
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:05.265
the different key pieces of creating
a highly available solution in AWS.

22
00:01:05.265 --> 00:01:08.345
>> Yeah, having something in your
network not be available to,

23
00:01:08.345 --> 00:01:11.535
think if your web server went down,
not good right, especially if your

24
00:01:11.535 --> 00:01:16.430
a web based company, if IT PRO TV websites
were down that would not be good for us.

25
00:01:16.430 --> 00:01:20.700
So we have to make sure that we stay
up as long as humanly possible.

26
00:01:20.700 --> 00:01:24.590
Now, Don, this is something that Amazon
says they can protect us from, right?

27
00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:26.130
>> Yeah.
>> How do they do that?

28
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:27.500
>> And who would know better than them?

29
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:29.360
They're an online retailer
>> That's true.

30
00:01:29.360 --> 00:01:30.780
>> and they have no physical stores.

31
00:01:30.780 --> 00:01:33.210
So if their website goes down,
what happens to them?

32
00:01:33.210 --> 00:01:34.380
They stop making money.

33
00:01:34.380 --> 00:01:38.810
So the choice for them is the site is up
and we make money or the site is down and

34
00:01:38.810 --> 00:01:39.760
we don't make money.

35
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:40.989
Which state that we wanna be in?

36
00:01:40.989 --> 00:01:42.920
It's an easy choice,
you always wanna be up.

37
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:44.225
So they've all ready done this for

38
00:01:44.225 --> 00:01:47.156
there own site and then they offer the
features to use, so you can do the same.

39
00:01:47.156 --> 00:01:50.864
The key thing to remember about the
availability, is people often times don't

40
00:01:50.864 --> 00:01:53.757
realize all the different things
that affect availability.

41
00:01:53.757 --> 00:01:58.253
That the definition of availability
is that a customer can come to your

42
00:01:58.253 --> 00:02:02.860
application and perform the action
you intend them to perform.

43
00:02:02.860 --> 00:02:07.163
And whatever your application, is it might
be an email server, it might be a file

44
00:02:07.163 --> 00:02:11.177
transfer server, it might be a online
shopping cart, it might be a forum.

45
00:02:11.177 --> 00:02:14.447
Let's say a forum, they need to be able
to browse through your webpage and

46
00:02:14.447 --> 00:02:15.305
read forum posts.

47
00:02:15.305 --> 00:02:18.090
And they need to be able to post and
add new posts to it.

48
00:02:18.090 --> 00:02:21.310
And if anything stops them
from being able to do that,

49
00:02:21.310 --> 00:02:23.840
your site is down,
it doesn't have to be a hardware failure.

50
00:02:23.840 --> 00:02:26.580
People think of power outage,
a hard drive failing,

51
00:02:26.580 --> 00:02:31.410
a server dying right, but
that's only one aspect of availability.

52
00:02:31.410 --> 00:02:35.020
It could be down because of
a bad software configuration,

53
00:02:35.020 --> 00:02:38.390
it could be down because of a hacker,
somebody gets in and defaces our website.

54
00:02:38.390 --> 00:02:41.620
It could be that our server is so
over loaded with traffic.

55
00:02:41.620 --> 00:02:43.770
We had a video that went viral and
now we have so

56
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:46.360
much traffic the server
can't handle it anymore.

57
00:02:46.360 --> 00:02:50.260
Those are all things that could
make our server unavailable.

58
00:02:50.260 --> 00:02:54.420
So the server might actually be up and
happy and responding to traffic and

59
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:58.060
it's just overwhelmed, and it creates
the same environment as if server was down

60
00:02:58.060 --> 00:03:00.560
on the first place, but
affects availability.

61
00:03:00.560 --> 00:03:01.726
So when you're planning for

62
00:03:01.726 --> 00:03:04.211
high availability it's not
all redundant power supplies.

63
00:03:04.211 --> 00:03:09.021
It's not all that, it's making sure
the server stays up even when these odd

64
00:03:09.021 --> 00:03:13.697
conditions are happening, and
often times a backup isn't good enough.

65
00:03:13.697 --> 00:03:16.650
Cuz, if the server goes down and I have to
restore from backup, I've got down time.

66
00:03:16.650 --> 00:03:21.380
Highly available means being
online even during the failure.

67
00:03:21.380 --> 00:03:22.880
Backup and
restore isn't gonna handle that.

68
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:26.630
So we need to think about the other stuff
that's available that can help us to

69
00:03:26.630 --> 00:03:29.340
survive through anything that
would affect availability.

70
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:32.990
>> Yeah, you really bring up the question
that comes to the mind is, okay,

71
00:03:32.990 --> 00:03:37.720
we do have these weird,
odd things do cause non availability.

72
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:40.810
What can we do to just stop that,
dominigate that problem?

73
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:42.800
>> All right.
So I mentioned back to restores.

74
00:03:42.800 --> 00:03:46.300
If its a significant failure,
like data center goes down or

75
00:03:46.300 --> 00:03:49.920
we have some operating system lock up or
what ever.

76
00:03:49.920 --> 00:03:53.080
We can always bring up a new server,
restore our data and off we go.

77
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:57.610
But that doesnt really help availability
That helps just durability I guess,

78
00:03:57.610 --> 00:04:00.050
getting your system back online and
making it available.

79
00:04:00.050 --> 00:04:02.970
It doesn't keep us available
during the failure.

80
00:04:02.970 --> 00:04:07.730
So that's kinda out, so what we need to
do is rely on a couple other concepts,

81
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:11.460
mostly elasticity and scalability.

82
00:04:11.460 --> 00:04:14.450
We can leverage those two things
to make sure that we stay online

83
00:04:14.450 --> 00:04:16.380
even when we have a failure.

84
00:04:16.380 --> 00:04:18.150
So it's two kinda key concepts.

85
00:04:18.150 --> 00:04:21.570
You see it spread all throughout
the Amazon console, elasticity this, and

86
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:22.830
scalability that.

87
00:04:22.830 --> 00:04:24.130
And when you leverage both of them,

88
00:04:24.130 --> 00:04:26.630
you can get a really,
really highly available environment.

89
00:04:26.630 --> 00:04:29.090
>> Yeah, and Don, I don't wanna stop
here on a good train of thought there,

90
00:04:29.090 --> 00:04:30.910
but you're saying elasticity and

91
00:04:30.910 --> 00:04:35.330
scalability, really sounds like it's
the same thing to be honest with you.

92
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:37.800
>> Yeah, it is confusing, and for

93
00:04:37.800 --> 00:04:39.750
most of us we use the terms
interchangeably, right?

94
00:04:39.750 --> 00:04:41.080
Let's talk about the terms themselves,
right.

95
00:04:41.080 --> 00:04:46.090
So elasticity, that means that I
can maintain a small environment.

96
00:04:46.090 --> 00:04:49.890
And if my system starts to get
really busy, if it gets overwhelmed,

97
00:04:49.890 --> 00:04:55.820
it can stretch and expand to have more
systems in it, to cover the high load.

98
00:04:55.820 --> 00:04:57.230
And then as the load goes away and

99
00:04:57.230 --> 00:05:01.770
recedes, it can shrink back into
it's original size, it's elastic.

100
00:05:01.770 --> 00:05:04.240
So I might have five web servers now, and

101
00:05:04.240 --> 00:05:06.170
then an hour from now I
have ten web servers.

102
00:05:06.170 --> 00:05:08.140
And two hours now I'm
back to five web servers.

103
00:05:08.140 --> 00:05:09.580
Right.
That's elasticity.

104
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:11.060
We grow and we shrink.

105
00:05:11.060 --> 00:05:15.610
Okay, scalability, same idea.

106
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:18.230
I've got a set of systems, and
they can handle a certain load.

107
00:05:18.230 --> 00:05:22.440
And as that load increases I can
scale them either up or out.

108
00:05:22.440 --> 00:05:25.710
Scale them to grow in my
environment to handle that load,

109
00:05:25.710 --> 00:05:28.000
that sounds just like elasticity,
doesn't it?

110
00:05:28.000 --> 00:05:31.750
Well the difference is kind of really
on the shrink back side, okay.

111
00:05:31.750 --> 00:05:34.400
Elasticity is designed to be temporary.

112
00:05:34.400 --> 00:05:37.210
That means I get some high
utilization on my system right now,

113
00:05:37.210 --> 00:05:40.370
so I go from five servers to ten servers.

114
00:05:40.370 --> 00:05:43.900
But then that traffic goes away, it was
just a peak, it was a one time thing.

115
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:47.090
And so we shrink back to the original
five servers, that's elasticity.

116
00:05:48.390 --> 00:05:53.450
Scalability on the other hand is usually
long term and it's usually permanent.

117
00:05:53.450 --> 00:05:57.290
That maybe when I brought up
the server I had 100 customers.

118
00:05:57.290 --> 00:05:59.170
Now I've got 1000 customers.

119
00:05:59.170 --> 00:06:02.970
So I scale my systems to be able to
handle that load of 1000 customers.

120
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:05.700
Now am I planning on losing all
my customers the next month?

121
00:06:05.700 --> 00:06:08.100
Hopefully not, I've got 1,000
customers I wanna keep them.

122
00:06:08.100 --> 00:06:11.570
In fact, I wanna grow to 2,000 customers,
or 5,000 or 10,000 customers.

123
00:06:11.570 --> 00:06:15.380
And so we scale to support
that load of customers.

124
00:06:15.380 --> 00:06:18.800
So elasticity is temporary, short term.

125
00:06:18.800 --> 00:06:21.800
Scalability is usually permanent and
long term.

126
00:06:21.800 --> 00:06:22.910
But you can scale back, too.

127
00:06:22.910 --> 00:06:23.630
You've got that.

128
00:06:23.630 --> 00:06:25.030
But that's not usually
when we're doing it.

129
00:06:25.030 --> 00:06:28.650
We're normally thinking of permanent
growth to support our organization.

130
00:06:28.650 --> 00:06:30.550
The two systems work very similar.

131
00:06:30.550 --> 00:06:32.920
The difference is whether
we automate them, right.

132
00:06:32.920 --> 00:06:35.160
Elasticity is normally automated.

133
00:06:35.160 --> 00:06:38.830
We need the servers to react on their
own to this one time burst of traffic or

134
00:06:38.830 --> 00:06:41.160
whatever, so
that our site doesn't go down.

135
00:06:41.160 --> 00:06:45.010
If we have a video go viral and
millions of people are coming to our site,

136
00:06:45.010 --> 00:06:47.570
we want those millions of people
to be able to get the traffic.

137
00:06:47.570 --> 00:06:50.200
But we know eventually the hype
will die down for that video.

138
00:06:50.200 --> 00:06:52.790
We'll just go back to our regular
traffic levels which might be very,

139
00:06:52.790 --> 00:06:54.170
very small, right?

140
00:06:54.170 --> 00:06:57.900
So we need elasticity for that, automated,
handle the load when it happens.

141
00:06:58.900 --> 00:07:02.240
But scalability,
we look at our traffic and we say,

142
00:07:02.240 --> 00:07:04.620
boy, we doubled our
customer base this year.

143
00:07:04.620 --> 00:07:08.060
So next year if we continue on this
trend we're gonna be at this level,

144
00:07:08.060 --> 00:07:10.300
let's scale our system to
be able to handle that.

145
00:07:10.300 --> 00:07:12.290
And we scale it, and we leave it.

146
00:07:12.290 --> 00:07:15.680
And we leave it at that level, and
we continue scaling as our system grows,

147
00:07:15.680 --> 00:07:18.430
it's long term and
typically permanent, right?

148
00:07:18.430 --> 00:07:21.390
Now in terms of the technology we use,
there's really not much difference

149
00:07:21.390 --> 00:07:23.490
aside from whether we
automate the process or not.

150
00:07:23.490 --> 00:07:26.180
But that's kinda the key
difference between the two.

151
00:07:26.180 --> 00:07:28.860
Now when I talk about elasticity.

152
00:07:28.860 --> 00:07:36.070
Elasticity is always talking about scaling
out, adding more servers to cover a need.

153
00:07:36.070 --> 00:07:40.900
But when we talk about scalability,
we could be scaling out or scaling up.

154
00:07:40.900 --> 00:07:42.820
And on the exam you'll see it
written two different ways.

155
00:07:42.820 --> 00:07:46.366
There's scaling up, which means
you take a piece of hardware, and

156
00:07:46.366 --> 00:07:47.808
you improve the hardware.

157
00:07:47.808 --> 00:07:52.039
So if I have an instance running that
has four gigs of RAM and two CPUs and

158
00:07:52.039 --> 00:07:56.658
it starts getting busy, I might bump it
up to eight gigs of RAM and four CPUs.

159
00:07:56.658 --> 00:08:01.404
Move it from a C4 large to a C.

160
00:08:01.404 --> 00:08:03.937
Five, or a C4 extra large.

161
00:08:03.937 --> 00:08:08.060
So I might bump it up to the next instance
type to get more resources out of it.

162
00:08:08.060 --> 00:08:09.820
That's scaling up.

163
00:08:09.820 --> 00:08:12.060
It's also called scaling vertically.

164
00:08:12.060 --> 00:08:14.610
And scaling vertically is great, cuz you
can do it while the server's online.

165
00:08:14.610 --> 00:08:16.590
And it doesn't require any
special configuration.

166
00:08:16.590 --> 00:08:18.890
You just go and edit the server's
properties and scale it up.

167
00:08:18.890 --> 00:08:21.370
We can do it whenever we want.

168
00:08:21.370 --> 00:08:22.980
But the problem is there's a limit.

169
00:08:22.980 --> 00:08:25.800
There comes a time where you hit a limit,
and

170
00:08:25.800 --> 00:08:29.320
when you hit that limit,
you can't scale up anymore.

171
00:08:29.320 --> 00:08:33.170
And so depending on what
region you're in and so on,

172
00:08:33.170 --> 00:08:39.100
that limit might be 64 processors and
256 gigs of RAM, right?

173
00:08:39.100 --> 00:08:40.930
And so you finally hit that limit.

174
00:08:40.930 --> 00:08:42.430
And now what do you do?

175
00:08:42.430 --> 00:08:43.420
You're out of luck.

176
00:08:43.420 --> 00:08:46.840
So scaling vertically works, but it does
have a limit that you're going to hit and

177
00:08:46.840 --> 00:08:47.810
you're going to hit it eventually.

178
00:08:49.060 --> 00:08:52.990
Scaling out, on the other hand,
is where we have one server and

179
00:08:52.990 --> 00:08:55.920
it starts to get where it's
running out of resources.

180
00:08:55.920 --> 00:08:57.940
And before we run out,
if you want to stay available,

181
00:08:57.940 --> 00:09:01.070
if you want to stay online,
you've got to do this beforehand.

182
00:09:01.070 --> 00:09:03.850
And before it runs out,
we had the second server.

183
00:09:03.850 --> 00:09:07.000
And now the two servers are carrying that
load, and then I had a third server, and

184
00:09:07.000 --> 00:09:09.030
a fourth server, a 500th server.

185
00:09:09.030 --> 00:09:13.080
However many it is that I need to
cover the load of my customer base,

186
00:09:13.080 --> 00:09:15.480
and there's not a limit to this.

187
00:09:15.480 --> 00:09:18.180
I can scale out to my heart's content.

188
00:09:18.180 --> 00:09:20.920
And I can scale up within those servers,
but I'm scaling on

189
00:09:20.920 --> 00:09:25.040
having more servers to cover the load,
and that gives us a lot more power.

190
00:09:25.040 --> 00:09:27.630
Now scaling out is also called
scaling horizontally, right,

191
00:09:27.630 --> 00:09:29.000
that's why I keep doing
the hand motion like that.

192
00:09:29.000 --> 00:09:32.270
In other words, adding more and
more servers scaling horizontally or

193
00:09:32.270 --> 00:09:33.600
scaling out.

194
00:09:33.600 --> 00:09:37.010
Now, when you have an environment that's
starting to come under utilization,

195
00:09:37.010 --> 00:09:38.650
maybe it's a denial of service attack.

196
00:09:38.650 --> 00:09:42.350
Maybe it's a Black Friday sale and
you got more customers than normal.

197
00:09:42.350 --> 00:09:44.670
It's up to you to choose whether
you wanna scale up or scale out.

198
00:09:44.670 --> 00:09:47.940
Scaling up is easier, but
scaling out is not actually that hard.

199
00:09:47.940 --> 00:09:50.028
I'm gonna show you the process
a little bit later this episode.

200
00:09:50.028 --> 00:09:54.421
>> So it's sounds like done there is
definitely a specific time when I would

201
00:09:54.421 --> 00:09:56.941
choose scaling up versus scaling out, or

202
00:09:56.941 --> 00:10:01.837
I guess that brings up that question is
there anytime when you're looking out and

203
00:10:01.837 --> 00:10:05.900
you're going, should I scale up here or
should I scale out?

204
00:10:05.900 --> 00:10:07.510
When those scenarios happen,
what do we do?

205
00:10:07.510 --> 00:10:09.600
>> All right, so on the exam
>> [LAUGH]

206
00:10:09.600 --> 00:10:11.480
>> It's easy, scaling out or

207
00:10:11.480 --> 00:10:13.980
scaling horizontally is almost
always the right answer.

208
00:10:13.980 --> 00:10:17.075
So that's what Amazon want you to do,
that's the recommend model and

209
00:10:17.075 --> 00:10:19.460
that's absolutely true even in real
life not just in exam scenario.

210
00:10:19.460 --> 00:10:22.830
But in real life you normally
wanna scale out whenever possible.

211
00:10:22.830 --> 00:10:24.804
But there are time when
that it doesn't work, and

212
00:10:24.804 --> 00:10:26.640
a great example is a database, right?

213
00:10:26.640 --> 00:10:29.719
If I've got a database and
RDS and I bring it up and

214
00:10:29.719 --> 00:10:32.360
I bring it online, I can set up replicas.

215
00:10:32.360 --> 00:10:33.510
Right?

216
00:10:33.510 --> 00:10:35.030
But the replicas are read-only and

217
00:10:35.030 --> 00:10:37.660
if I'm trying to balance out read traffic,
I can do that.

218
00:10:37.660 --> 00:10:41.510
I can bring up an aurora database,
I can have 16 replicas and

219
00:10:41.510 --> 00:10:43.450
now I've got reads spread
around 16 servers.

220
00:10:43.450 --> 00:10:44.918
That's scaling out.

221
00:10:44.918 --> 00:10:46.790
But what about my writes?

222
00:10:46.790 --> 00:10:50.870
The write operations on the database
happen on the primary server, one server.

223
00:10:50.870 --> 00:10:53.850
And that's it,
I can't do writes on more than one server.

224
00:10:53.850 --> 00:10:55.120
I would get inconsistent writes.

225
00:10:55.120 --> 00:10:56.496
I would get conflicting writes left and
right.

226
00:10:56.496 --> 00:10:58.940
It would be a problem, right?

227
00:10:58.940 --> 00:11:01.190
See how many times I say write
in the same sentence there.

228
00:11:01.190 --> 00:11:02.790
But that wouldn't work.

229

511
00:24:39.130 --> 00:24:42.280
And what's gonna happen is,
when we create this ELB.

512
00:24:42.280 --> 00:24:43.830
It's gonna watch the nodes inside of it.

513
00:24:43.830 --> 00:24:47.780
And it's gonna track whether they're
in-service or out of service.

514
00:24:47.780 --> 00:24:48.660
We'll have to tell it how to do it.

515
00:24:48.660 --> 00:24:51.680
So the health checks
are actually baked into ELB.

516
00:24:51.680 --> 00:24:55.750
It's not like in Route 53 where we have
to choose to add the health checks,

517
00:24:55.750 --> 00:24:56.800
here they're baked into it.

518
00:24:56.800 --> 00:24:58.910
So we're gonna see that in just a second.

519
00:24:58.910 --> 00:25:01.840
Now I've got this listener configured
now for port 80, so I'm listening for

00:25:01.840 --> 00:25:03.130
web traffic.

00:25:03.130 --> 00:25:05.470
So I need to set,
I guess I have to give it a name too.

00:25:05.470 --> 00:25:07.460
I should probably have thought of that.

523
00:25:07.460 --> 00:25:09.100
I lost it.
I had typed it earlier.

524
00:25:09.100 --> 00:25:10.835
Well anyhow so I called it,
what did I call it?

525
00:25:10.835 --> 00:25:13.182
us-east-web servers.

526
00:25:13.182 --> 00:25:15.880

00:25:15.880 --> 00:25:17.930
If I am listening for

528
00:25:17.930 --> 00:25:21.850
port 80 traffic coming in, then I

529
00:25:21.850 --> 00:25:25.258
I might want to create a security group
anyway that will limit access to it while

00:25:25.258 --> 00:25:27.340
I'm getting it set up and
configured and so on.

531
00:25:27.340 --> 00:25:28.605
So we can certainly do that,

00:25:28.605 --> 00:25:32.330
I actually have an existing security
group that I am going to use, this one.

00:25:32.330 --> 00:25:34.020
That already allows port 80.

534
00:25:34.020 --> 00:25:36.465
So I'm gonna do that one, but
you can create your own and

535
00:25:36.465 --> 00:25:39.030
specify whatever protocol it
is that you're balancing.

536
00:25:40.700 --> 00:25:43.720
Then, it's just asking me here
to verify my security settings.

537
00:25:43.720 --> 00:25:46.580
And I don't have much here cuz I
didn't create a new security group.

538
00:25:46.580 --> 00:25:47.790
If I did a new one,
here's where I would set it up.

539
00:25:47.790 --> 00:25:51.246
And so it's just warning me that I do
have HTTP open and it's open to the whole

540
00:25:51.246 --> 00:25:54.824
world, and I should really consider using
HTTPS or SSL but I'll pass on that.

541
00:25:54.824 --> 00:25:59.590
And then here is the health
check Daniel asked about.

542
00:25:59.590 --> 00:26:03.410
So, how does it know if a node is up and
running and

543
00:26:03.410 --> 00:26:06.930
you can tell it to check for
HTTP or anything.

544
00:26:06.930 --> 00:26:10.278
If it's a database server I can tell it
to reach out and do TCP connections or

545
00:26:10.278 --> 00:26:12.580
Microsoft Remote Desktop,
the terminal server.

546
00:26:12.580 --> 00:26:14.689
So I can say, hey, try and
connect on TCP 3389.

547
00:26:14.689 --> 00:26:17.950
If you get a connection, the node is up.

548
00:26:17.950 --> 00:26:19.810
Now, it's not very advanced.

549
00:26:19.810 --> 00:26:22.560
It can't test and
say can I actually log in and

550
00:26:22.560 --> 00:26:24.380
get a desktop,
it doesn't know how to do that.

551
00:26:24.380 --> 00:26:25.900
It's just seeing if the ports open,

552
00:26:25.900 --> 00:26:27.950
if that server is responding
on that port number.

553
00:26:27.950 --> 00:26:31.060
So the server could actually be down and
you see that with database servers a lot.

554
00:26:31.060 --> 00:26:34.530
Where the hard drive storing the database
might have failed so the database is

555
00:26:34.530 --> 00:26:38.710
offline but the service is still running
and still answering on that port.

556
00:26:38.710 --> 00:26:42.760
So it might not know it's down, with HTTP
it can be a little more sophisticated cuz

557
00:26:42.760 --> 00:26:46.840
we can actually request a particular
page so I might have a php app so

558
00:26:46.840 --> 00:26:50.960
I specifically request index.PHP, and
I probably need to put that on port 80.

559
00:26:50.960 --> 00:26:54.470
There we go, so it will do that request
a little more intelligently, and

560
00:26:54.470 --> 00:26:56.420
then I can specify how
often I want to check.

561
00:26:56.420 --> 00:26:58.320
Now the defaults are pretty good.

562
00:26:58.320 --> 00:27:01.040
The way it works is we're
gonna request that page and

563
00:27:01.040 --> 00:27:05.890
if we don't get that page back in
five seconds, it's a failure, right.

564
00:27:05.890 --> 00:27:09.700
You might wanna give it longer if we know
the page takes a long time to render, but

565
00:27:09.700 --> 00:27:12.840
I think in the marketing world they always
tell you that a page should load in under

566
00:27:12.840 --> 00:27:15.020
two seconds or
you're gonna lose your customer anyway, so

567
00:27:15.020 --> 00:27:16.670
five seconds is probably
more than generous.

568
00:27:18.030 --> 00:27:20.170
Then we've got out health check interval,
right.

569
00:27:20.170 --> 00:27:21.220
How often do we check?

570
00:27:21.220 --> 00:27:23.850
And the default is every 30 seconds.

571
00:27:23.850 --> 00:27:27.774
Now every 30 seconds sounds like a lot but
there's a little problem because the very

572
00:27:27.774 --> 00:27:29.860
next thing here is
the unhealthy threshold.

573
00:27:29.860 --> 00:27:33.450
How many failures have to happen
before we decide a node is dead?

574
00:27:33.450 --> 00:27:38.810
If we're checking every 30 seconds and
we have an unhealthy threshold of 2.

575
00:27:38.810 --> 00:27:43.680
That means every 60 seconds, that's how
long it would take us to detect a failure.

576
00:27:43.680 --> 00:27:47.630
Cuz the first failure happens, we wait
another 30 seconds, we try again and

577
00:27:47.630 --> 00:27:48.490
then we see the failure.

578
00:27:48.490 --> 00:27:49.490
So it'll take a minute.

579
00:27:49.490 --> 00:27:51.450
Our website could be down for
an entire minute.

580
00:27:51.450 --> 00:27:54.240
So I might wanna shrink this
down a good bit and try and

581
00:27:54.240 --> 00:27:58.360
minimize that to make it where
the detection happens a lot faster.

582
00:27:58.360 --> 00:28:02.380
So I can come in and I can say, I'm gonna
make my response time three seconds.

583
00:28:02.380 --> 00:28:05.010
If I don't get that page back in
three seconds, it's a failure.

584
00:28:05.010 --> 00:28:06.630
And I can set my health check interval.

585
00:28:06.630 --> 00:28:08.740
Maybe I'll do every ten seconds.

586
00:28:08.740 --> 00:28:10.730
So I'm gonna check every ten seconds and

587
00:28:10.730 --> 00:28:13.780
if I have two failures,
then I know the page is dead.

588
00:28:13.780 --> 00:28:15.880
And that's gonna be 20 seconds now.

589
00:28:15.880 --> 00:28:19.950
So in two times ten or
two intervals of ten.

590
00:28:19.950 --> 00:28:22.400
We'll give that 20 seconds, we'll know
the page is down and we'll fail it over.

591
00:28:22.400 --> 00:28:24.880
And then how do we decide
it's healthy again?

592
00:28:24.880 --> 00:28:29.930
Well, I might want to give it say four
checks before I bring it healthy.

593
00:28:29.930 --> 00:28:31.860
So when the server comes back up,

594
00:28:31.860 --> 00:28:35.070
test it four times before I
actually allow it to come back up.

595
00:28:35.070 --> 00:28:36.990
And that way if it's flapping,
like it comes up and

596
00:28:36.990 --> 00:28:39.530
then crashes again, I won't just
immediately throw it back into the pool.

597
00:28:41.240 --> 00:28:43.450
All right, then I can pick my instances.

598
00:28:43.450 --> 00:28:47.550
And I can pick instances I've already got
or I can add them later on after the fact.

599
00:28:47.550 --> 00:28:49.970
And a lot of times we'll attach
these to an auto scaling group.

600
00:28:49.970 --> 00:28:53.060
So it's adding new instances, and
automatically throwing them in here.

601
00:28:53.060 --> 00:28:55.950
But I'll just pick all my servers,
let's go crazy.

602
00:28:55.950 --> 00:28:56.490
And add them in.

603
00:28:56.490 --> 00:29:01.190
Now notice I'm getting servers in
those different availability zones,

604
00:29:01.190 --> 00:29:04.480
I've got two servers in 1c and one in 1d.

605
00:29:04.480 --> 00:29:09.530
So now, if 1c were to completely go
offline, I've still got a node over in 1d,

606
00:29:09.530 --> 00:29:10.720
or vice-versa.

607
00:29:10.720 --> 00:29:13.090
So now I've got redundancy
within the availability zones.

608
00:29:13.090 --> 00:29:16.587
But they are all in the same region,
so if the region has an outage,

609
00:29:16.587 --> 00:29:17.850
I'm still in trouble.

610
00:29:17.850 --> 00:29:21.230
All right.

611
00:29:21.230 --> 00:29:22.270
Now down at the bottom,

612
00:29:22.270 --> 00:29:26.810
there's a little check mark here that
says Enable Cross-Zone Load Balancing.

613
00:29:26.810 --> 00:29:30.210
If I turn that off, my servers
will have to be in the same zone.

614
00:29:31.310 --> 00:29:33.130
Which there's not a lot of reason for
that.

615
00:29:33.130 --> 00:29:34.690
That's why it's on by default,

616
00:29:34.690 --> 00:29:37.770
but you can disable that if you want,
and you can set that.

617
00:29:37.770 --> 00:29:39.679
There's one other option here
which is connection draining.

618
00:29:40.730 --> 00:29:42.430
If I need to shut a server down,

619
00:29:42.430 --> 00:29:46.050
if I need to take a server out of the
pool, you can do what's called draining.

620
00:29:46.050 --> 00:29:48.760
Draining says, don't just shut down
right now, because anybody who's

621
00:29:48.760 --> 00:29:51.750
connected to that server is gonna
get moved over to another server.

622
00:29:51.750 --> 00:29:52.790
And what if they had a shopping cart?

623
00:29:52.790 --> 00:29:54.720
Right, what if they were in
the middle of a purchase?

624
00:29:54.720 --> 00:29:55.880
They're gonna lose that.

625
00:29:55.880 --> 00:29:57.080
Connection draining says,

626
00:29:57.080 --> 00:30:00.450
when I go to shut a server down
don't send anymore traffic to it.

627
00:30:00.450 --> 00:30:04.060
Don't send any,
well don't send any new traffic to it.

628
00:30:04.060 --> 00:30:08.660
But let the existing sessions continue for
up to 5 minutes, 300 seconds, so

629
00:30:08.660 --> 00:30:10.120
they can finish what they're doing.

630
00:30:10.120 --> 00:30:11.310
If they haven't finished in that time,

631
00:30:11.310 --> 00:30:13.060
then we take it out and
they lose it, right?

632
00:30:13.060 --> 00:30:16.390
You might wanna set that to a higher
number, so that people have time to finish

633
00:30:16.390 --> 00:30:18.760
their transaction, finish buying
whatever it is they're buying.

634
00:30:18.760 --> 00:30:20.670
You don't wanna give your
customers a bad experience just

635
00:30:20.670 --> 00:30:22.040
cuz you're doing maintenance on a server.

636
00:30:23.960 --> 00:30:24.921
All right.
Once that's done,

637
00:30:24.921 --> 00:30:27.230
when we're ready to move forward to
the last screen here which is add tags.

And we'll get that ELB created.

640
00:30:31.310 --> 00:30:33.450
Once it's created, we're ready to rock.

641
00:30:33.450 --> 00:30:34.310
Right?

642

643
00:30:38.680 --> 00:30:40.850
But at this point,
I think we've seen the load balancer.

644
00:30:40.850 --> 00:30:41.600
We've seen what it can do.

645
00:30:41.600 --> 00:30:44.270
We've seen the basic configuration.

646
00:30:44.270 --> 00:30:46.980
What I need to continue showing

647

how to make sure it's working, and see
how to actually use it in production so

648

649
00:30:52.180 --> 00:30:55.680
But for this one, I think let's see,
did I leave anything out?

650
00:30:55.680 --> 00:30:57.855
You know I did leave some other stuff out.

651
00:30:57.855 --> 00:31:00.245
We'll probably have to do a part two
cuz we don't have time on this one.

652
00:31:00.245 --> 00:31:02.753
Yeah, you've bumped your
gums quite a bit there, Don.

653
00:31:02.753 --> 00:31:05.495
[LAUGH] All right, so let's round this up.

654
00:31:05.495 --> 00:31:06.955
We'll do a part two, definitely come back,

655
00:31:06.955 --> 00:31:10.335
cuz there's more configuration features
that we don't see in the setup wizard, but

658
00:31:13.635 --> 00:31:14.255
Awesome stuff, Don.

659
00:31:14.255 --> 00:31:18.365
This is really intriguing, to have that
ability to do the load balancing and

660
00:31:18.365 --> 00:31:20.860
set these up now,

661
00:31:20.860 --> 00:31:24.480
How we need to implement them in our

662
00:31:24.480 --> 00:31:28.510
Thank you for showing us that, we look
forward to part two, finishing this up and

663
00:31:28.510 --> 00:31:31.180

through an ELB instance.

664
00:31:31.180 --> 00:31:32.360
So, hopefully we'll see you there.

665
00:31:32.360 --> 00:31:35.220
As for this episode,
we're gonna go ahead and close it down.

00:31:35.220 --> 00:31:38.040
Signing off for ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don dive into Amazon's fault tolerance service known as Elastic Load Balancing. First they go over the basics of ELB, both the abilities and limitations, then they move on to the different types of ELB available (Public and Private types). They also take a look at implementing Health-checks with ELB.

Excited to be back and

I know we got the whole

00:00:45.750 --> 00:00:48.460
So I'd definitely want to go through that
and just kind of get a chance to see some

of the other little nuts and

16

>> Yeah.
I'm actually pretty interested about

00:00:53.780 --> 00:00:57.780
this because when we were working on
the other show you were saying that

elastic low balancers are basically,

I need it here and you kind of just

But you said that they handle it.

We don't go in and settle the settings.

Is set up for getting Amazon handles that.

23
00:01:13.600 --> 00:01:16.495
So I'll be interested in
seeing what else is left.

24
00:01:16.495 --> 00:01:18.290
[LAUGH] What else is left?

25
00:01:18.290 --> 00:01:20.590
>> And the ELB as we deployed
it in the last episode,

26
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:22.370
is probably gonna be fine for most people.

27
00:01:22.370 --> 00:01:23.230
All right?

28
00:01:23.230 --> 00:01:26.010
But there are a few scenarios where
we might need to go in there and

29
00:01:26.010 --> 00:01:27.270
tweak it's behavior a little bit.

30
00:01:27.270 --> 00:01:30.110
And, unfortunately, in some of these
scenarios, you can't tweak it yourself.

31
00:01:30.110 --> 00:01:32.290
And there's a great example
that I wanna talk about,

32
00:01:32.290 --> 00:01:34.450
what's called pre-warming in ELB.

33
00:01:34.450 --> 00:01:35.480
All right?

34
00:01:35.480 --> 00:01:38.130
Now, when you create an elastic
load balancer, what's going on is,

35
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:40.560
on the back end Amazon is
creating a Linux server.

36
00:01:40.560 --> 00:01:42.370
They're spinning up this
instance that's running.

37
00:01:42.370 --> 00:01:43.560
Kinda like when you configure your nat,

38
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:46.078
they're actually spinning up
a Linux installs in that router.

39
00:01:46.078 --> 00:01:47.570
Here they're spinning up in the ELB.

40
00:01:47.570 --> 00:01:49.950
I'm glad that I mentioned that.

41
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:53.150
I know there's some confusion out
there where some people will say,

42
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:56.150
is the ELB like a replacement for nat?

43
00:01:56.150 --> 00:01:59.740
Right, cuz if I nat more than one
host behind a single IP then isn't

44
00:01:59.740 --> 00:02:03.320
that kind of like an ELB and they're
really two different things, right.

45
00:02:03.320 --> 00:02:07.520
Nat is were we mask our internal ips
behind a single external ip on their way

46
00:02:07.520 --> 00:02:08.620
out of a network.

47
00:02:08.620 --> 00:02:11.490
On the way into the network, and
that really just screws things up and

48
00:02:11.490 --> 00:02:13.940
you have to do port redirections and
all that mess.

49
00:02:13.940 --> 00:02:17.790
And ELB, on the other hand, is not really
designed for inside going out, it's

50
00:02:17.790 --> 00:02:21.650
designed for outside coming in, and then
we can distribute people across systems.

51
00:02:21.650 --> 00:02:25.340
And, so you might even use the two
together, you might have ELB and NAT, but

52
00:02:25.340 --> 00:02:28.700
one is not a replacement for the other,
so make sure you don't mix those two up.

53
00:02:28.700 --> 00:02:33.360
But basically, when we configure that ELB,
Amazon creates that instance.

54
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:35.590
That Linux server that's gonna be
the balancing, they spin it up and

55
00:02:35.590 --> 00:02:38.180
it's got all of their
default configuration on it.

56
00:02:38.180 --> 00:02:42.740
Now, Amazon spins up tens of
thousands of ELB's in any given day.

57
00:02:42.740 --> 00:02:46.270
And they don't want to waste a ton of
resources on these because their build

58
00:02:46.270 --> 00:02:48.500
a lot less expensively then an instance.

59
00:02:48.500 --> 00:02:52.410
If you brought up an instance itself to be
an ELB you'd end up paying a lot more for

60
00:02:52.410 --> 00:02:53.430
it, right?

61
00:02:53.430 --> 00:02:57.730
And so what they do is they spin down
the amount of RAM in that system.

62
00:02:57.730 --> 00:03:02.430
They spin down the amount of CPU to match
the load of traffic that you've got.

63
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:06.520
So I might have an ELB with

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the monitoring services available for AWS users that are employing Elastic Load Balancing. Here they go over basic monitoring as well as the advanced monitoring features in CloudWatch. They also walk you through some of the error codes you may encounter when monitoring an ELB instance.

00:16:18.980 --> 00:16:23.250

00:16:23.250 --> 00:16:26.870

00:16:57.830 --> 00:17:00.230

00:17:00.230 --> 00:17:01.760

00:17:16.410 --> 00:17:17.764

00:17:21.560 --> 00:17:24.110

00:17:24.110 --> 00:17:25.790

00:17:25.790 --> 00:17:30.760

00:17:30.760 --> 00:17:31.640

00:17:31.640 --> 00:17:35.330

00:17:35.330 --> 00:17:37.020

00:17:38.070 --> 00:17:42.720

00:17:46.470 --> 00:17:49.070

00:17:52.010 --> 00:17:55.120

00:17:55.120 --> 00:17:56.540

00:17:56.540 --> 00:17:59.920

00:17:59.920 --> 00:18:00.780

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore redundancy features in the Domain Name Service(DNS) system, Route 53. They start with a Route 53, DNS overview; explaining DNS zones and record sets (A/CNAME/MX/etc.). They then move into providing DNS redundancy through Route 53 Routing Policies. Here they cover routing policies like Simple, Round-Robin policies as well as Weighted policies that allow you to handle DNS traffic through setting custom priorities.

00:27:37.085 --> 00:27:41.320
And I'm going to paste in the address
of one of my other servers.

600
00:27:41.320 --> 00:27:45.965
Here's the one from Oregon and
I'll throw that one in here.

601
00:27:45.965 --> 00:27:48.835
And I guess I could tack Ireland on this
one cause their going to have the same

602
00:27:48.835 --> 00:27:51.403
weight but I'll add it separate just so
I can do a different set ID.

603
00:27:51.403 --> 00:27:56.425
And then I come down here and I'll say
that this ones going to be weighted and

604
00:27:56.425 --> 00:27:59.150
in the weight I'll set this one to 25.

605
00:27:59.150 --> 00:28:03.320
And I'll give it the US-West name just so
I can remember, and I'll create that one.

606
00:28:03.320 --> 00:28:07.520
And see how it didn't complain, like,
you've got a record with the same name.

607
00:28:07.520 --> 00:28:09.960
If these were a records
it would have complained.

608
00:28:09.960 --> 00:28:13.702
It would have said no you can't do that or
a records on a simple routing policy, but

609
00:28:13.702 --> 00:28:17.080
because I set the weighted routing
policy it allows me to duplicate that.

610
00:28:17.080 --> 00:28:20.650
And then I can add in my third one
which again I'll just called weighted.

611
00:28:20.650 --> 00:28:23.300
I hope I'm spelling right.

612
00:28:23.300 --> 00:28:23.857
Okay.
And

613
00:28:23.857 --> 00:28:26.410
I might have said a lower
tt on the other one.

614
00:28:26.410 --> 00:28:27.010
I've forgotten.

615
00:28:27.010 --> 00:28:29.070
I'll just leave it I guess.

616
00:28:29.070 --> 00:28:32.600
Nothing like good dedicated
attention to detail here.

617
00:28:32.600 --> 00:28:36.790
So we go in and
set this other one to be weighted 25 and

618
00:28:36.790 --> 00:28:39.585
this one's going to be EU-West and

619
00:28:39.585 --> 00:28:44.510
I guess I'll probably need to put
in an IP address on this one.

620
00:28:44.510 --> 00:28:47.576
So I'll go get my IP from Ireland and
I'll throw that one in too.

621
00:28:47.576 --> 00:28:51.738
Okay, now once I've got that
I created the records and

622
00:28:51.738 --> 00:28:56.261
now I can see that I've got three
records in here that are all

623
00:28:56.261 --> 00:29:00.264
weighted.itprotv.net and
if I scroll over here.

624
00:29:00.264 --> 00:29:01.607
Here's the weights.

625
00:29:01.607 --> 00:29:03.325
And my head's covering it.

626
00:29:03.325 --> 00:29:05.110
Can we get rid of my head for a second?

627
00:29:05.110 --> 00:29:06.746
So if we look, you'll see right here.

628
00:29:06.746 --> 00:29:09.393
eu-west, us-virginia, us-west.

629
00:29:09.393 --> 00:29:11.626
There's those set IDs,
which are really useful for

630
00:29:11.626 --> 00:29:13.717
us if we're trying to
figure out which is which.

631
00:29:13.717 --> 00:29:17.040
I can see that us-virginia's gonna
be getting 50% of my traffic.

632
00:29:17.040 --> 00:29:19.510
And then 25 and 25 to the other guys.

633
00:29:19.510 --> 00:29:23.143
So that's kinda weighted being put in
place, and I did leave my TTLs at 300 for

634
00:29:23.143 --> 00:29:24.112
all of them, right.

635
00:29:24.112 --> 00:29:28.845
And now if I start doing DNS lookups for
this, well,

636
00:29:28.845 --> 00:29:34.775
I can come down here and
do a lookup for weighted.itprotv.net.

637
00:29:34.775 --> 00:29:36.931
And when I do that lookup,

638
00:29:36.931 --> 00:29:41.840
remember with round robin how
I got all three address back.

639
00:29:41.840 --> 00:29:42.751
Here, I only get one address.

640
00:29:42.751 --> 00:29:46.796
And that's because it said,
50% of the traffic is gonna go to this IP.

641
00:29:46.796 --> 00:29:47.957
50% of the lookups.

642
00:29:47.957 --> 00:29:49.699
And so I'm gonna poll that IP.

643
00:29:49.699 --> 00:29:53.553
206, which I assume is us-east.

644
00:29:53.553 --> 00:29:54.900
And so it's gonna give me that IP.

645
00:29:54.900 --> 00:29:57.546
Another person might do that lookup and
get a different one.

646
00:29:57.546 --> 00:30:00.666
As you see, I ran it again and
I got it a different one, and so

647
00:30:00.666 --> 00:30:02.927
it's balancing me across the other ones.

648
00:30:02.927 --> 00:30:07.948
I'm getting balanced and laid across
those and if I fire up the actual,

649
00:30:07.948 --> 00:30:11.880
if I actually browse to the page,
well that's not it.

650
00:30:11.880 --> 00:30:12.530
Where's the page?

651
00:30:12.530 --> 00:30:14.010
Here.

652
00:30:14.010 --> 00:30:18.968
So if I fire up the actual page and
try and browse to weighted.itprotv.net,

653
00:30:18.968 --> 00:30:24.153
I created this little sample page that it
would tell me and see how when I get here,

654
00:30:24.153 --> 00:30:28.216
I can see the ip that I'm connected to and
it says compute-1.

655
00:30:28.216 --> 00:30:29.980
Compute-1 is the us-east data center.

656
00:30:29.980 --> 00:30:32.600
That's the one in Virginia.

657
00:30:32.600 --> 00:30:35.530
So I'm connected to that, that was
the very first one that Amazon made.

658
00:30:35.530 --> 00:30:37.460
The other ones actually named
a little more appropriately.

659
00:30:37.460 --> 00:30:42.279
Now Safari here is going to cache that
DNS lookup and it's going to hold it.

660
00:30:42.279 --> 00:30:44.679
I might have to wait 5 minutes
before it does lookup again or

661
00:30:44.679 --> 00:30:47.320
end up somewhere else and
then I'm back on that 206 this time.

662
00:30:47.320 --> 00:30:49.790
So now I got that weighted distribution.

663
00:30:49.790 --> 00:30:52.458
Not really done with it, I'd normally
want to tack on health checks, so

664
00:30:52.458 --> 00:30:54.864
that now if one server goes down,
we stop sending people there but

665
00:30:54.864 --> 00:30:57.210
we'll see health checks when we
start to do the failover side.

666
00:30:57.210 --> 00:30:59.236
Cuz they're really important, but

667
00:30:59.236 --> 00:31:01.860
that would be the next
step to get this one done.

668
00:31:01.860 --> 00:31:06.282
>> Yeah Don, we do have actually quite
a bit more to cover when it comes to and

669
00:31:06.282 --> 00:31:08.817
DNS and
all the cool stuff we can do with it, but

670
00:31:08.817 --> 00:31:11.176
our clock has ticked
down to its last tock.

671
00:31:11.176 --> 00:31:13.080
And this show here has no more time.

672
00:31:13.080 --> 00:31:16.998
So any parting words for
our guest before we move into a part two.

673
00:31:16.998 --> 00:31:20.528

00:31:20.528 --> 00:31:22.942
Which one is the right one for

And so far we've only seen simple and

676
00:31:26.239 --> 00:31:29.953

00:31:29.953 --> 00:31:32.330

00:31:34.716 --> 00:31:37.272

680
00:31:37.272 --> 00:31:38.291
definitely tune in for those.

681
00:31:38.291 --> 00:31:39.963
>> Awesome, thank you so

00:31:39.963 --> 00:31:41.449
And thank you for watching.

683
00:31:41.449 --> 00:31:42.842
Hopefully we'll see you in part two.

684
00:31:42.842 --> 00:31:45.907
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue exploring Route 53 Routing Policies, this time looking at the Latency and Geolocation Routing Policies which allow you to direct DNS traffic based on speed and distance respectfully. They also show you how to set up health-checks which verify the operating status of your systems. Health-checks also integrate with certain types of Routing Policies.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.277 --> 00:00:16.057
All right, greetings everyone, welcome
to another great episode of ITPro TV,

3
00:00:16.057 --> 00:00:20.906
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in this
episode we're continuing on with a little

4
00:00:20.906 --> 00:00:25.573
more of that AWS SysOps Certified
Administrator Certification from Amazon.

5
00:00:25.573 --> 00:00:30.556
And again back with us here in the studio
to help weed us through that little bit

6
00:00:30.556 --> 00:00:33.635
of a jungle is none other than,
Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:33.635 --> 00:00:34.523
How's it going today Don?

8
00:00:34.523 --> 00:00:37.045
>> It is going great Dan,
I'm glad to be back on the show and

9
00:00:37.045 --> 00:00:38.810
ready to continue on with route 53.

10
00:00:38.810 --> 00:00:44.080
You'll remember in the last episode we
got a chance to see how to do some simple

11
00:00:44.080 --> 00:00:44.610
record sets.

12
00:00:44.610 --> 00:00:46.670
Just regular A record type things.

13
00:00:46.670 --> 00:00:49.889
We also got a chance to see how
to do weighted record sets.

14
00:00:49.889 --> 00:00:52.466
And DNS round robin so
a couple of neat little features for

15
00:00:52.466 --> 00:00:55.741
doing a bit of redundancy, a bit of
distribution inside of Route 53 and

16
00:00:55.741 --> 00:00:58.231
we're going to continue on
with that in this episode.

17
00:00:58.231 --> 00:01:02.851
>> Now Don I know you want to get on to
the other routing policies that we have

18
00:01:02.851 --> 00:01:03.395
there.

19
00:01:03.395 --> 00:01:07.454
But I was really intrigued and since
it's my show and I'm a little selfish,

20
00:01:07.454 --> 00:01:10.637
I want you to expound on this for
me, was the health checks.

21
00:01:10.637 --> 00:01:13.937
I thought that looked really interesting
and it seems to be an integral part of

22
00:01:13.937 --> 00:01:16.397
this type of operation, so
can you help us out with that?

23
00:01:16.397 --> 00:01:17.540
Show us a little bit of that?

24
00:01:17.540 --> 00:01:21.058
>> Sure if you don't remember or
if you skipped the other episode,

25
00:01:21.058 --> 00:01:23.824
one of the things I did was when
I set up DNS round robbining

26
00:01:23.824 --> 00:01:27.284
it was rotating between three IPs and
if one of those servers went down,

27
00:01:27.284 --> 00:01:30.477
I said it's still gonna send a third
of your people to that bad IP.

28
00:01:30.477 --> 00:01:34.179
When we configured weighted as our route
policy it gave us the option to tie it to

29
00:01:34.179 --> 00:01:38.277
a health check and health check is awesome
because that's where route 53 is checking

30
00:01:38.277 --> 00:01:40.598
to see whether that server
is actually working.

31
00:01:40.598 --> 00:01:43.412
And if it is working it'll
keep sending traffic to it,

32
00:01:43.412 --> 00:01:46.852
but if the server stops working it
will stop sending traffic to it.

33
00:01:46.852 --> 00:01:50.404
It's a great way to take that
bad server out of the pool and

34
00:01:50.404 --> 00:01:53.003
overcome the limitation of round robin.

35
00:01:53.003 --> 00:01:55.707
Now you can still do round robin with
weighted, you just give all the servers

36
00:01:55.707 --> 00:01:58.490
equal weight, and
now it's basically gonna round robin.

37
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:01.993
But the ability to do health checks
is where that extra power comes in.

38
00:02:01.993 --> 00:02:03.832
So let's see how these health checks work.

39
00:02:03.832 --> 00:02:08.408
So I'm gonna jump into my Amazon dashboard
here, and if I get get back to my console,

40
00:02:08.408 --> 00:02:10.220
I'll just dive into Route 53.

41
00:02:10.220 --> 00:02:14.173
And on the main Route 53 dashboard,
you'll see your hosted zones, and

42
00:02:14.173 --> 00:02:15.335
your health checks.

43
00:02:15.335 --> 00:02:16.635
And I don't currently have any.

44
00:02:16.635 --> 00:02:18.957
So I'm gonna create a health check.

45
00:02:18.957 --> 00:02:22.847
And a health check is basically telling
it how to determine whether the server is

46
00:02:22.847 --> 00:02:23.376
up or not.

47
00:02:23.376 --> 00:02:26.567
And what it's actually doing is in
the background it's using Cloud Watch.

48
00:02:26.567 --> 00:02:30.001
So we're really setting up basic
Amazon Cloud watch services, but

49
00:02:30.001 --> 00:02:34.098
it's not a replacement for Cloud Watch
because Cloud Watch can monitor all sorts

50
00:02:34.098 --> 00:02:37.410
of great stuff such as performance,
here it's really limited,

51
00:02:37.410 --> 00:02:39.665
we're just trying to
see if it works right.

52
00:02:39.665 --> 00:02:41.981
The server can be really slow,
we don't care about that,

53
00:02:41.981 --> 00:02:44.171
we just need to make sure
it's actually functioning.

54
00:02:44.171 --> 00:02:47.759
So when I go to create a health check,
I need to give it a name and

55
00:02:47.759 --> 00:02:49.837
I'm gonna tell it what to monitor.

56
00:02:49.837 --> 00:02:52.128
And I can tell it to monitor
the end point itself, or

57
00:02:52.128 --> 00:02:55.609
to monitor some other health check that
I might have made over in Cloud Watch.

58
00:02:55.609 --> 00:02:58.060
So you can kind of tie to together
if you wanna get really advanced.

59
00:02:58.060 --> 00:02:59.690
Now, notice this little
informational blurb.

60
00:02:59.690 --> 00:03:04.171
If we monitor the endpoint, it's actually
covered by the free usage tier in AWS.

61
00:03:04.171 --> 00:03:06.394
If we choose to monitor another check,
well,

62
00:03:06.394 --> 00:03:08.788
now we start to move beyond
the free usage tier, so

63
00:03:08.788 --> 00:03:12.838
the advanced stuff does cost a little bit,
but it's actually really inexpensive.

64
00:03:12.838 --> 00:03:17.069
We need to give the health check a name,
and then we tell it what we're going

65
00:03:17.069 --> 00:03:20.574
to be monitoring and
you'll notice the IP address is needed.

66
00:03:20.574 --> 00:03:24.513
I've got multiple servers so I'm going
to need to create a health check for

67
00:03:24.513 --> 00:03:28.139
each one to be able to keep tabs on
whether or not it's functioning and

68
00:03:28.139 --> 00:03:30.974
you can monitor it by an IP address or
by a domain name.

69
00:03:30.974 --> 00:03:34.116
When you're doing things like
a shared DNS entry, you don't want

70
00:03:34.116 --> 00:03:37.611
to monitor the shared DNS entry cuz
you'd be monitoring all the servers.

71
00:03:37.611 --> 00:03:40.101
You need to monitor the individual nodes.

72
00:03:40.101 --> 00:03:43.702
So I may come in here and say I'm
gonna create this first one for my.

73
00:03:43.702 --> 00:03:47.604
This'll be my US-EAST server
that I'm gonna monitor.

74
00:03:47.604 --> 00:03:52.789
And I'm going to monitor that particular
end point and its HTTP, it's a web server,

75
00:03:52.789 --> 00:03:57.541
and I need the IP address to that server
which I have right here so I'll choose to

76
00:03:57.541 --> 00:04:02.032
monitor that and I'll punch in an IP or
I could do that host name if I had it.

77
00:04:02.032 --> 00:04:02.989
I'm going to leave that empty.

78
00:04:02.989 --> 00:04:07.960
I'm going to monitor on port 80 and
I'm going to look for index.PHP, right?

79
00:04:07.960 --> 00:04:09.686
That's my main index file.

80
00:04:09.686 --> 00:04:13.902
If I can resolve that file,
then the server must be up, right?

81
00:04:13.902 --> 00:04:15.530
If I can't resolve that file,
then it's not.

82
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:16.560
Now that's a pretty basic check.

83
00:04:16.560 --> 00:04:19.259
You'll see where you can do HTTPS or
even TCP.

84
00:04:19.259 --> 00:04:20.769
If you've got like a database server,

85
00:04:20.769 --> 00:04:23.852
you might choose to do a TCP connection to
see if you can connect to the database.

86
00:04:23.852 --> 00:04:25.402
But it's not a very advanced check.

87
00:04:25.402 --> 00:04:27.639
It's not saying can I query this table?

88
00:04:27.639 --> 00:04:28.986
Can I run this application?

89
00:04:28.986 --> 00:04:31.911
It's just saying if I go to this
page do I get something back?

90
00:04:31.911 --> 00:04:32.569
Right?

91
00:04:32.569 --> 00:04:35.748
So if you want something more advanced
that's where you kind of have to go to

92
00:04:35.748 --> 00:04:38.579
Cloud Watch and that's why it gets
you out of that free usage tier.

93
00:04:38.579 --> 00:04:41.497
So I'm just going to monitor to
see if I can get to that page and

94
00:04:41.497 --> 00:04:42.537
if I can't, great.

95
00:04:42.537 --> 00:04:43.193
All right?

96
00:04:43.193 --> 00:04:46.863
If I already had other healthchecks I
could choose that and you can see where I

97
00:04:46.863 --> 00:04:50.647
start to pick other healthchecks that I
might have and I get nothing when I click

98
00:04:50.647 --> 00:04:54.545
on that because I don't have any other
healthchecks in Cloud Watch or whatever so

99
00:04:54.545 --> 00:04:57.380
I'll flip back to endpoint and
just kind of run with that.

100
00:04:57.380 --> 00:05:00.425
So this is a basic health check,
no additional charges, and

101
00:05:00.425 --> 00:05:01.510
I'll just hit Next.

102
00:05:01.510 --> 00:05:03.718
Then it's gonna say,
what do I do if there's an alarm?

103
00:05:03.718 --> 00:05:08.070
Now, it's got whether I wanna create an
alarm when it fails, and I can choose no.

104
00:05:08.070 --> 00:05:10.680
Why wouldn't I wanna create an alarm?

105
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:13.491
Well, I might not actually care that it
failed, I just wanna take it out of DNS,

106
00:05:13.491 --> 00:05:15.760
right, so I wouldn't necessarily
I have an alarm, but

107
00:05:15.760 --> 00:05:17.600
if I say yes I can choose
to create that and

108
00:05:17.600 --> 00:05:20.750
tell it to send me an email and
it'll fire off an email to me if I want.

109
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:24.717
I'm not gonna create an alarm for
mine, and I'll create that check.

110
00:05:24.717 --> 00:05:28.584
Now that check is created for
my US East server, I want to continue and

111
00:05:28.584 --> 00:05:31.801
create these from my other
servers to check for them too.

112
00:05:31.801 --> 00:05:34.913
So I would need to do my US West and
my other one.

113
00:05:34.913 --> 00:05:38.609
So I'll just kinda whip through
here real quick and do US West,

114
00:05:38.609 --> 00:05:40.017
monitor the endpoint.

115
00:05:40.017 --> 00:05:43.250
Punch in that IP and look for INDEX.PHP.

116
00:05:43.250 --> 00:05:46.926
So pretty simple,
if not a little on the repetitive side.

117
00:05:46.926 --> 00:05:51.361
So, we'll get that one created and
my last one was EU-WEST.

118
00:05:51.361 --> 00:05:53.502
My server that's over in Ireland.

119
00:05:53.502 --> 00:05:55.420
And so I'll come in here and grab its IP.

120
00:05:55.420 --> 00:06:00.454
Keep in mind, you hope,
that you're using elastic IP's,

121
00:06:00.454 --> 00:06:03.327
the static IP's for these nodes.

122
00:06:03.327 --> 00:06:05.848
Or these are load balancer
IPs that you're monitoring.

123
00:06:05.848 --> 00:06:08.711
If you're monitoring a dynamic IP and
the IP changes,

124
00:06:08.711 --> 00:06:10.710
it'll cause a health check failure.

125
00:06:10.710 --> 00:06:11.825
So remember that.

126
00:06:11.825 --> 00:06:13.523
All right, so we'll punch that in.

127
00:06:13.523 --> 00:06:15.030
And there's my last check.

128
00:06:15.030 --> 00:06:16.649
And so,
now I've got my three health checks.

129
00:06:16.649 --> 00:06:19.623
Now notice their status is unknown,
I have to wait.

130
00:06:19.623 --> 00:06:21.937
It is going to query out to those
systems and check them, but

131
00:06:21.937 --> 00:06:23.568
it's not the fastest thing in the world.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at AWS Relational Database Service (RDS) redundancy features. They begin by covering the basics of RDS and explaining the different databases available. Then they show you the ways to enable redundancy for your databases. This includes using the setup wizard during the database creation, as well as methods for making already running databases redundant.

00:08:38.160 --> 00:08:41.640
I'd just say yes, and

00:08:41.640 --> 00:08:45.260
I'm gonna create a redundant environment

I think I did DB4 a second ago,

00:08:53.680 --> 00:08:56.560

an accounting database and

it's gonna create the primary first,

00:09:19.232 --> 00:09:21.697
then it's gonna create the standby.

Then it's gonna configure replication for
me, then it's gonna sync it all up.

193
00:09:26.990 --> 00:09:27.800
And once it's done,

194
00:09:27.800 --> 00:09:33.100
I'm gonna end up with a redundant
database, just like that, right?

195
00:09:33.100 --> 00:09:37.640
And I didn't have to understand all the

196

And what's even better is they map one

197
00:09:43.630 --> 00:09:48.230
And if there's a failure, it'll
automatically repoint that to the standby.

198
00:09:48.230 --> 00:09:51.600
I don't even have to do the failover,
it takes care of it for me.

199
00:09:51.600 --> 00:09:55.450
And all my applications, as long as
I point them to that one endpoint,

00:09:55.450 --> 00:09:57.580
then they're always gonna
get either the primary or

the standby depending on which one
has gone active at that given time.

202
00:10:00.570 --> 00:10:03.490
It's the easiest kind of
redundancy you can set up.

00:10:03.490 --> 00:10:06.290
Especially when you consider on

So for example, if I do MySQL or

00:10:13.500 --> 00:10:15.490

00:10:15.490 --> 00:10:18.790
So if I pick any of those

00:10:18.790 --> 00:10:21.900
Amazon is whipping up a primary and

00:10:28.970 --> 00:10:31.120
