00:34:43.960 --> 00:34:48.750
So, the active status here, it went to
running setup for a few moments and

704
00:34:48.750 --> 00:34:49.650
then it switched to online.

705
00:34:49.650 --> 00:34:52.930
So, I've got one app that's active,
or one instance that's active now.

706
00:34:52.930 --> 00:34:56.820
So, I can go to my app and
in my app I can choose to deploy.

707
00:34:56.820 --> 00:34:59.710
And when you deploy it,

708
00:34:59.710 --> 00:35:02.660
right here it's telling me OpsWorks will
run this command on 1 of 2 instances.

709
00:35:02.660 --> 00:35:03.770
The one that's online.

710
00:35:03.770 --> 00:35:06.940
But you can actually pick and choose and
say, like, I don't wanna run on this guy,

711
00:35:06.940 --> 00:35:08.270
or I do wanna run on this one.

712
00:35:08.270 --> 00:35:10.210
So you've got a little
bit of flexibility there.

713
00:35:10.210 --> 00:35:10.780
Right?

714
00:35:10.780 --> 00:35:11.930
And whoops.

715
00:35:11.930 --> 00:35:13.100
I'm going into Custom JSON.

716
00:35:13.100 --> 00:35:15.180
That's not what I wanted to do.

717
00:35:15.180 --> 00:35:17.670
So once we've got that,
you can just hit Deploy.

718
00:35:17.670 --> 00:35:20.520
And when we hit Deploy.

719
00:35:20.520 --> 00:35:25.759
It's gonna reach out to GitHub, it's
gonna get a copy of my little PHP app and

720
00:35:25.759 --> 00:35:28.440
it's gonna install it on php-app1.

721
00:35:28.440 --> 00:35:30.040
And that's what it's doing right now,
is installing.

722
00:35:30.040 --> 00:35:32.600
The bigger your app is
the longer this'll take.

723
00:35:32.600 --> 00:35:35.560
Mine is, I think, 4k in size.

724
00:35:35.560 --> 00:35:37.040
It's like really, really tiny.

725
00:35:37.040 --> 00:35:40.424
So, mine should happen pretty quick,
but once this deployed,

726
00:35:40.424 --> 00:35:42.867
we should be able to
browse to that server, and

727
00:35:42.867 --> 00:35:46.340
see this web page come back for
us and have access to that web app.

728
00:35:46.340 --> 00:35:49.070
So, we'll give that a second
while it deploys it.

729
00:35:49.070 --> 00:35:52.660
Now, the cool part here is that it's
reaching out to GitHub to get my app.

730
00:35:52.660 --> 00:35:56.230
So, if I've committed new changes,
it's automatically got them and

731
00:35:56.230 --> 00:35:59.110
it's ready to deploy, and I can manage
it in software that I'm already using.

732
00:35:59.110 --> 00:36:00.730
Right, you may not be using GitHub.

733
00:36:00.730 --> 00:36:03.710
So, you might point this to a URL in
your own system and that's fine, too.

734
00:36:03.710 --> 00:36:05.055
There we go, yep, so the host name.

735
00:36:05.055 --> 00:36:07.490
It's got a little green checkmark
right there letting me know that it

736
00:36:07.490 --> 00:36:08.198
finished the deployment.

737
00:36:08.198 --> 00:36:09.500
It was successful.

738
00:36:09.500 --> 00:36:14.860
And, it should be good to go,
as far as I know.

739
00:36:14.860 --> 00:36:17.650
And I can't really think of
anything too crazy there.

740
00:36:17.650 --> 00:36:20.998
I'm just gonna scroll down here to
the Public DNS for this server, and

741
00:36:20.998 --> 00:36:22.090
I'm gonna copy that.

742
00:36:24.750 --> 00:36:27.745
And when I browse to it,
instead of seeing the Apache homepage,

743
00:36:27.745 --> 00:36:30.940
like I would of on a normal one,
we see my test page that I made.

744
00:36:30.940 --> 00:36:32.270
And so it's telling me,

745
00:36:32.270 --> 00:36:34.960
here is the name of that instance cuz I
didn't know the name of the instance.

746
00:36:34.960 --> 00:36:36.110
I hadn't seen it before.

747
00:36:36.110 --> 00:36:36.690
But there it is,

748
00:36:36.690 --> 00:36:40.780
it's up, it's running and it tells me that
Apache is happy and serving up web pages.

749
00:36:40.780 --> 00:36:42.710
There's my web app, all deployed.

750
00:36:42.710 --> 00:36:47.000
And the best part about that,
I never SSH'd into the instance.

751
00:36:47.000 --> 00:36:48.730
I never logged in
the instance a single time.

752
00:36:48.730 --> 00:36:52.160
But I just deployed my application,
potentially on top of a very complexive

753
00:36:52.160 --> 00:36:54.480
environment, without having to
mess with those components.

754
00:36:54.480 --> 00:36:55.980
That's what OpsWork is all about.

755
00:36:55.980 --> 00:36:57.950
That's what Elastic Beanstalk
is all about.

756
00:36:57.950 --> 00:37:00.470
That's what, to a lesser extent,
cloud formation is all about.

757
00:37:00.470 --> 00:37:03.220
It's kinda up to you which
tool is gonna suit your needs.

758
00:37:03.220 --> 00:37:05.610
But, OpsWorks is really the one
they want you to move to.

759
00:37:05.610 --> 00:37:08.910
>> Well, it's obviously a very awesome,
powerful and robust tool.

760
00:37:08.910 --> 00:37:12.810
So, it would definitely benefit
us to learn how to use it and

761
00:37:12.810 --> 00:37:14.200
take advantage of it in our environments.

762
00:37:14.200 --> 00:37:17.630
Don is there anything else that you wanna
add to this before we close the show?

763
00:37:17.630 --> 00:37:19.460
>> I think I've dragged this
one out long enough waiting for

764
00:37:19.460 --> 00:37:21.930
that one deployment to happen,
sorry about that guys.

765
00:37:21.930 --> 00:37:24.320
But it's rolled out,
you got a chance to see how it works.

766
00:37:24.320 --> 00:37:27.340
On the exam, they're not gonna ask you
to deploy something with OpsWorks.

767
00:37:27.340 --> 00:37:29.770
But, I wanted you to see how
that works to understand it.

768
00:37:29.770 --> 00:37:32.235
Because they are gonna
ask you how it works.

769
00:37:32.235 --> 00:37:33.020
You need to understand that.

770
00:37:33.020 --> 00:37:35.840
And you need to remember that
terminology about stacks and layers.

771
00:37:35.840 --> 00:37:39.470
You need to understand about chef being
under the hood and what a recipe is.

772
00:37:39.470 --> 00:37:40.531
You need to know those concepts.

773
00:37:40.531 --> 00:37:43.471
And so we got a chance to see it here,
kinda from start to finish,

774
00:37:43.471 --> 00:37:45.491
how to deploy that And
get it up and running.

775
00:37:45.491 --> 00:37:47.323
It's really cool stuff,
if you're not using it yet

776
00:37:47.323 --> 00:37:48.810
you should take advantage of it.

777
00:37:48.810 --> 00:37:51.270
>> Well, thank you so much, Don,
for explaining that for us.

778
00:37:51.270 --> 00:37:54.680
Now, we have a little better grasp
of those concepts and terms.

779
00:37:54.680 --> 00:37:56.750
As for the show, though,
we're gonna go ahead and close her down.

780
00:37:56.750 --> 00:37:57.770
Thanks for watching.

781
00:37:57.770 --> 00:38:00.890
And signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

782
00:38:00.890 --> 00:38:01.520
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

783
00:38:01.520 --> 00:38:02.675
>> And we'll see you next time.

784
00:38:02.675 --> 00:38:09.190
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel take you through a tour of the backup and recovery services provided by the many AWS services. They start by explaining Disaster Recovery concepts like Recovery Time Objective(RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) and what is involved with traditional DR. Then they look at AWSs DR solutions like Regions, S3, Glacier, EBS, and AWS Storage Gateway.
episodes.title: Backup and Recovery Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:10.008
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.966 --> 00:00:13.655
>> All right, greetings, everyone.

3
00:00:13.655 --> 00:00:16.395
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.395 --> 00:00:19.105
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

5
00:00:19.105 --> 00:00:23.755
we're continuing on our series of
the AWS Certified Sysops Admin.

6
00:00:23.755 --> 00:00:26.492
Joining me yet again today is
none other than my good friend,

7
00:00:26.492 --> 00:00:30.952
my colleague, and happens to be
my boss as well, Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.952 --> 00:00:32.132
How's it going today, Don?

9
00:00:32.132 --> 00:00:33.112
>> It is going great, Daniel.

10
00:00:33.112 --> 00:00:34.162
Glad to be back on this show.

11
00:00:34.162 --> 00:00:35.892
And we're kicking off a new section here.

12
00:00:35.892 --> 00:00:38.242
And we're jumping into backup and
recovery services.

13
00:00:38.242 --> 00:00:42.132
So what I want to do for
our first episode on this is to

14
00:00:42.132 --> 00:00:46.332
focus in on any one particular service,
but instead take a look at the whole,

15
00:00:46.332 --> 00:00:50.630
what should we call it,
the backup portfolio from AWS.

16
00:00:50.630 --> 00:00:53.440
On the exam, they really expect
you to know how to back up and

17
00:00:53.440 --> 00:00:55.280
restore EC2 instances.

18
00:00:55.280 --> 00:00:58.940
And they expect you to know how
to back up and restore RDS, so

19
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:01.330
the relational databases,
especially MySQL, right.

20
00:01:01.330 --> 00:01:03.090
Those are the two they really hit on.

21
00:01:03.090 --> 00:01:07.270
But all the other services, they want
you to be familiar with the options.

22
00:01:07.270 --> 00:01:08.110
What's available.

23
00:01:08.110 --> 00:01:09.420
You don't necessarily have
to know how to do it,

24
00:01:09.420 --> 00:01:12.110
just know what options
are available inside of AWS.

25
00:01:12.110 --> 00:01:14.710
And it's pretty impressive, all
the different things that are available.

26
00:01:14.710 --> 00:01:17.580
It's a big system, it's very redundant,

27
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:20.500
tons of cool features, some of them
we just have to remember to turn on.

28
00:01:20.500 --> 00:01:22.560
And once it's on, we get a nice,
stable environment.

29
00:01:22.560 --> 00:01:26.400
>> Now, Don, I think a good place to begin
to start with this, since we're talking

30
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:31.910
about backup, is traditional and
just backup topics, and standard

31
00:01:31.910 --> 00:01:35.930
things that we're normally used to dealing
with, before we jump in to see how Amazon.

32
00:01:35.930 --> 00:01:37.470
So let's start there.

33
00:01:37.470 --> 00:01:38.910
>> Sure.
>> Let's cover some of those topics.

34
00:01:38.910 --> 00:01:43.730
>> So, two terms that you're going to see
on the exam, guaranteed, is RTO and RPO,

35
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:44.460
all right?

36
00:01:44.460 --> 00:01:48.480
If you're not familiar with those,
RTO is recovery time objective.

37
00:01:48.480 --> 00:01:51.190
When you have a failure
a server goes offline, right?

38
00:01:51.190 --> 00:01:54.480
Now your customers are not able to access
that server, or your own employees are not

39
00:01:54.480 --> 00:01:57.180
able to access that server,
it depends on who it's designed to serve.

40
00:01:57.180 --> 00:01:58.880
It's now offline and it's not functioning.

41
00:01:59.970 --> 00:02:03.840
How long can you allow that to be
down before you have a problem?

42
00:02:03.840 --> 00:02:06.820
Now if you're a small business,
you might have days, weeks.

43
00:02:06.820 --> 00:02:08.860
It might not even matter,
the server goes down you don't care.

44
00:02:08.860 --> 00:02:11.270
So your RTO might be very, very large.

45
00:02:11.270 --> 00:02:15.810
>> But if you are a mission critical type
environment, you're dealing with medical

46
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:20.600
records or financial or whatever, you
might only be able to have a few seconds.

47
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:23.630
So different people have
different objectives here, and

48
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:27.140
when you have a failure, you need
to recover as quickly as possible.

49
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:29.890
The smaller your RTO is,
your recovery time objective,

50
00:02:29.890 --> 00:02:34.250
the smaller that is, the less amount
of downtime you can have, right?

51
00:02:34.250 --> 00:02:38.660
So you'll hear people talk about
shooting for five-nines of downtime or

52
00:02:38.660 --> 00:02:39.505
of availability.

53
00:02:39.505 --> 00:02:42.630
Five-nines means you're
up 99.999% of the time.

54
00:02:42.630 --> 00:02:44.220
And if you work that out,

55
00:02:44.220 --> 00:02:46.880
that works out to just a handful of
seconds per year that you can be down.

56
00:02:46.880 --> 00:02:49.130
How do you keep the system up?

57
00:02:50.360 --> 00:02:52.870
With only a few seconds
of downtime a year.

58
00:02:52.870 --> 00:02:55.540
If it's a Linux box and
I do an update and I need to reboot.

59
00:02:55.540 --> 00:02:57.960
Or a Windows box, I do an update and
I need to reboot.

60
00:02:57.960 --> 00:03:00.220
The reboot's going to take
more than a few seconds and so

61
00:03:00.220 --> 00:03:03.400
now I've blown my five nine's
availability and I have a hit.

62
00:03:03.400 --> 00:03:07.380
Well you can still achieve
it through redundancy.

63
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:08.670
Having not just one server, but

64
00:03:08.670 --> 00:03:12.350
more than one server so that when one
goes offline another one takes over.

65
00:03:12.350 --> 00:03:14.910
And that's very difficult to do
in the traditional model, but

66
00:03:14.910 --> 00:03:16.880
in the virtual model
it's very easy to do and

67
00:03:16.880 --> 00:03:19.880
so maintaining high levels
of availability are easier.

68
00:03:19.880 --> 00:03:20.640
But your RTO,

69
00:03:20.640 --> 00:03:24.130
your recovery time objective,
it's important you know it ahead of time.

70
00:03:24.130 --> 00:03:26.610
You need to know how much
downtime you can have, so

71
00:03:26.610 --> 00:03:28.690
you plan your resources accordingly.

72
00:03:28.690 --> 00:03:31.220
And I'll just give you a little
story here, I used to work for

73
00:03:31.220 --> 00:03:32.270
a bank out in Seattle.

74
00:03:32.270 --> 00:03:36.720
And at the bank, I asked them,
we were implementing a new system,

75
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:38.850
I said what level of redundancy
are we shooting for here?

76
00:03:38.850 --> 00:03:40.210
What up time do we need?

77
00:03:40.210 --> 00:03:43.060
And the CIO said well,
it should always be up.

78
00:03:43.060 --> 00:03:45.200
And I said okay, I can make that.

79
00:03:45.200 --> 00:03:49.010
I can make it where this system
is always up, what's my budget.

80
00:03:49.010 --> 00:03:50.830
And, you know, that's how it works right.

81
00:03:50.830 --> 00:03:53.440
If you want it to always be up you're
gonna need millions of dollars for

82
00:03:53.440 --> 00:03:54.870
the infrastructure to
be able to deploy that.

83
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:59.010
But if that's what you truly need,
then you can do it, right.

84
00:03:59.010 --> 00:04:02.180
And so when I started asking the budget
questions, that's when the conversation

85
00:04:02.180 --> 00:04:05.600
turned to, well how much does it cost for
availability?

86
00:04:05.600 --> 00:04:07.520
And how much can I get by with
this amount, this amount.

87
00:04:07.520 --> 00:04:09.990
And at the end of the day
we reached out to the FDIC.

88
00:04:09.990 --> 00:04:11.650
We were insured through the FDIC.

89
00:04:11.650 --> 00:04:16.190
And they had this rule and it said that
the bank could actually be down for

90
00:04:16.190 --> 00:04:17.984
72 hours down for three days.

91
00:04:17.984 --> 00:04:23.230
And that we weren't backed up in
three days, they would take us over.

92
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:25.560
And they would get it backed
up which really bad for

93
00:04:25.560 --> 00:04:27.352
bank because they don't give it back.

94
00:04:27.352 --> 00:04:31.360
So, [LAUGH] so you know what can happen,
but the reality was in three days.

95
00:04:31.360 --> 00:04:34.321
So if we ever had a failure we
could let the bank be down and

96
00:04:34.321 --> 00:04:38.610
not servicing people's money for three
days, I know it sounds terrible right?

97
00:04:38.610 --> 00:04:39.840
For people out there, right?

98
00:04:39.840 --> 00:04:42.870
But that was our actual true RTO.

99
00:04:42.870 --> 00:04:44.730
So, when we started planning for
back up and

100
00:04:44.730 --> 00:04:48.830
recovery, I didn't need to
be backed up in seconds.

101
00:04:48.830 --> 00:04:51.430
I could have it take minutes or hours or

102
00:04:51.430 --> 00:04:53.950
even days as long as it didn't
take more than three days.

103
00:04:53.950 --> 00:04:56.980
So, as we start to look
at all of the different

104
00:04:56.980 --> 00:04:58.530
resources that are available to us.

105
00:04:58.530 --> 00:04:59.550
Some are amazing.

106
00:04:59.550 --> 00:05:00.410
Some are phenomenal.

107
00:05:00.410 --> 00:05:03.300
Some will stop you from having
even one second of down time.

108
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:04.700
But they won't have a cost
associated with them,

109
00:05:04.700 --> 00:05:06.890
and you don't necessarily
have to incur that.

110
00:05:06.890 --> 00:05:09.720
Now if you're a hospital and
you've got a server that's stored

111
00:05:09.720 --> 00:05:14.220
in the AWS that's responsible for doling
out medication or something like that,

112
00:05:14.220 --> 00:05:17.560
you don't want that to be down even for
a second, and so your RTO is very small.

113
00:05:17.560 --> 00:05:20.930
But we need to understand our recovery
time objective, our RTO, the amount

114
00:05:20.930 --> 00:05:25.542
of downtime that we can handle, before
we plan what recovery we're going to do.

115
00:05:25.542 --> 00:05:26.770
All right?

116
00:05:26.770 --> 00:05:31.930
And right along side of that is the RPO,
recovery point objective.

117
00:05:31.930 --> 00:05:33.840
There very similar so
it's easy to confuse them but

118
00:05:33.840 --> 00:05:38.950
a recovery point objective that's how
much data you can afford to lose, right?

119
00:05:38.950 --> 00:05:39.920
Think about it.

120
00:05:39.920 --> 00:05:43.820
For your company, for your organization,
how much data can you afford to lose?

121
00:05:43.820 --> 00:05:45.590
Let's just think about it for
me personally.

122
00:05:45.590 --> 00:05:47.520
And maybe my email, right?

123
00:05:47.520 --> 00:05:48.800
So I have an email box.

124
00:05:48.800 --> 00:05:52.410
And I get, I don't know,
hundreds of emails a day.

125
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:53.760
It's frustrating sometimes.

126
00:05:53.760 --> 00:05:55.920
But I get a ton of emails a day.

127
00:05:55.920 --> 00:06:02.350
If my mailbox were to fail, how much email
could I lose before I was really upset?

128
00:06:02.350 --> 00:06:06.070
If I lost one day of email would
that be the end of the world?

129
00:06:06.070 --> 00:06:06.930
Probably not.

130
00:06:06.930 --> 00:06:08.290
I could lose a day of email I'd be okay.

131
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:11.470
There's some people who'd wonder
why I wasn't responding to them but

132
00:06:11.470 --> 00:06:13.833
I don't respond to people anyway, so
it's not that big of a deal right?

133
00:06:13.833 --> 00:06:17.490
>> Yeah,I can attest to the fact that
Don does not answer his emails [LAUGH].

134
00:06:17.490 --> 00:06:20.790
>> So with that in mind if I'm not going
to answer them anyway I can afford to lose

135
00:06:20.790 --> 00:06:23.700
a day or a week or a month or
even all of my emails I don't care, right?

136
00:06:23.700 --> 00:06:25.900
But I've got a lot of
important stuff in my mailbox.

137
00:06:25.900 --> 00:06:28.870
And if were to lose more than a few days,
I'd get pretty frustrated.

138
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:33.440
So my RPO my recovery point objective for
my email might be three days.

139
00:06:33.440 --> 00:06:34.140
Right?

140
00:06:34.140 --> 00:06:38.400
But if you are Amazon.com right?

141
00:06:38.400 --> 00:06:42.210
And you are doing retail
transactions every single minute.

142
00:06:42.210 --> 00:06:45.090
Amazon moves over a million dollars

little button right here on the screen.

592
00:27:44.590 --> 00:27:48.950
Now under our storage and content
delivery you'll see storage gateway.

593
00:27:48.950 --> 00:27:53.960
Okay, storage gateway is one of
the coolest features that Amazon has.

594
00:27:53.960 --> 00:27:57.420
One challenge you'll have is that a lot of
organizations are still doing things like

595
00:27:57.420 --> 00:27:58.700
backing up to tape.

596
00:27:58.700 --> 00:28:01.380
Right, and boy is it hard to
get them to go away from tape.

597
00:28:01.380 --> 00:28:03.430
They just love that idea of having tapes,
and

598
00:28:03.430 --> 00:28:05.530
being able to rotate tapes, and get at it.

599
00:28:05.530 --> 00:28:08.940
So when you start talking to them
about pushing data into the cloud,

600
00:28:08.940 --> 00:28:11.110
they get kinda hesitant, right?

601
00:28:11.110 --> 00:28:14.780
For those people,
the Amazon Storage Gateway is amazing.

602
00:28:14.780 --> 00:28:16.580
What it is, is actually a virtual plan.

603
00:28:16.580 --> 00:28:18.180
See how it's telling me to download and

604
00:28:18.180 --> 00:28:22.480
deploy a virtual machine on
a host in my own data center?

605
00:28:22.480 --> 00:28:25.590
Why is Amazon telling me to do
something in my own data center?

606
00:28:25.590 --> 00:28:28.350
What they do is they have a virtual
machine that you can deploy.

607
00:28:28.350 --> 00:28:30.350
So let's say you have like VMWare ESX, or

608
00:28:30.350 --> 00:28:31.750
something like that running
in your environment.

609
00:28:31.750 --> 00:28:36.050
You can deploy this VM and
it creates an iSCSI appliance, and

610
00:28:36.050 --> 00:28:40.120
on your local network it actually
looks like a tape server.

611
00:28:40.120 --> 00:28:45.150
It looks like a tape robot, and
you start backing up to this tape robot.

612
00:28:45.150 --> 00:28:49.980
And it just shows us having constantly
fresh new rotated up tapes.

613
00:28:49.980 --> 00:28:52.910
Every single day it shows us having fresh,
brand new tapes that are all empty,

614
00:28:52.910 --> 00:28:53.820
ready to be backed up onto.

615
00:28:53.820 --> 00:28:55.930
And you start backing up.

616
00:28:55.930 --> 00:28:59.910
And when you back up, what you're
backing up to is what's called a VTL,

617
00:28:59.910 --> 00:29:02.430
a Virtual Tape Library, okay?

618
00:29:02.430 --> 00:29:05.700
And with each virtual tape
instance you provision

619
00:29:05.700 --> 00:29:07.070
it's creating a separate gateway.

620
00:29:07.070 --> 00:29:09.090
So you'd have a list here
of virtual tape gateways.

621
00:29:09.090 --> 00:29:11.930
I don't have any, but
that's what would show up here.

622
00:29:11.930 --> 00:29:15.400
And then with those gateways,
those tapes are really being stored in S3.

623
00:29:15.400 --> 00:29:16.660
We don't see it, it's hidden.

624
00:29:16.660 --> 00:29:18.120
They look like tapes to us.

625
00:29:18.120 --> 00:29:20.640
So maybe use Symantec Backup Exec or

626
00:29:20.640 --> 00:29:25.700
CommVault or IBM's Tivloli, Arcserve,
one of those traditional backup programs.

627
00:29:25.700 --> 00:29:28.930
They just see this is a tape robot and
they start backing-up to it.

628
00:29:28.930 --> 00:29:32.960
And then, here in the UI you can
create what is called a Tape Shelf,

629
00:29:32.960 --> 00:29:37.430
where you take the tapes out of the
library which is like the auto loader and

630
00:29:37.430 --> 00:29:39.940
you move into a shelf which is GLACIER.

631
00:29:39.940 --> 00:29:44.470
So you've got Amazon S3 and
you've got Amazon GLACIER, so now you've

632
00:29:44.470 --> 00:29:47.630
got tapes that are available immediately,
they are in the loader, they are ready.

633
00:29:47.630 --> 00:29:49.150
Right, they're in
the Virtual Tape Library,

634
00:29:49.150 --> 00:29:53.560
and you've got tapes that are in storage
that will take three to five hours to get.

635
00:29:53.560 --> 00:29:56.340
Well, how long is it gonna take me to
call one of those third-party vault

636
00:29:56.340 --> 00:29:59.750
companies to say, I need tape 75, and
they've gotta get it out of the vault,

637
00:29:59.750 --> 00:30:00.680
they've gotta drive it over,

638
00:30:00.680 --> 00:30:03.450
three to five hours is probably right
in line with what that's gonna take.

639
00:30:03.450 --> 00:30:06.640
So, the Virtual Tape Shelf does that,
and it keeps the storage down.

640
00:30:06.640 --> 00:30:10.450
So if you're a tape environment and
you really don't wanna get rid of tapes,

641
00:30:10.450 --> 00:30:13.560
you have this model in place,
you got procedures built to run,

642
00:30:13.560 --> 00:30:15.480
you've got software you've invested in.

643
00:30:15.480 --> 00:30:19.060
This is a great way to leverage S3 and
GLACIER for your storage, but

644
00:30:19.060 --> 00:30:21.110
still keep the tape model, right?

645
00:30:21.110 --> 00:30:24.140
This device up here,
we've got Deploy a new Gateway.

646
00:30:24.140 --> 00:30:26.660
You can choose to deploy a gateway, and

647
00:30:26.660 --> 00:30:28.660
this is where its going to ask
you what kind your gonna do and

648
00:30:28.660 --> 00:30:31.940
what I'm talking about is
the Gateway-Virtual Tape Library and

649
00:30:31.940 --> 00:30:37.050
so it lets you create this virtual machine
that looks like a tape server okay.

650
00:30:37.050 --> 00:30:39.740
That's not the only one you can actually
do these other ones Gateway-Cached

651
00:30:39.740 --> 00:30:42.430
volumes and Gateway-Stored
volumes these are other ones

652
00:30:42.430 --> 00:30:45.630
these don't look like tape libraries all
right these are a little bit different.

653
00:30:45.630 --> 00:30:47.650
The tape library that's
the coolest one I think.

654
00:30:47.650 --> 00:30:53.490
But the other two, basically what
you can do is one of two things.

655
00:30:53.490 --> 00:30:56.920
If you want your primary
data to be up in AWS,

656
00:30:56.920 --> 00:31:01.100
but you want a copy of
all of your data locally.

657
00:31:01.100 --> 00:31:04.700
Let's say your biggest fear is that Amazon
goes out of business tomorrow right?

658
00:31:04.700 --> 00:31:07.440
What happens if Amazon goes
out of business tomorrow?

659
00:31:07.440 --> 00:31:08.810
I just lost all my data.

660
00:31:08.810 --> 00:31:12.700
And maybe they go in to bankruptcy filing
and the courts freeze all the data, and

661
00:31:12.700 --> 00:31:14.100
I can't get at it.

662
00:31:14.100 --> 00:31:17.150
This happened to a company
not too long ago.

663
00:31:17.150 --> 00:31:22.770
The australian file upload site, that
crazy guy Kim.com, do you know that one?

664
00:31:22.770 --> 00:31:24.110
>> No I didn't know-
>> Mega Upload,

665
00:31:24.110 --> 00:31:25.050
that's what it was-
>> Oh, Mega Upload.

666
00:31:25.050 --> 00:31:25.670
>> Mega Upload.
People

667
00:31:25.670 --> 00:31:29.740
could store all this data in Mega Upload
and it was a lot of illegal stuff, and so

668
00:31:29.740 --> 00:31:32.320
they got shut down, and
people lost their data.

669
00:31:32.320 --> 00:31:36.140
And it was two years before the courts
finally said here's the way you can get at

670
00:31:36.140 --> 00:31:37.380
your data, right.

671
00:31:37.380 --> 00:31:39.260
So imagine if that happened with Amazon.

672
00:31:39.260 --> 00:31:42.840
Well, with the Gateway-Cached
volumes what you can do

673
00:31:42.840 --> 00:31:47.040
is you can store all your data up in
Amazon and you run this gateway appliance.

674
00:31:47.040 --> 00:31:50.250
Again a virtual machine that's running
down on your system that will cache

675
00:31:50.250 --> 00:31:55.430
all of the volumes you have in Amazon and
bring those down locally.

676
00:31:55.430 --> 00:31:57.620
Okay, so you'll have a copy locally.

677
00:31:57.620 --> 00:31:58.890
And if you need to access the data,

678
00:31:58.890 --> 00:32:02.930
you can access the local copy faster
than you can going out to the cloud, and

679
00:32:02.930 --> 00:32:05.330
if Amazon goes out of business
you've got a copy of all the data.

680
00:32:05.330 --> 00:32:06.880
So that's kind of one way to do it.

681
00:32:06.880 --> 00:32:11.840
That's primary data in Amazon,
back up copy at your facility.

682
00:32:11.840 --> 00:32:13.130
You can also do the opposite.

683
00:32:13.130 --> 00:32:15.820
The opposite is a gateway stored volume.

684
00:32:15.820 --> 00:32:18.360
The volumes of data is stored on premise.

685
00:32:18.360 --> 00:32:19.140
It's your network.

686
00:32:19.140 --> 00:32:23.250
You've got the data there,
then you upload, you backup to S3 and

687
00:32:23.250 --> 00:32:24.700
store your data.

688
00:32:24.700 --> 00:32:26.660
That's very similar to
the virtual tape library, but

689
00:32:26.660 --> 00:32:28.970
it gets that whole tape thing
out of the picture, right?

690
00:32:28.970 --> 00:32:31.450
Now, we're just backing up
our data right into S3.

691
00:32:31.450 --> 00:32:35.300
And the way that the appliance works
is it's a virtual machine that you run.

692
00:32:35.300 --> 00:32:38.270
It builds a VPN tunnel back to Amazon.

693
00:32:38.270 --> 00:32:40.950
And that's what connects it in and
it uploads over this secure,

694
00:32:40.950 --> 00:32:43.020
encrypted connection to backup your data.

695
00:32:43.020 --> 00:32:46.750
So three different systems right
there that let you back up your data.

696
00:32:46.750 --> 00:32:48.880
One that emulates a tape drive.

697
00:32:48.880 --> 00:32:51.570
One that backs up Amazon data to you.

698
00:32:51.570 --> 00:32:54.110
And the third that backs
up your data to Amazon.

699
00:32:54.110 --> 00:32:57.970
Be aware of the three of those, and on the
exam, they're kind of easy to confuse, so

700
00:32:57.970 --> 00:33:00.295
make sure you remember which does which,
right?

701
00:33:00.295 --> 00:33:01.580
Gateway-cached?

702
00:33:01.580 --> 00:33:04.485
That's where the data is at Amazon and
the backup is on your side.

703
00:33:04.485 --> 00:33:09.240
Gateway-stored, that's where the data is
on your side and the backup is on Amazon.

704
00:33:09.240 --> 00:33:11.970
And then the virtual tape library,
data is on your side and

705
00:33:11.970 --> 00:33:14.190
it's backed up through
the virtual tapes up to Amazon,

706
00:33:14.190 --> 00:33:16.370
so definitely know the difference
between those three.

707
00:33:16.370 --> 00:33:17.150
>> Awesome stuff, Don.

708
00:33:17.150 --> 00:33:21.200
Well, I know you've got
tons of more backup and

709
00:33:21.200 --> 00:33:25.635
recovery type options for us available
in AWS, but we have run out of time.

710
00:33:25.635 --> 00:33:27.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> Really looking forward to that part

711
00:33:27.350 --> 00:33:28.760
two, so thank you for this part one.

712
00:33:28.760 --> 00:33:31.065
Thank you guys for watching,
we're gonna sign off, and

713
00:33:31.065 --> 00:33:32.615
hopefully we'll see you in part two.

714
00:33:32.615 --> 00:33:35.355
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

715
00:33:35.355 --> 00:33:35.925
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

716
00:33:35.925 --> 00:33:36.937
>> And we'll see you next time.

717
00:33:36.937 --> 00:33:42.900
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel continue their exposition of AWS Disaster Recovery options available in the different AWS services. They pick up with AWS Compute (Amazon Machine Images, Availability Zones, and EC2 VM Import Connector). Then they look at networking backup/redundancy options found in Route 53, Elastic Load Balancers(ELB) and Virtual Private Clouds. From there they jump to database services; Relation Database Service(RDS), DynamoDB, and Redshift. Finally they look at Deployment Orchestration services, specifically CloudFormation, Elastic Beanstalk, and OpsWorks.
episodes.title: Backup and Recovery Services Part 2

WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

Joining me, well you know who he is,

00:01:03.810 --> 00:01:06.880
and how the back up and recovery solutions

22

>> Yeah, and
in our part one we covered storage,

we hit it pretty hard actually,

We do want to be backing up all of
our storage, all of our instances and

things of that nature, but Don,
AWS provides a lot of different services.

26

And from what I can tell they all
have their own kind of backup or

00:01:24.400 --> 00:01:27.680
recovery type of solution and
that's where we're gonna start today.

28

What, where do we begin?

30

We focused on storage,

31
00:01:32.580 --> 00:01:35.860
that one's knocked out, let's just move
on to the next biggest thing, all right?

32
00:01:35.860 --> 00:01:38.200
When most people think of AWS,
they think of instances,

33
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:41.120
they think of virtual machines
running in the cloud.

34
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:42.980
And we need to back those up.

35
00:01:42.980 --> 00:01:46.410
Well, there's actually two different
solutions available for backing up EC2,

36
00:01:46.410 --> 00:01:49.540
and there's even other things
that get kind of involved, right?

37

Let's not even talk about backups,
let's talk about regions, right?

38
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:54.160
I mentioned regions in the last episode.

39
00:01:54.160 --> 00:01:58.410
When you spin up an instance,
there's a chance that instance could fail.

40
00:01:58.410 --> 00:02:00.040
So what do I do?

41
00:02:00.040 --> 00:02:01.640
If I have backups I can always restore it,

42
00:02:01.640 --> 00:02:04.960
but If I'm having to restore from
a backup, that means I've got down time.

43
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:07.290
And if I want to avoid
that down time altogether,

44
00:02:07.290 --> 00:02:08.640
that doesn't necessarily help me, right?

45
00:02:08.640 --> 00:02:13.130
I mean, it helps you recover, but
if you're trying to keep your down time,

46
00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:19.750
your RTO, as low as possible, then what's
better is to have a second instance.

47
00:02:19.750 --> 00:02:22.810
And maybe even a second
instance in a different region.

48
00:02:22.810 --> 00:02:25.800
So I might have five servers
here in US East, and

49
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:28.130
then have five more
servers over in US West.

50
00:02:28.130 --> 00:02:31.570
And then that way if the East servers
fail, then we jump over to West.

51
00:02:31.570 --> 00:02:33.200
And that's where they are up and going.

52
00:02:33.200 --> 00:02:37.550
I can still be running my restores to
get those VM's fixed over in US East.

53
00:02:37.550 --> 00:02:39.030
But the ones in US West are up and going.

54
00:02:39.030 --> 00:02:42.470
Right, so the regions are really a great
example of something we can use to

55
00:02:42.470 --> 00:02:46.160
provide redundancy and
its really redundancy not backup.

56
00:02:46.160 --> 00:02:50.247
Now that's a question I get a lot is well
if I've got more then one server do I need

00:02:50.247 --> 00:02:51.896

58
00:02:51.896 --> 00:02:53.663
Can I just ignore the backups?

59
00:02:53.663 --> 00:02:55.163
And the answers no and

60
00:02:55.163 --> 00:02:59.925
that's because when you have more

61
00:02:59.925 --> 00:03:03.128
I'm saying the answer is whatever

62
00:03:03.128 --> 00:03:04.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what I'm trying to say.

63
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:08.240
You still have to do the backups,
because what happens is yes,

64
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:10.710
if one server fails then you've
got another one over there, right?

65
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:12.420
So it's up and going.

66
00:03:12.420 --> 00:03:15.660
But when you have servers that
are serving up the same website or

67
00:03:15.660 --> 00:03:17.860

68
00:03:17.860 --> 00:03:21.130
You replicate between them so

69
00:03:21.130 --> 00:03:24.740

70
00:03:24.740 --> 00:03:28.470
Well the delete replicates over to

71
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:32.720
And so now, if I need to recover

72
00:03:32.720 --> 00:03:34.804
Well, the other servers

73
00:03:34.804 --> 00:03:37.080
I need my backups.

74
00:03:37.080 --> 00:03:43.061
And the two primary ways to back up
an instance inside of AWS is to use AMIs,

75
00:03:43.061 --> 00:03:48.120
the Amazon Machine Images,
or to use snapshots, right?

76
00:03:48.120 --> 00:03:50.680
Both are effective, and
both kind of serve a different purpose.

77
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:52.390
Let me show you here on my console.

00:03:52.390 --> 00:03:56.530
So if I jump into my console and

It's nothing too special.

It's got Apache on it and that's it.

00:04:06.130 --> 00:04:07.480
Right?
So it's up and running.

85
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:11.320
And if I want to back it up so

00:04:11.320 --> 00:04:15.480
deletes a file by accident,

87
00:04:15.480 --> 00:04:18.750
I can come up here to actions and
I can go into my instance and

00:04:29.550 --> 00:04:32.230
And so when I choose the instance and

00:04:32.230 --> 00:04:36.410

00:04:36.410 --> 00:04:37.340
It's not in these menus.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explore a few different methods for backing up and restoring your on-premises environment with AWS. They start by looking at Pilot Light, which is a low-cost, minimalistic approach to Disaster Recovery in AWS. Then they move to more robust solutions to Disaster Recovery, specifically the Warm Standby and Multi-Site models.
episodes.title: Backup and Restore Scenarios

00:26:22.130 --> 00:26:25.480
So your executives, your staff that
doesn't wanna give up those local servers,

586
00:26:25.480 --> 00:26:26.240
that wants that control.

587
00:26:26.240 --> 00:26:27.550
They've got it.

588
00:26:27.550 --> 00:26:28.520
But then you're already in the cloud.

589
00:26:28.520 --> 00:26:30.590
It's also a great way to migrate
because then if you say,

590
00:26:30.590 --> 00:26:32.410
all right,
we're done with this on-premises stuff.

591
00:26:32.410 --> 00:26:37.190
Let's just move up to AWS, you just go and
change the waiting on your DNS record so

592
00:26:37.190 --> 00:26:40.320
that 90% of the traffic goes up to
the cloud and 10% stays with you.

593
00:26:40.320 --> 00:26:43.390
And maybe you become the disaster recovery
site just in case something happens to

594
00:26:43.390 --> 00:26:44.650
Amazon, right?

595
00:26:44.650 --> 00:26:49.580
But more ideally, you would just set up
another site in another region in AWS and

596
00:26:49.580 --> 00:26:51.110
now it's all in the cloud.

597
00:26:51.110 --> 00:26:53.310
And you don't have physical
equipment to worry about anymore.

598
00:26:53.310 --> 00:26:55.800
And the cost savings alone is significant.

599
00:26:55.800 --> 00:26:59.150
But Amazon's data centers are so
state-of-the-art, so

600
00:26:59.150 --> 00:27:02.280
cutting edge that it would be really
difficult for you to replicate that on

601
00:27:02.280 --> 00:27:05.644
your own within any reasonable budget
unless you worked for the US government.

602
00:27:05.644 --> 00:27:07.550
[LAUGH] Always gotta
throw that one in there.

603
00:27:07.550 --> 00:27:08.750
>> They have a couple of bucks.

604
00:27:08.750 --> 00:27:10.130
Don, you sit here and

605
00:27:10.130 --> 00:27:13.749
touted the greatness of using cloud
service as disaster recovery.

606
00:27:14.770 --> 00:27:20.210
Is there any room for traditional
DR setting anymore to be honest?

607
00:27:20.210 --> 00:27:22.110
>> Personally for me, not usually.

608
00:27:22.110 --> 00:27:25.400
For me if I gonna build some kind of
DR I'm always looking at cloud services,

609
00:27:25.400 --> 00:27:26.350
that's usually I will go.

610
00:27:26.350 --> 00:27:27.468
But there are times we can't.

611
00:27:27.468 --> 00:27:31.580
So maybe you're a hospital and
you're doing medical records and

612
00:27:31.580 --> 00:27:33.520
your worried about
the safety of those records.

613
00:27:33.520 --> 00:27:35.860
Well, Amazon has encrypted data.

614
00:27:35.860 --> 00:27:39.080
You can encrypt an S3 bucket,
you can encrypt your Glacier Storage,

615
00:27:39.080 --> 00:27:41.720
you can encrypt your
virtual tape libraries.

616
00:27:41.720 --> 00:27:45.170
They just rolled out the other day,
you've been able to encrypt EBS,

617
00:27:45.170 --> 00:27:46.350
the elastic block storage.

618
00:27:46.350 --> 00:27:48.450
You've been able to do that for
a long time.

619
00:27:48.450 --> 00:27:51.500
But they just rolled out where you
can now encrypt your operating system

620
00:27:51.500 --> 00:27:53.270
partition for EBS back instance.

621
00:27:53.270 --> 00:27:55.700
You can have entire instances
that are encrypted.

622
00:27:55.700 --> 00:27:59.120
The data is very safe and
Amazon provides great partitioning.

623
00:27:59.120 --> 00:28:03.120
They are certified for
numerous regulatory compliance laws.

624
00:28:03.120 --> 00:28:04.420
So they've got you covered.

625
00:28:05.800 --> 00:28:08.950
But there's still that trust, right?

626
00:28:08.950 --> 00:28:11.220
Name an employee at Amazon.

627
00:28:11.220 --> 00:28:12.105
>> I couldn't tell you one.

628
00:28:12.105 --> 00:28:12.607
>> Jeff Bezos.
>> [LAUGH]

629
00:28:12.607 --> 00:28:13.109
>> That's it.

630
00:28:13.109 --> 00:28:14.380
[CROSSTALK]

631
00:28:14.380 --> 00:28:14.880
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]

632
00:28:14.880 --> 00:28:15.832
>> I've got the big guy.

633
00:28:15.832 --> 00:28:16.528
>> You did one, I got zero.

634
00:28:16.528 --> 00:28:18.623
>> I can not name a single other employee

635
00:28:18.623 --> 00:28:22.712
at Amazon and so we trust these people
that we don't even know, right?

636
00:28:22.712 --> 00:28:25.094
And so if you don't have that trust,

637
00:28:25.094 --> 00:28:28.310
then that's the time where the Cloud
is not an option, but there's no

638
00:28:28.310 --> 00:28:31.720
technical reason that you couldn't use it.
There's no financial reason that you

639
00:28:31.720 --> 00:28:33.870
couldn't use it.
There's no technical desire reason,

640
00:28:33.870 --> 00:28:37.500
it's easy to learn, it's easy to deploy,
it's my first option, it's what I do.

641
00:28:37.500 --> 00:28:40.190
>> The opposite would be true,
there's all the technical reasons and

642
00:28:40.190 --> 00:28:43.720
financial reasons in the world to use
this model versus the traditional.

643
00:28:43.720 --> 00:28:45.990
Oh yeah, I guess if you say it that way.

644
00:28:45.990 --> 00:28:49.094
>> [CROSSTALK] But yeah, it would
really just come down to that trust.

645
00:28:49.094 --> 00:28:51.706
There are some people who just
don't have that trust, and

646
00:28:51.706 --> 00:28:53.800
I'm not saying that's not founded, right?

647
00:28:53.800 --> 00:28:55.650
It just means that you really care for
your customer and

648
00:28:55.650 --> 00:28:56.610
want to take care of them.

649
00:28:56.610 --> 00:28:57.840
And that's the right thing, right?

650
00:28:57.840 --> 00:29:00.660
And so, in that situation
it may not be an option but

651
00:29:00.660 --> 00:29:03.140
that's what it would come down to, right?

652
00:29:03.140 --> 00:29:08.360
Not technical, not financial, those
are all things that are pro for using AWS.

653
00:29:08.360 --> 00:29:08.920
>> Well, awesome, and

654
00:29:08.920 --> 00:29:12.380
this definitely sounds like AWS
is going to be the solution for

655
00:29:12.380 --> 00:29:17.870
many an IT group out there so thank you so
much Don for showing us our way around it,

656
00:29:17.870 --> 00:29:21.210
kind of giving us a tour of what they
offer as far as disaster recovery.

657
00:29:21.210 --> 00:29:22.520
Anything else you want
to add before we go?

658
00:29:22.520 --> 00:29:25.760
>> Yeah, you know, the exam,
they don't hit on this that much but

659
00:29:25.760 --> 00:29:27.300
I do want to mention it.

660
00:29:27.300 --> 00:29:32.160
Failing over to AWS, that's kind of one
step, but at some point you're going to

661
00:29:32.160 --> 00:29:36.210
rebuild your facility and you may or may
not choose to rebuild your data center.

662
00:29:36.210 --> 00:29:39.110
You might say, you know what, we failed
our AWS, things are running great.

663
00:29:39.110 --> 00:29:41.020
Let's just leave it in AWS.

664
00:29:41.020 --> 00:29:44.270
So at that point your next
step would be to build

665
00:29:44.270 --> 00:29:47.310
a new DR site in AWS in
a different region, right?

666
00:29:47.310 --> 00:29:50.920
So your current DR site in AWS
now becomes your production.

667
00:29:50.920 --> 00:29:52.660
And then you pick another region.

668
00:29:52.660 --> 00:29:53.770
You start building up servers.

669
00:29:53.770 --> 00:29:57.470
And you basically set up the same
typologies that I just showed you

670
00:29:57.470 --> 00:29:59.040
in the other region, right?

671
00:29:59.040 --> 00:30:00.680
So you kinda go through that process.

672
00:30:00.680 --> 00:30:02.220
And now you're entirely in the cloud.

673
00:30:02.220 --> 00:30:06.860
But if you had on-premises equipment for
a reason and you want to get back to that,

674
00:30:06.860 --> 00:30:09.830
well, now what you have to do is
basically set up the opposite.

675
00:30:09.830 --> 00:30:12.180
You've gotta buy a new building.

676
00:30:12.180 --> 00:30:13.920
Build a new data center.

677
00:30:13.920 --> 00:30:16.120
Order your servers, get them put in place.

678
00:30:16.120 --> 00:30:17.270
Install their operating systems.

679
00:30:17.270 --> 00:30:18.240
Get them configured.

680
00:30:18.240 --> 00:30:22.290
Get a database set up that's
replicating changes from AWS back down.

681
00:30:22.290 --> 00:30:24.630
And then once it's all up,
you've gotta redirect traffic.

682
00:30:24.630 --> 00:30:27.110
And Amazon recommends two
different methods for that.

683
00:30:27.110 --> 00:30:29.780
One method is what I just described,
kind of setting up the replication and

684
00:30:29.780 --> 00:30:30.840
moving people over.

685
00:30:30.840 --> 00:30:34.580
The other thing is you could just
freeze changes in the cloud so

686
00:30:34.580 --> 00:30:37.030
that people can get to your site but
they can't make changes and

687
00:30:37.030 --> 00:30:40.810
then repoint them over locally
after you've synced things over.

688
00:30:40.810 --> 00:30:42.700
That's fine unless you're
a transaction business.

689
00:30:42.700 --> 00:30:44.980
You know, if you're doing sales you
can't just freeze the site and say hey,

690
00:30:44.980 --> 00:30:46.840
we're not gonna take sales for a few days.

691
00:30:46.840 --> 00:30:49.370
I guess you could but it's really
gonna tick off the executives so

692
00:30:49.370 --> 00:30:54.070
we want to avoid that if we can so that's
another part kind of of failing back.

693
00:30:54.070 --> 00:30:55.540
But there's a lot of challenges for that.

694
00:30:55.540 --> 00:30:57.870
It takes a long time to get
those servers back up and

695
00:30:57.870 --> 00:31:02.360
in the meantime you're running
from inside one region in AWS.

696
00:31:02.360 --> 00:31:05.030
So even if you're going to rebuild
your physical data center,

697
00:31:05.030 --> 00:31:09.390
it's still a good idea to build a
temporary DR site in another Amazon region

698
00:31:09.390 --> 00:31:12.030
just in the interim until you can
get your servers in and stuff.

699
00:31:12.030 --> 00:31:16.180
And unlike a physical disaster recovery
site, when we're done with this temporary

700
00:31:16.180 --> 00:31:17.790
one, you just delete it and
you stop paying for it.

701
00:31:17.790 --> 00:31:20.260
Versus a physical site where you'd still
have the building and the lease and

702
00:31:20.260 --> 00:31:23.080
all that other stuff to mess with,
here it's far more simple.

703
00:31:23.080 --> 00:31:25.280
>> Well,
it definitely sounds a lot more simple.

704
00:31:25.280 --> 00:31:28.440
And that would be the way that I
would want to go if it were up to me.

705
00:31:28.440 --> 00:31:31.690
Don, thank you so much for showing us
how to work our way through this thing.

706
00:31:31.690 --> 00:31:33.170
And thank you guys so much for watching.

707
00:31:33.170 --> 00:31:34.880
We're going ahead and close down the show.

708
00:31:34.880 --> 00:31:38.080
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

709
00:31:38.080 --> 00:31:39.707
>> And I'm Don Pozette
>> And we'll see you next time.

710

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe how to employ backups for AWS Relational Database Services(RDS). Here they cover some details about how RDS is backed up as well as some pre-requisite work that needs to be done to prepare RDS for being backed up. Then they show you how to setup automated backups and/or take an on-demand backup. Finally they explain the procedure for restoring your data in case of a failure.
episodes.title: Backing up RDS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.271 --> 00:00:10.271
[MUSIC]

2

to another exciting episode of IT Pro TV.

3

I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we're continuing on with

4
00:00:20.160 --> 00:00:24.050
our AWS certified Syl soft admin,

And joining us to lend his

6

00:00:29.925 --> 00:00:31.475

9

Thanks for having me back on the show and

00:00:33.455 --> 00:00:36.645

12

In this episode we're going to be

13

The Amazon Relational Database Service.

14
00:00:42.865 --> 00:00:44.635
Databases are super important.

15
00:00:44.635 --> 00:00:46.245
We put a lot of our company data in there.

16
00:00:46.245 --> 00:00:47.555
We have entire websites and

other things that depend on

So a backup and

critical, and with Amazon,

00:01:05.380 --> 00:01:08.260
But we still need to be aware of how it

00:01:08.260 --> 00:01:11.590
see to make sure the backups are

24
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:13.760
And that's what we're gonna

25

>> Yeah.

cuz if you're a DBA like I am.

be hosed in a matter of at least minutes.

28
00:01:22.565 --> 00:01:26.420
[LAUGH] We need to have some steps in
place to make sure that we can put

00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:27.900
them back the way they're supposed to be.

>> When you started saying that, you're
like "when you're a DBA like I am" and

31
00:01:31.860 --> 00:01:33.190
I'm thinking, "a bad one?" [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You know me.

32
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:38.770
>> Yeah, you know one of the the best
parts about Amazon's RDS service.

33
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:41.770
It is a little more expensive than
if you spun up an instance and

34
00:01:41.770 --> 00:01:43.810
put the data base on there yourself,
right?

35
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:47.290
But when you do that, if you just spin
up an Amazon Linux instance right,

36
00:01:47.290 --> 00:01:50.480
in a chuck MySQL on there,
you have to manage it yourself.

37
00:01:50.480 --> 00:01:53.270
You have to manage all the different ins
and outs, the optimizations happen on it,

38
00:01:53.270 --> 00:01:54.300
the backups, the recovery.

39

It's all kind of up to you.

40
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:58.580
That when you do it through RDS,
they charge a little bit more, and for

41

that extra money, they completely
manage the underlying layers of it, so

42

43

We don't even have to really worry

44

They take care of that too.

45
00:02:07.628 --> 00:02:11.184
They even do the backups and
set it up for easy management.

46
00:02:11.184 --> 00:02:14.820
So, let's see how that works and
kind of an idea on it.

47
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:16.069
When we set this up,

48
00:02:16.069 --> 00:02:20.750
the main intention is gonna be to set
up to back up our database, right?

49
00:02:20.750 --> 00:02:24.000
And then if we ever have a failure, and
by a failure, I don't normally mean

50
00:02:24.000 --> 00:02:26.950
an infrastructure failure,
cuz Amazon's gonna resolve that for us.

51
00:02:26.950 --> 00:02:29.820
I'm talking about
an accidental user deletion.

52
00:02:29.820 --> 00:02:32.410
Somebody hacks into your database and
wipes out several tables, or

53
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:35.300
you just do a bad insert statement and
overwrite something by accident,

54
00:02:35.300 --> 00:02:37.650
and you need to retrieve that data, right?

55
00:02:37.650 --> 00:02:41.360
That's the type of recovery that we
normally have to deal with with RDS.

56
00:02:41.360 --> 00:02:43.930
Cuz any infrastructure
stuff is handled by Amazon.

57
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:45.640
So, that's how we're
normally going to use this.

58
00:02:45.640 --> 00:02:46.930
But you can use this in other ways.

59
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:50.710
In fact if you watched one of our
earlier episodes we talked about

60
00:02:51.890 --> 00:02:55.890
the different storage types for
S3 or for RDS where

61
00:02:55.890 --> 00:03:00.210
we could do generally provisioned SSD,
or generally purposed SSD.

62
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:03.870
And we could do provisioned IOPS, SSD.

63
00:03:03.870 --> 00:03:06.360
There's not a great way
to flip between the two.

64
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:09.000
But you can do a back up of a server and
then you can restore it.

65
00:03:09.000 --> 00:03:11.140
And restore it as the different type, and

66
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:14.740
now you just upgraded to provisioned
IOPS or downgraded to general purpose.

67
00:03:14.740 --> 00:03:17.460
You can also do that with
your database instance, too.

68
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:23.190
You can say, for example maybe I deployed
a Microsoft SQL Standard Edition server.

69
00:03:23.190 --> 00:03:25.970

Microsoft SQL Enterprise.

70
00:03:25.970 --> 00:03:30.000
Well I can back the server up, and when I
restore it I can flip it to enterprise.

71
00:03:30.000 --> 00:03:32.160
And now it's going to come up and

72
00:03:32.160 --> 00:03:34.920
So the backup and
recovery process is not just for

00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:36.700

00:03:36.700 --> 00:03:38.220
It can actually be used for upgrading or

75
00:03:38.220 --> 00:03:42.530
downgrading your server in some scenarios,
and that's a pretty cool thing to do.

76
00:03:42.530 --> 00:03:44.790
So there's just a lot of
power to be found in there.

77
00:03:44.790 --> 00:03:45.530
>> Awesome.
Now, Don,

78
00:03:45.530 --> 00:03:47.180
is there anything that I need to do?

79
00:03:47.180 --> 00:03:49.790
Or can I just start using
these backup systems.

80
00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:52.850
Or there's some back end stuff
that I gotta kinda delve into.

81
00:03:52.850 --> 00:03:54.890
>> So if you're doing a new
database deployment, right?

82
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:57.550
You're just rolling out
a brand new database today?

83
00:03:57.550 --> 00:03:58.980
It's all in the setup wizard, right?

84
00:03:58.980 --> 00:04:00.970
So as you're going through the wizard,
you'll hit the backup spot.

85
00:04:00.970 --> 00:04:02.860
You can set your backups and that's that.

86
00:04:02.860 --> 00:04:04.870
So it's really easy for something new.

87
00:04:04.870 --> 00:04:08.030
But if you've got an existing database and
you're wanting to go in there and

88
00:04:08.030 --> 00:04:11.490
either modify its backups or
start to configure backups on it.

89
00:04:11.490 --> 00:04:13.580
When you do that there's a few
things we need to be aware of.

90
00:04:13.580 --> 00:04:19.260
One of the big things is the most
popular RDS database engine on

91
00:04:19.260 --> 00:04:25.280
Amazon is MySQL or
MariaDB which is basically the same thing.

92
00:04:25.280 --> 00:04:29.780
When you do that, MySQL actually has
two database engines in it, right?

93
00:04:29.780 --> 00:04:32.400
It's got MyISAM,
which is the older one and

94
00:04:32.400 --> 00:04:35.000
it's got InnoDB, which is the newer one.

95
00:04:35.000 --> 00:04:37.235
There's a big difference between the two.

96
00:04:37.235 --> 00:04:43.270
MyISAM writes data faster, because you're
writing directly into the data files.

97
00:04:43.270 --> 00:04:44.250
With InnoDB,

98
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:47.590
it writes a little slower because you
don't write to the database files,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don go over the topic of billing and cost management for your AWS account(s). Here they cover cost optimization in the AWS dashboard to quickly see how much you're spending and how much Amazon predicts you'll be spending. Then they take a look at more detailed billing info through IAM and the use of cost allocation tags. Lastly they explain the cost differences with each of the EC2 instance types(On Demand/Reserved/Spot).

00:27:55.710 --> 00:27:59.950
So if I'm gonna use the server long term,
it makes more sense to go ahead and

571
00:27:59.950 --> 00:28:02.870
do a reserved instance.

572
00:28:02.870 --> 00:28:05.650
But even if I was only gonna use it for
three months.

573
00:28:05.650 --> 00:28:10.020
Let's say I use it for three months,
I paid $470 on day one, I then used it for

574
00:28:10.020 --> 00:28:12.743
three months, my total spent $524.

575
00:28:12.743 --> 00:28:16.840
Right there,
I'm more expensive than On Demand.

576
00:28:16.840 --> 00:28:18.900
But look what happens in month four.

577
00:28:18.900 --> 00:28:23.553
Month four, my spend is $551,
over here my spend is $563.

578
00:28:23.553 --> 00:28:24.990
It's cheaper.

579
00:28:24.990 --> 00:28:31.450
And if I turn the server off right there,
and I don't use that instance ever again,

580
00:28:31.450 --> 00:28:34.210
for the rest of the year these
would all drop to zeros.

581
00:28:34.210 --> 00:28:37.380
And it would end up being cheaper
than if I'd done it On Demand,

582
00:28:37.380 --> 00:28:39.440
even though I only used it for
four months.

583
00:28:39.440 --> 00:28:41.930
So even though you sign
a one year contract,

584
00:28:41.930 --> 00:28:44.340
you don't actually have to use
the server for that one year.

585
00:28:44.340 --> 00:28:48.600
You have it, but even if you shut it off,
if you at least use if for

586
00:28:48.600 --> 00:28:51.680
four months, you'll save money
over an On Demand, right?

587
00:28:53.020 --> 00:28:54.290
But not everybody thinks that way.

588
00:28:54.290 --> 00:28:57.140
People fear the contract, and so
you pay the On Demand price, and

589
00:28:57.140 --> 00:28:57.720
you have no contract.

590
00:28:57.720 --> 00:29:01.050
>> So really, it comes down to trying
to work out your financial strategy.

591
00:29:01.050 --> 00:29:02.990
How long am I going to use this server?

592
00:29:02.990 --> 00:29:05.970
How often am I going to need
this service available to me?

593
00:29:05.970 --> 00:29:07.610
It's going to be a short term.

594
00:29:07.610 --> 00:29:09.530
Well, that On Demand might
be the way to go, but

595
00:29:09.530 --> 00:29:12.860
if it's long-term,
that's going to be the right thing.

596
00:29:12.860 --> 00:29:15.420
>> And
on the three years reserved instance,

597
00:29:15.420 --> 00:29:16.720
it gets even a little more weird.

598
00:29:16.720 --> 00:29:18.880
On three years reserved instance
the up-front cost is higher,

599
00:29:18.880 --> 00:29:21.920
like if we look at my chart here,
day one, I'm at $694.

600
00:29:21.920 --> 00:29:25.420
And so all year long I'm
behind the eight ball, right?

601
00:29:25.420 --> 00:29:29.572
These red Ns over here letting me know
that at the end of the year I'm paying

602
00:29:29.572 --> 00:29:32.650
$935, that's more expensive than
if I'd done a one year, right?

603
00:29:32.650 --> 00:29:37.030
But then in January, if I had done a one
year, I have that up front cost again,

604
00:29:37.030 --> 00:29:38.880
there's another $470.

605
00:29:38.880 --> 00:29:39.460
Right?

606
00:29:39.460 --> 00:29:41.650
But on a three year I
wouldn't have that cost and

607
00:29:41.650 --> 00:29:43.620
we immediately start saving money.

608
00:29:43.620 --> 00:29:49.360
The three year contracts save you money
in the first month of the second year.

609
00:29:49.360 --> 00:29:52.430
So even if I only use it 13 or
14 months and then cut it off and

610
00:29:52.430 --> 00:29:53.660
didn't use it again for two more years,

611
00:29:53.660 --> 00:29:58.940
it would still be cheaper than if I had
done one years throughout that time.

612
00:29:58.940 --> 00:30:01.900
So you just need to look at how
long you're gonna use the server.

613
00:30:01.900 --> 00:30:02.930
If you're gonna use the server for

614
00:30:02.930 --> 00:30:07.240
more than three months, and the prices
have changed but the times really haven't.

615
00:30:07.240 --> 00:30:10.070
If you're gonna use the server for
more than three months, a one year

616
00:30:10.070 --> 00:30:13.320
reserved instance is going to save you
money even if you turn it off early.

617
00:30:14.380 --> 00:30:18.200
If you're gonna use it for more than one
year, a three year reserved instance is

618
00:30:18.200 --> 00:30:21.680
gonna save you money even if you
turn it off after the 1st year.

619
00:30:21.680 --> 00:30:23.400
So that's how you have to look at it.

620
00:30:23.400 --> 00:30:24.939
Don't look at it as
a three year commitment.

621
00:30:24.939 --> 00:30:26.982
Look at it as a 13 month commitment.

622
00:30:26.982 --> 00:30:29.070
Don't look it as a one
year reserved instance.

623
00:30:29.070 --> 00:30:32.010
Look at it as a four month commitment cuz
that's where to start to save the money.

624
00:30:32.010 --> 00:30:34.307
And otherwise you're at
the same price as an On Demand.

625
00:30:34.307 --> 00:30:37.297
So keep that in mind when it
comes to cost optimization.

626
00:30:37.297 --> 00:30:41.530
If you don't fear the contracts, if you go
into the contracts, you will save money.

627
00:30:41.530 --> 00:30:43.490
And that's a great way
to optimize your costs.

628
00:30:43.490 --> 00:30:44.020
>> And very cool.

629
00:30:44.020 --> 00:30:45.660
Thank you.
Thank you for showing us that.

630
00:30:45.660 --> 00:30:47.280
Then now maybe we won't be so

631
00:30:47.280 --> 00:30:50.950
afraid of diving into those
reserves types of instances.

632
00:30:50.950 --> 00:30:53.090
So they can work out to our benefit.

633
00:30:53.090 --> 00:30:55.770
Specifically, financially,
which is always a nice thing.

634
00:30:55.770 --> 00:30:58.420
Now Dom, we talked about monitoring.

635
00:30:58.420 --> 00:31:01.530
We have the, we can go in and
see the financial monitor.

636
00:31:01.530 --> 00:31:02.910
It gives us that nice view.

637
00:31:02.910 --> 00:31:07.350
We also have that, where it can
create that, generate the report for

638
00:31:07.350 --> 00:31:08.780
us, see the tags.

639
00:31:08.780 --> 00:31:11.498
And we do want to get into a little
more of that because there's

640
00:31:11.498 --> 00:31:13.710
some really cool things we
want to look at as well.

641
00:31:13.710 --> 00:31:15.388
But our clock is down yet again.

642
00:31:15.388 --> 00:31:20.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is a wicked mistress.

643
00:31:20.790 --> 00:31:22.170
Always a slave driver.

644
00:31:22.170 --> 00:31:24.750
So we're going to have to
do another part for this.

645
00:31:24.750 --> 00:31:26.230
>> Yeah let's just break
it up into another part.

646
00:31:26.230 --> 00:31:27.640
It won't be a long episode, but

647
00:31:27.640 --> 00:31:30.820
I definitely want to talk about
setting alarms for our billings so

648
00:31:30.820 --> 00:31:32.830
you can get emails that warn you
when things are going crazy.

649
00:31:32.830 --> 00:31:34.560
And I want to talk about
consolidated billing.

650
00:31:34.560 --> 00:31:37.080
So a little bit more there that you might
have to set up as an administrator.

651
00:31:37.080 --> 00:31:38.220
But what we've seen so far,

652
00:31:38.220 --> 00:31:41.100
you guys get an idea of how we
can get all our building data.

653
00:31:41.100 --> 00:31:42.460
We can really optimize things.

654
00:31:42.460 --> 00:31:44.550
We can save money and
really have a great solution out there.

655
00:31:44.550 --> 00:31:45.930
So definitely stay tuned for part two.

656
00:31:45.930 --> 00:31:47.860
We'll see a few more of those pieces.

657
00:31:47.860 --> 00:31:49.200
>> Awesome.
Thank you so much Don for

658
00:31:49.200 --> 00:31:50.750
showing us what we've seen so far.

659
00:31:50.750 --> 00:31:52.410
Hopefully we'll see you in part two.

660
00:31:52.410 --> 00:31:56.486
As for this one, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

00:31:56.486 --> 00:31:57.376

>> Yeah, yeah lets

a dollar 50 per day, and so that meant the

35
00:01:54.985 --> 00:01:58.530
that bit of data in an Amazon S3 bucket.

36
00:01:58.530 --> 00:01:59.270
Right?

37
00:01:59.270 --> 00:02:01.860
And one month the bill came out.

And the bill,

00:02:06.070 --> 00:02:08.410

The bill was significantly higher.

47

Alright.

I showed you the cost explorer

I'll kinda re-enact what I did.

So, what I did is I kinda went into

00:02:41.230 --> 00:02:46.430
Cost Management, and then, from in here

55
00:02:46.430 --> 00:02:50.099
And so for them, for example,

And it'll tell you where that

I was seeing that the bulk of

59

But for them,
it was almost the entire donut.

00:03:11.250 --> 00:03:14.710
And s, if you jump in here, you can

64
00:03:14.710 --> 00:03:17.820
And my account apparently doesn't have
enough traffic on it right now to generate

00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:18.860
any good data.

66
00:03:18.860 --> 00:03:23.810
But, you know maybe if I do the last

This is like the eleventh

There we go.

00:03:41.950 --> 00:03:45.280
So, I can start to see month by month,

So, I'm in the month view here.

00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:49.800
If I go day by day,
now I can start to get this broken out.

00:03:49.800 --> 00:03:51.720

00:03:51.720 --> 00:03:56.270
So, on this day, it was $1.34,
which, let me zoom in on that a bit.

00:03:56.270 --> 00:04:01.322
So, as we start to look at this, I can
see on this day it was $1.34, on this day

00:04:01.322 --> 00:04:06.950
it was $0.78, on this day it was $0.89,
on this day it was $1.59, right?

00:04:06.950 --> 00:04:09.640
So, and then,
I get this forecast of what they

they think I'm gonna to be

They, they always give you a little

85

So, what I was able to do

00:04:32.140 --> 00:04:34.350
It was really between like 35 and $40.

00:04:40.150 --> 00:04:42.120
Now, where that's important is two things.

00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:47.050
So one, it was ten times

00:04:47.050 --> 00:04:49.610
Two, it was just the last

If that had been happening all month long,

00:04:51.570 --> 00:04:53.670
it wouldn't have been $400
it would have been $1200.

97
00:04:53.670 --> 00:04:55.840
It would have been a lot more, right?

98
00:04:55.840 --> 00:04:58.970
So, it was important that we caught it
early on and I caught it by looking at

99
00:04:58.970 --> 00:05:02.780
the monthly bill, but
by just watching the monthly bill,

100
00:05:02.780 --> 00:05:06.790
I allowed ten days to go by with that
higher spending, before I even noticed it.

101
00:05:06.790 --> 00:05:10.290
So, just watching the monthly bills,
is not necessarily the greatest practice.

102
00:05:10.290 --> 00:05:12.070
So, if you really want to contro,l and

103
00:05:12.070 --> 00:05:16.880
monitor your costs,
it's a better idea, to set up alerts.

104
00:05:16.880 --> 00:05:20.720
I knew that their average daily spend

105
00:05:20.720 --> 00:05:22.280
I knew that.

00:05:22.280 --> 00:05:23.750

00:05:23.750 --> 00:05:26.130
That the files have a really low traffic,

00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:27.610
I told them it's gonna

00:05:27.610 --> 00:05:30.820
Don't bother setting up a server,

00:05:30.820 --> 00:05:32.620
Right.

00:05:32.620 --> 00:05:37.600

00:05:37.600 --> 00:05:42.510

114
00:05:45.890 --> 00:05:47.140
And they said, oh, yeah.

115
00:05:47.140 --> 00:05:48.940
That S3 bug has been working so great.

116
00:05:48.940 --> 00:05:51.510
We decided to stick some videos in there.

00:05:51.510 --> 00:05:52.790
And that's what they did.

00:05:52.790 --> 00:05:57.760
And so, the bandwidth utilization went

119
00:05:57.760 --> 00:06:00.260
Now, there were some videos,
some MP4s, or MOVs, or

120
00:06:00.260 --> 00:06:03.330

00:06:03.330 --> 00:06:06.100
There was larger amounts of data,

122
00:06:06.100 --> 00:06:07.480
So, they knew exactly what they did.

123
00:06:07.480 --> 00:06:08.380
They were the ones that did it.

124
00:06:08.380 --> 00:06:09.900
So, they just removed
the files from there.

125
00:06:09.900 --> 00:06:12.610
And then,
the spin went back to the way it was.

126
00:06:12.610 --> 00:06:15.190

I could've said, hey,

00:06:15.190 --> 00:06:19.110

$2.00 a day or whatever.

128
00:06:19.110 --> 00:06:22.930
So, I might set an alert that says,

129
00:06:22.930 --> 00:06:23.520
